10130-8{_}4670{_}I looked down on all my young companions as my inferiors; but I chiefly assumed airs of superiority over Maria Hartley, whose father was a clerk in my father's counting-house, and therefore I concluded she would regard the fine show I made with more envy and admiration than any other of my companions.
10130-8{_}4671{_}In the days of my humiliation, which I too soon experienced, I was thrown on the bounty of her father for support.
10130-8{_}4672{_}To be a dependent on the charity of her family, seemed the heaviest evil that could have befallen me; for I remembered how often I had displayed my finery and my expensive ornaments, on purpose to enjoy the triumph of my superior advantages; and with shame I now speak it, I have often glanced at her plain linen frock, when I shewed her my beautiful ball-dresses.
10130-8{_}4673{_}Nay, I once gave her a hint, which she so well understood that she burst into tears, that I could not invite her to some of my parties, because her mamma once sent her on my birthday in a coloured frock.
10130-8{_}4674{_}I cannot now think of my want of feeling without excessive pain; but one day I saw her highly amused with some curious toys, and on her expressing the pleasure the sight of them gave her, I said "Yes, they are very well for those who are not accustomed to these things; but for my part, I have so many, I am tired of them, and I am quite delighted to pass an hour in the empty closet your mamma allows you to receive your visitors in, because there is nothing there to interrupt the conversation."
10130-8{_}4675{_}Once, as I have said, Maria was betrayed into tears: now that I insulted her by calling her own small apartment an empty closet, she turned quick upon me, but not in anger, saying, "O, my dear miss Wilmot, how very sorry I am--" here she stopped; and though I knew not the meaning of her words, I felt it as a reproof.
10130-8{_}4676{_}I hung down my head abashed; yet, perceiving that she was all that day more kind and obliging than ever, and being conscious of not having merited this kindness, I thought she was mean-spirited, and therefore I consoled myself with having discovered this fault in her, for I thought my arrogance was full as excusable as her meanness.
10130-8{_}4677{_}In a few days I knew my error; I learned why Maria had been so kind, and why she had said she was sorry.
10130-8{_}4678{_}It was for me, proud disdainful girl that I was, that she was sorry; she knew, though I did not, that my father was on the brink of ruin; and it came to pass, as she had feared it would, that in a few days my play-room was as empty as Maria's closet, and all my grandeur was at an end.
10130-8{_}4679{_}My father had what is called an execution in the house; every thing was seized that we possessed.
10130-8{_}4680{_}Our splendid furniture, and even our wearing apparel, all my beautiful ball-dresses, my trinkets, and, my toys, were taken away by my father's merciless creditors.
10130-8{_}4681{_}The week in which this happened was such a scene of hurry, confusion and misery, that I will not attempt to describe it.
10130-8{_}4682{_}At the end of a week I found that my father and mother had gone out very early in the morning.
10130-8{_}4683{_}Mr. Hartley took me home to his own house, and I expected to find them there; but, oh, what anguish did I feel, when I heard him tell Mrs. Hartley they had quitted England, and that he had brought me home to live with them!
10130-8{_}4684{_}In tears and sullen silence I passed the first day of my entrance into this despised house.
10130-8{_}4685{_}Maria was from home.
10130-8{_}4686{_}All the day I sate in a corner of the room, grieving for the departure of my parents; and if for a moment I forgot that sorrow, I tormented myself with imagining the many ways which Maria might invent, to make me feel in return the slights and airs of superiority which I had given myself over her.
10130-8{_}4687{_}Her mother began the prelude to what I expected, for I heard her freely censure the imprudence of my parents.
10130-8{_}4688{_}She spoke in whispers; yet, though I could not hear every word, I made out the tenor of her discourse.
10130-8{_}4689{_}She was very anxious, lest her husband should be involved in the ruin of our house.
10130-8{_}4690{_}He was the chief clerk in my father's counting-house; towards evening he came in and quieted her fears, by the welcome news that he had obtained a more lucrative situation than the one he had lost.
10130-8{_}4691{_}At eight in the evening Mrs. Hartley said to me, "Miss Wilmot, it is time for you to be in bed, my dear;" and ordered the servant to shew me up stairs, adding, that she supposed she must assist me to undress, but that when Maria came home, she must teach me to wait on myself.
10130-8{_}4692{_}The apartment in which I was to sleep was at the top of the house.
10130-8{_}4693{_}The walls were white-washed, and the roof was sloping.
10130-8{_}4694{_}There was only one window in the room, a small casement, through which the bright moon shone, and it seemed to me the most melancholy sight I had ever beheld.
10130-8{_}4695{_}In broken and disturbed slumbers I passed the night.
10130-8{_}4696{_}When I awoke in the morning, she whom I most dreaded to see, Maria, who I supposed had envied my former state, and who I now felt certain would exult over my present mortifying reverse of fortune, stood by my bedside.
10130-8{_}4697{_}She awakened me from a dream, in which I thought she was ordering me to fetch her something; and on my refusal, she said I must obey her, for I was now her servant.
10130-8{_}4698{_}Far differently from what my dreams had pictured, did Maria address me!
10130-8{_}4699{_}She said, in the gentlest tone imaginable, "My dear miss Wilmot, my mother begs you will come down to breakfast.
10130-8{_}4700{_}Will you give me leave to dress you?"
10130-8{_}4701{_}My proud heart would not suffer me to speak, and I began to attempt to put on my clothes; but never having been used to do any thing for myself, I was unable to perform it, and was obliged to accept of the assistance of Maria.
10130-8{_}4702{_}She dressed me, washed my face, and combed my hair; and as she did these services for me, she said in the most respectful manner, "Is this the way you like to wear this, miss Wilmot?"
10130-8{_}4703{_}or, "Is this the way you like this done?"
10130-8{_}4704{_}and curtsied, as she gave me every fresh article to put on.
10130-8{_}4705{_}The slights I expected to receive from Maria, would not have distressed me more, than the delicacy of her behaviour did.
10130-8{_}4706{_}I hung down my head with shame and anguish.
10130-8{_}4707{_}In a few days Mrs. Hartley ordered her daughter to instruct me in such useful works and employments as Maria knew.
10130-8{_}4708{_}Of every thing which she called useful I was most ignorant.
10130-8{_}4709{_}My accomplishments I found were held in small estimation here, by all indeed except Maria.
10130-8{_}4710{_}She taught me nothing without the kindest apologies for being obliged to teach me, who, she said, was so excellent in all elegant arts, and was for ever thanking me for the pleasure she had formerly received, from my skill in music and pretty fancy works.
10130-8{_}4711{_}The distress I was in, made these complimentary speeches not flatteries, but sweet drops of comfort to my degraded heart, almost broken with misfortune and remorse.
10130-8{_}4712{_}I remained at Mr. Hartley's but two months, for at the end of that time my father inherited a considerable property by the death of a distant relation, which has enabled him to settle his affairs.
10130-8{_}4713{_}He established himself again as a merchant; but as he wished to retrench his expences, and begin the world again on a plan of strict economy, he sent me to this school to finish my education.
10130-8{_}4714{_}IX  SUSAN YATES  (_By Charles Lamb_)   I was born and brought up, in a house in which my parents had all their lives resided, which stood in the midst of that lonely tract of land called the Lincolnshire fens.
10130-8{_}4715{_}Few families besides our own lived near the spot, both because it was reckoned an unwholesome air, and because its distance from any town or market made it an inconvenient situation.
10130-8{_}4716{_}My father was in no very affluent circumstances, and it was a sad necessity which he was put to, of having to go many miles to fetch any thing he wanted from the nearest village, which was full seven miles distant, through a sad miry way that at all times made it heavy walking, and after rain was almost impassable.
10130-8{_}4717{_}But he had no horse or carriage of his own.
10130-8{_}4718{_}The church which belonged to the parish in which our house was situated, stood in this village; and its distance being, as I said before, seven miles from our house, made it quite an impossible thing for my mother or me to think of going to it.
10130-8{_}4719{_}Sometimes indeed, on a fine dry Sunday, my father would rise early, and take a walk to the village, just to see how _goodness thrived_, as he used to say, but he would generally return tired, and the worse for his walk.
10130-8{_}4720{_}It is scarcely possible to explain to any one who has not lived in the fens, what difficult and dangerous walking it is.
10130-8{_}4721{_}A mile is as good as four, I have heard my father say, in those parts.
10130-8{_}4722{_}My mother, who in the early part of her life had lived in a more civilised spot, and had been used to constant churchgoing, would often lament her situation.
10130-8{_}4723{_}It was from her I early imbibed a great curiosity and anxiety to see that thing, which I had heard her call a church, and so often lament that she could never go to.
10130-8{_}4724{_}I had seen houses of various structures, and had seen in pictures the shapes of ships and boats, and palaces and temples, but never rightly any thing that could be called a church, or that could satisfy me about its form.
10130-8{_}4725{_}Sometimes I thought it must be like our house, and sometimes I fancied it must be more like the house of our neighbour, Mr. Sutton, which was bigger and handsomer than ours.
10130-8{_}4726{_}Sometimes I thought it was a great hollow cave, such as I have heard my father say the first inhabitants of the earth dwelt in.
10130-8{_}4727{_}Then I thought it was like a waggon, or a cart, and that it must be something moveable.
10130-8{_}4728{_}The shape of it ran in my mind strangely, and one day I ventured to ask my mother, what was that foolish thing that she was always longing to go to, and which she called a church.
10130-8{_}4729{_}Was it any thing to eat or drink, or was it only like a great huge play-thing, to be seen and stared at?--I was not quite five years of age when I made this inquiry.
10130-8{_}4730{_}This question, so oddly put, made my mother smile; but in a little time she put on a more grave look, and informed me, that a church was nothing that I had supposed it, but it was a great building, far greater than any house which I had seen, where men, and women, and children, came together, twice a day, on Sundays, to hear the Bible read, and make good resolutions for the week to come.
10130-8{_}4731{_}She told me, that the fine music which we sometimes heard in the air, came from the bells of St. Mary's church, and that we never heard it but when the wind was in a particular point.
10130-8{_}4732{_}This raised my wonder more than all the rest; for I had somehow conceived that the noise which I heard, was occasioned by birds up in the air, or that it was made by the angels, whom (so ignorant I was till that time) I had always considered to be a sort of birds: for before this time I was totally ignorant of any thing like religion, it being a principle of my father, that young heads should not be told too many things at once, for fear they should get confused ideas, and no clear notions of any thing.
10130-8{_}4733{_}We had always indeed so far observed Sundays, that no work was done upon that day, and upon that day I wore my best muslin frock, and was not allowed to sing, or to be noisy; but I never understood why that day should differ from any other.
10130-8{_}4734{_}We had no public meetings:--indeed the few straggling houses which were near us, would have furnished but a slender congregation; and the loneliness of the place we lived in, instead of making us more sociable, and drawing us closer together, as my mother used to say it ought to have done, seemed to have the effect of making us more distant and averse to society than other people.
10130-8{_}4735{_}One or two good neighbours indeed we had, but not in numbers to give me an idea of church attendance.
10130-8{_}4736{_}But now my mother thought it high time to give me some clearer instruction in the main points of religion, and my father came readily into her plan.
10130-8{_}4737{_}I was now permitted to sit up half an hour later on a Sunday evening, that I might hear a portion of Scripture read, which had always been their custom, though by reason of my tender age, and my father's opinion on the impropriety of children being taught too young, I had never till now been an auditor.
10130-8{_}4738{_}I was taught my prayers, and those things which you, ladies, I doubt not, had the benefit of being instructed in at a much earlier age.
10130-8{_}4739{_}The clearer my notions on these points became, they only made me more passionately long for the privilege of joining in that social service, from which it seemed that we alone, of all the inhabitants of the land, were debarred; and when the wind was in that point which favoured the sound of the distant bells of St. Mary's to be heard over the great moor which skirted our house, I have stood out in the air to catch the sounds which I almost devoured; and the tears have come in my eyes, when sometimes they seemed to speak to me almost in articulate sounds, to _come to church_, and because of the great moor which was between me and them I could not come; and the too tender apprehensions of these things have filled me with a religious melancholy.
10130-8{_}4740{_}With thoughts like these I entered into my seventh year.
10130-8{_}4741{_}And now the time was come, when the great moor was no longer to separate me from the object of my wishes and of my curiosity.
10130-8{_}4742{_}My father having some money left him by the will of a deceased relation, we ventured to set up a sort of a carriage--no very superb one, I assure you, ladies; but in that part of the world it was looked upon with some envy by our poorer neighbours.
10130-8{_}4743{_}The first party of pleasure which my father proposed to take in it, was to the village where I had so often wished to go, and my mother and I were to accompany him; for it was very fit, my father observed, that little Susan should go to church, and learn how to behave herself, for we might some time or other have occasion to live in London, and not always be confined to that out of the way spot.
10130-8{_}4744{_}It was on a Sunday morning that we set out, my little heart beating with almost breathless expectation.
10130-8{_}4745{_}The day was fine, and the roads as good as they ever are in those parts.
10130-8{_}4746{_}I was so happy and so proud.
10130-8{_}4747{_}I was lost in dreams of what I was going to see.
10130-8{_}4748{_}At length the tall steeple of St. Mary's church came in view.
10130-8{_}4749{_}It was pointed out to me by my father, as the place from which that music had come which I have heard over the moor, and had fancied to be angels singing.
10130-8{_}4750{_}I was wound up to the highest pitch of delight at having visibly presented to me the spot from which had proceeded that unknown friendly music; and when it began to peal, just as we approached the village, it seemed to speak.
10130-8{_}4751{_}_Susan is come_, as plainly as it used to invite me _to come_, when I heard it over the moor.
10130-8{_}4752{_}I pass over our alighting at the house of a relation, and all that passed till I went with my father and mother to church.
10130-8{_}4753{_}St. Mary's church is a great church for such a small village as it stands in.
10130-8{_}4754{_}My father said it was a cathedral, and that it had once belonged to a monastery, but the monks were all gone.
10130-8{_}4755{_}Over the door there was stone work, representing saints and bishops, and here and there, along the sides of the church, there were figures of men's heads, made in a strange grotesque way: I have since seen the same sort of figures in the round tower of the Temple church in London.
10130-8{_}4756{_}My father said they were very improper ornaments for such a place, and so I now think them; but it seems the people who built these great churches in old times, gave themselves more liberties than they do now; and I remember that when I first saw them, and before my father had made this observation, though they were so ugly and out of shape, and some of them seemed to be grinning and distorting their features with pain or with laughter, yet being placed upon a church, to which I had come with such serious thoughts, I could not help thinking they had some serious meaning; and I looked at them with wonder, but without any temptation to laugh.
10130-8{_}4757{_}I somehow fancied they were the representation of wicked people set up as a warning.
10130-8{_}4758{_}When we got into the church, the service was not begun, and my father kindly took me round, to shew me the monuments and every thing else remarkable.
10130-8{_}4759{_}I remember seeing one of a venerable figure, which my father said had been a judge.
10130-8{_}4760{_}The figure was kneeling, as if it was alive, before a sort of desk, with a book, I suppose the Bible, lying on it.
10130-8{_}4761{_}I somehow fancied the figure had a sort of life in it, it seemed so natural, or that the dead judge that it was done for, said his prayers at it still.
10130-8{_}4762{_}This was a silly notion, but I was very young, and had passed my little life in a remote place, where I had never seen any thing nor knew any thing; and the awe which I felt at first being in a church, took from me all power but that of wondering.
10130-8{_}4763{_}I did not reason about any thing, I was too young.
10130-8{_}4764{_}Now I understand why monuments are put up for the dead, and why the figures which are upon them, are described as doing the actions which they did in their life-times, and that they are a sort of pictures set up for our instruction.
10130-8{_}4765{_}But all was new and surprising to me on that day; the long windows with little panes, the pillars, the pews made of oak, the little hassocks for the people to kneel on, the form of the pulpit with the sounding-board over it, gracefully carved in flower work.
10130-8{_}4766{_}To you, who have lived all your lives in populous places, and have been taken to church from the earliest time you can remember, my admiration of these things must appear strangely ignorant.
10130-8{_}4767{_}But I was a lonely young creature, that had been brought up in remote places, where there was neither church nor churchgoing inhabitants.
10130-8{_}4768{_}I have since lived in great towns, and seen the ways of churches and of worship, and I am old enough now to distinguish between what is essential in religion, and what is merely formal or ornamental.
10130-8{_}4769{_}When my father had done pointing out to me the things most worthy of notice about the church, the service was almost ready to begin; the parishioners had most of them entered, and taken their seats; and we were shewn into a pew where my mother was already seated.
10130-8{_}4770{_}Soon after the clergyman entered, and the organ began to play what is called the voluntary.
10130-8{_}4771{_}I had never seen so many people assembled before.
10130-8{_}4772{_}At first I thought that all eyes were upon me, and that because I was a stranger.
10130-8{_}4773{_}I was terribly ashamed and confused at first; but my mother helped me to find out the places in the Prayer-book, and being busy about that, took off some of my painful apprehensions.
10130-8{_}4774{_}I was no stranger to the order of the service, having often read in a Prayer-book at home; but my thoughts being confused, it puzzled me a little to find out the responses and other things, which I thought I knew so well; but I went through it tolerably well.
10130-8{_}4775{_}One thing which has often troubled me since, is, that I am afraid I was too full of myself, and of thinking how happy I was, and what a privilege it was for one that was so young, to join in the service with so many grown people, so that I did not attend enough to the instruction which I might have received.
10130-8{_}4776{_}I remember, I foolishly applied every thing that was said to myself, so as it could mean nobody but myself, I was so full of my own thoughts.
10130-8{_}4777{_}All that assembly of people, seemed to me as if they were come together only to shew me the way of a church.
10130-8{_}4778{_}Not but I received some very affecting impressions from some things which I heard that day; but the standing up and the sitting down of the people; the organ; the singing;--the way of all these things took up more of my attention than was proper; or I thought it did.
10130-8{_}4779{_}I believe I behaved better and was more serious when I went a second time, and a third time; for now we went as a regular thing every Sunday, and continued to do so, till, by a still further change for the better in my father's circumstances, we removed to London.
10130-8{_}4780{_}Oh!
10130-8{_}4781{_}it was a happy day for me my first going to St. Mary's church: before that day I used to feel like a little outcast in the wilderness, like one that did not belong to the world of Christian people.
10130-8{_}4782{_}I have never felt like a little outcast since.
10130-8{_}4783{_}But I never can hear the sweet noise of bells, that I don't think of the angels singing, and what poor but pretty thoughts I had of angels in my uninstructed solitude.
10130-8{_}4784{_}X  ARABELLA HARDY  (_By Charles Lamb_)   I was born in the East Indies.
10130-8{_}4785{_}I lost my father and mother young.
10130-8{_}4786{_}At the age of five my relations thought it proper that I should be sent to England for my education.
10130-8{_}4787{_}I was to be entrusted to the care of a young woman who had a character for great humanity and discretion; but just as I had taken leave of my friends, and we were about to take our passage, the young woman was taken suddenly ill, and could not go on board.
10130-8{_}4788{_}In this unpleasant emergency, no one knew how to act.
10130-8{_}4789{_}The ship was at the very point of sailing, and it was the last ship which was to sail that season.
10130-8{_}4790{_}At last the captain, who was known to my friends, prevailed upon my relation who had come with us to see us embark, to leave the young woman on shore, and to let me embark separately.
10130-8{_}4791{_}There was no possibility of getting any other female attendant for me, in the short time allotted for our preparation; and the opportunity of going by that ship was thought too valuable to be lost.
10130-8{_}4792{_}No other ladies happened to be going; so I was consigned to the care of the captain and his crew,--rough and unaccustomed attendants for a young creature, delicately brought up as I had been; but indeed they did their best to make me not feel the difference.
10130-8{_}4793{_}The unpolished sailors were my nursery-maids and my waiting-women.
10130-8{_}4794{_}Every thing was done by the captain and the men, to accommodate me, and make me easy.
10130-8{_}4795{_}I had a little room made out of the cabin, which was to be considered as my room, and nobody might enter into it.
10130-8{_}4796{_}The first mate had a great character for bravery, and all sailor-like accomplishments; but with all this he had a gentleness of manners, and a pale feminine cast of face, from ill health and a weakly constitution, which subjected him to some little ridicule from the officers, and caused him to be named Betsy.
10130-8{_}4797{_}He did not much like the appellation, but he submitted to it the better, as he knew that those who gave him a woman's name, well knew that he had a man's heart, and that in the face of danger he would go as far as any man.
10130-8{_}4798{_}To this young man, whose real name was Charles Atkinson, by a lucky thought of the captain, the care of me was especially entrusted.
10130-8{_}4799{_}Betsy was proud of his charge, and, to do him justice, acquitted himself with great diligence and adroitness through the whole of the voyage.
10130-8{_}4800{_}From the beginning I had somehow looked upon Betsy as a woman, hearing him so spoken of, and this reconciled me in some measure to the want of a maid, which I had been used to.
10130-8{_}4801{_}But I was a manageable girl at all times, and gave nobody much trouble.
10130-8{_}4802{_}I have not knowledge enough to give an account of my voyage, or to remember the names of the seas we passed through, or the lands which we touched upon, in our course.
10130-8{_}4803{_}The chief thing I can remember, for I do not remember the events of the voyage in any order, was Atkinson taking me up on deck, to see the great whales playing about in the sea.
10130-8{_}4804{_}There was one great whale came bounding up out of the sea, and then he would dive into it again, and then would come up at a distance where nobody expected him, and another whale was following after him.
10130-8{_}4805{_}Atkinson said they were at play, and that that lesser whale loved that bigger whale, and kept it company all through the wide seas: but I thought it strange play, and a frightful kind of love; for I every minute expected they would come up to our ship and toss it.
10130-8{_}4806{_}But Atkinson said a whale was a gentle creature, and it was a sort of sea-elephant, and that the most powerful creatures in nature are always the least hurtful.
10130-8{_}4807{_}And he told me how men went out to take these whales, and stuck long, pointed darts into them; and how the sea was discoloured with the blood of these poor whales for many miles distance: and I admired at the courage of the men, but I was sorry for the inoffensive whale.
10130-8{_}4808{_}Many other pretty sights he used to shew me, when he was not on watch, or doing some duty for the ship.
10130-8{_}4809{_}No one was more attentive to his duty than he; but at such times as he had leisure, he would shew me all pretty sea sights:--the dolphins and porpoises that came before a storm, and all the colours which the sea changed to; how sometimes it was a deep blue, and then a deep green, and sometimes it would seem all on fire: all these various appearances he would shew me, and attempt to explain the reason of them to me, as well as my young capacity would admit of.
10130-8{_}4810{_}There was a lion and a tiger on board, going to England as a present to the king, and it was a great diversion to Atkinson and me, after I had got rid of my first terrors, to see the ways of these beasts in their dens, and how venturous the sailors were in putting their hands through the grates, and patting their rough coats.
10130-8{_}4811{_}Some of the men had monkeys, which ran loose about, and the sport was for the men to lose them, and find them again.
10130-8{_}4812{_}The monkeys would run up the shrouds, and pass from rope to rope, with ten times greater alacrity than the most experienced sailor could follow them; and sometimes they would hide themselves in the most unthought-of places, and when they were found, they would grin, and make mouths as if they had sense.
10130-8{_}4813{_}Atkinson described to me the ways of these little animals in their native woods, for he had seen them.
10130-8{_}4814{_}Oh, how many ways he thought of to amuse me in that long voyage!
10130-8{_}4815{_}Sometimes he would describe to me the odd shapes and varieties of fishes that were in the sea, and tell me tales of the sea-monsters that lay hid at the bottom, and were seldom seen by men; and what a glorious sight it would be, if our eyes could be sharpened to behold all the inhabitants of the sea at once, swimming in the great deeps, as plain as we see the gold and silver fish in a bowl of glass.
10130-8{_}4816{_}With such notions he enlarged my infant capacity to take in many things.
10130-8{_}4817{_}When in foul weather I have been terrified at the motion of the vessel, as it rocked backwards and forwards, he would still my fears, and tell me that I used to be rocked so once in a cradle, and that the sea was God's bed, and the ship our cradle, and we were as safe in that greater motion, as when we felt that lesser one in our little wooden sleeping-places.
10130-8{_}4818{_}When the wind was up, and sang through the sails, and disturbed me with its violent clamours, he would call it music, and bid me hark to the sea-organ, and with that name he quieted my tender apprehensions.
10130-8{_}4819{_}When I have looked around with a mournful face at seeing all _men_ about me, he would enter into my thoughts, and tell me pretty stories of his mother and his sisters, and a female cousin that he loved better than his sisters, whom he called Jenny, and say that when we got to England I should go and see them, and how fond Jenny would be of his little daughter, as he called me; and with these images of women and females which he raised in my fancy, he quieted me for a time.
10130-8{_}4820{_}One time, and never but once, he told me that Jenny had promised to be his wife if ever he came to England, but that he had his doubts whether he should live to get home, for he was very sickly.
10130-8{_}4821{_}This made me cry bitterly.
10130-8{_}4822{_}That I dwell so long upon the attentions of this Atkinson, is only because his death, which happened just before we got to England, affected me so much, that he alone of all the ship's crew has engrossed my mind ever since; though indeed the captain and all were singularly kind to me, and strove to make up for my uneasy and unnatural situation.
10130-8{_}4823{_}The boatswain would pipe for my diversion, and the sailor-boy would climb the dangerous mast for my sport.
10130-8{_}4824{_}The rough foremastman would never willingly appear before me, till he had combed his long black hair smooth and sleek, not to terrify me.
10130-8{_}4825{_}The officers got up a sort of play for my amusement, and Atkinson, or, as they called him, Betsy, acted the heroine of the piece.
10130-8{_}4826{_}All ways that could be contrived, were thought upon, to reconcile me to my lot.
10130-8{_}4827{_}I was the universal favourite;--I do not know how deservedly; but I suppose it was because I was alone, and there was no female in the ship besides me.
10130-8{_}4828{_}Had I come over with female relations or attendants, I should have excited no particular curiosity; I should have required no uncommon attentions.
10130-8{_}4829{_}I was one little woman among a crew of men; and I believe the homage which I have read that men universally pay to women, was in this case directed to me, in the absence of all other woman-kind.
10130-8{_}4830{_}I do not know how that might be, but I was a little princess among them, and I was not six years old.
10130-8{_}4831{_}I remember the first draw-back which happened to my comfort, was Atkinson's not appearing during the whole of one day.
10130-8{_}4832{_}The captain tried to reconcile me to it, by saying that Mr. Atkinson was confined to his cabin;--that he was not quite well, but a day or two would restore him.
10130-8{_}4833{_}I begged to be taken in to see him, but this was not granted.
10130-8{_}4834{_}A day, and then another came, and another, and no Atkinson was visible, and I saw apparent solicitude in the faces of all the officers, who nevertheless strove to put on their best countenances before me, and to be more than usually kind to me.
10130-8{_}4835{_}At length, by the desire of Atkinson himself, as I have since learned, I was permitted to go into his cabin and see him.
10130-8{_}4836{_}He was sitting up, apparently in a state of great exhaustion, but his face lighted up when he saw me, and he kissed me, and told me that he was going a great voyage, far longer than that which we had passed together, and he should never come back; and though I was so young, I understood well enough that he meant this of his death, and I cried sadly; but he comforted me and told me, that I must be his little executrix, and perform his last will, and bear his last words to his mother and his sister, and to his cousin Jenny, whom I should see in a short time; and he gave me his blessing, as a father would bless his child, and he sent a last kiss by me to all his female relations, and he made me promise that I would go and see them when I got to England, and soon after this he died; but I was in another part of the ship when he died, and I was not told it till we got to shore, which was a few days after; but they kept telling me that he was better and better, and that I should soon see him, but that it disturbed him to talk with any one.
10130-8{_}4837{_}Oh, what a grief it was, when I learned that I had lost my old ship-mate, that had made an irksome situation so bearable by his kind assiduities; and to think that he was gone, and I could never repay him for his kindness!
10130-8{_}4838{_}When I had been a year and a half in England, the captain, who had made another voyage to India and back, thinking that time had alleviated a little the sorrow of Atkinson's relations, prevailed upon my friends who had the care of me in England, to let him introduce me to Atkinson's mother and sister.
10130-8{_}4839{_}Jenny was no more; she had died in the interval, and I never saw her.
10130-8{_}4840{_}Grief for his death had brought on a consumption, of which she lingered about a twelvemonth, and then expired.
10130-8{_}4841{_}But in the mother and the sisters of this excellent young man, I have found the most valuable friends which I possess on this side the great ocean.
10130-8{_}4842{_}They received me from the captain as the little _protégée_ of Atkinson, and from them I have learned passages of his former life, and this in particular, that the illness of which he died was brought on by a wound of which he never quite recovered, which he got in the desperate attempt, when he was quite a boy, to defend his captain against a superior force of the enemy which had boarded him, and which, by his premature valour inspiriting the men, they finally succeeded in repulsing.
10130-8{_}4843{_}This was that Atkinson, who, from his pale and feminine appearance, was called Betsy.
10130-8{_}4844{_}This was he whose womanly care of me got him the name of a woman, who, with more than female attention, condescended to play the hand-maid to a little unaccompanied orphan, that fortune had cast upon the care of a rough sea captain, and his rougher crew.
10130-8{_}4845{_}THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS   [Illustration]    Showing how notably   the Queen made her tarts,   and how scurvily   the Knave stole them away,   with other particulars belonging thereunto  Printed for Thomas Hodgkins Hanway Street November 18 1805.
10130-8{_}4846{_}[Illustration: _The Queen of Hearts_]    High on a Throne of state is seen   She whom all Hearts own for their Queen.
10130-8{_}4847{_}Three Pages are in waiting by;   He with the umbrella is her Spy,   To spy out rogueries in the dark,   And smell a rat as you shall mark.
10130-8{_}4848{_}[Illustration: _She made some Tarts_]    The Queen here by the King's commands,   Who does not like Cook's dirty hands,   Makes the court-pastry all herself.
10130-8{_}4849{_}Pambo the knave, that roguish elf,   Watches each sugary sweet ingredient,   And slily thinks of an expedient.
10130-8{_}4850{_}[Illustration: _All on a Summer's day_]    Now first of May does summer bring,   How bright and fine is every thing!
10130-8{_}4851{_}After their dam the chickens run,   The green leaves glitter in the sun,   While youths and maids in merry dance   Round rustic maypoles do advance.
10130-8{_}4852{_}[Illustration: _The Knave of Hearts_]    When Kings and Queens ariding go,   Great Lords ride with them for a show   With grooms & courtiers, a great store;   Some ride behind, & some before.
10130-8{_}4853{_}Pambo the first of these does pass,   And for more state rides on an Ass.
10130-8{_}4854{_}[Illustration: _He stole those Tarts_]    Thieves!
10130-8{_}4855{_}Thieves!
10130-8{_}4856{_}holla, you knavish Jack,   Cannot the good Queen turn her back,   But you must be so nimble hasty   To come and steal away her pastry   You think you're safe, there's one fees all,   And understands, though he's but small  [Illustration: _And took them quite away_]    How like a thievish Jack he looks!
10130-8{_}4857{_}I wish for my part all the cooks   Would come and baste him with a ladle   As long as ever they were able,   To keep his fingers ends from itching   After sweet things in the Queen's kitchen.
10130-8{_}4858{_}[Illustration: _The King of Hearts_]    Behold the King of Hearts how gruff   The monarch stands, how square, how bluff!
10130-8{_}4859{_}When our eighth Harry rul'd this land,   Just like this King did Harry stand;   And just so amorous, sweet, and willing,   As this Queen stands, stood Anna Bullen.
10130-8{_}4860{_}[Illustration: _Call'd for those Tarts_]    The meat removed and dinner done,   The knives are wip'd and cheese put on.
10130-8{_}4861{_}The King aloud for Tarts does bawl,   Tarts, tarts, resound through all the Hall.
10130-8{_}4862{_}Pambo with tears denies the Fact,   But Mungo saw him in the act.
10130-8{_}4863{_}[Illustration: _And beat the Knave full sore_]    Behold the due reward of sin,   See what a plight rogue Pambo's in.
10130-8{_}4864{_}The King lays on his blows so stout,   The Tarts for fear come tumbling out   O King!
10130-8{_}4865{_}be merciful as just,   You'll beat poor Pambo into dust  [Illustration: _The Knave of Hearts_]    How like he looks to a dog that begs   In abject sort upon two legs!
10130-8{_}4866{_}Good Mr. Knave, give me my due,   I like a tart as well as you,   But I would starve on good roast Beef,   Ere I would look so like a thief.
10130-8{_}4867{_}[Illustration: _Brought back those Tarts_]    The Knave brings back the tarts he stole.
10130-8{_}4868{_}The Queen swears, that is not the whole.
10130-8{_}4869{_}What should poor Pambo do?
10130-8{_}4870{_}hard prest   Owns he has eaten up the rest.
10130-8{_}4871{_}The King takes back, as lawful debt,   Not all, but all that he can get.
10130-8{_}4872{_}[Illustration: _And vow'd he'd steal no more_]    Lo!
10130-8{_}4873{_}Pambo prostrate on the floor   Vows he will be a thief no more.
10130-8{_}4874{_}O King your heart no longer harden,   You've got the tarts, give him his pardon.
10130-8{_}4875{_}The best time to forgive a sinner   Is always after a good dinner.
10130-8{_}4876{_}[Illustration]    "How say you Sir?
10130-8{_}4877{_}tis all a joke--   Great Kings love tarts like other folk!"
10130-8{_}4878{_}If for a truth you'll not receive it,   Pray, view the picture, and believe it.
10130-8{_}4879{_}Sly Pambo too has got a share,   And eats it snug behind the chair.

10130-8{_}4882{_}--hush, gipsey!
10130-8{_}4883{_}Great Kings & Queens indeed get tipsey!

10130-8{_}4885{_}POETRY FOR CHILDREN  (_1808-1809.
10130-8{_}4886{_}Text of 1809_)   ENVY    This rose-tree is not made to bear   The violet blue, nor lily fair,     Nor the sweet mignionet:   And if this tree were discontent,   Or wish'd to change its natural bent,     It all in vain would fret.
10130-8{_}4887{_}And should it fret, you would suppose   It ne'er had seen its own red rose,     Nor after gentle shower   Had ever smell'd it rose's scent,   Or it could ne'er be discontent     With its own pretty flower.
10130-8{_}4888{_}Like such a blind and senseless tree   As I've imagin'd this to be,     All envious persons are:   With care and culture all may find   Some pretty flower in their own mind,     Some talent that is rare.
10130-8{_}4889{_}THE REAPER'S CHILD    If you go to the field where the Reapers now bind     The sheaves of ripe corn, there a fine little lass,   Only three months of age, by the hedge-row you'll find,     Left alone by its mother upon the low grass.
10130-8{_}4890{_}While the mother is reaping, the infant is sleeping;     Not the basket that holds the provision is less   By the hard-working Reaper, than this little sleeper,     Regarded, till hunger does on the babe press.
10130-8{_}4891{_}Then it opens its eyes, and it utters loud cries,     Which its hard-working mother afar off will hear;   She comes at its calling, she quiets its squalling,     And feeds it, and leaves it again without fear.
10130-8{_}4892{_}When you were as young as this field-nursed daughter,     You were fed in the house, and brought up on the knee;   So tenderly watched, thy fond mother thought her     Whole time well bestow'd in nursing of thee.
10130-8{_}4893{_}THE RIDE    Lately an Equipage I overtook,   And help'd to lift it o'er a narrow brook.
10130-8{_}4894{_}No horse it had except one boy, who drew   His sister out in it the fields to view.
10130-8{_}4895{_}O happy town-bred girl, in fine chaise going   For the first time to see the green grass growing.
10130-8{_}4896{_}This was the end and purport of the ride   I learn'd, as walking slowly by their side   I heard their conversation.
10130-8{_}4897{_}Often she--   "Brother, is this the country that I see?"
10130-8{_}4898{_}The bricks were smoking, and the ground was broke,   There were no signs of verdure when she spoke.
10130-8{_}4899{_}He, as the well-inform'd delight in chiding   The ignorant, these questions still deriding,   To his good judgment modestly she yields;   Till, brick-kilns past, they reach'd the open fields.
10130-8{_}4900{_}Then as with rapt'rous wonder round she gazes   On the green grass, the butter-cups, and daisies,   "This is the country sure enough," she cries;   "Is't not a charming place?"
10130-8{_}4901{_}The boy replies,   "We'll go no further."
10130-8{_}4902{_}"No," says she, "no need;   No finer place than this can be indeed."
10130-8{_}4903{_}I left them gathering flow'rs, the happiest pair   That ever London sent to breathe the fine fresh air,     THE BUTTERFLY  SISTER  Do, my dearest brother John, Let that Butterfly alone.
10130-8{_}4904{_}BROTHER         What harm now do I do?
10130-8{_}4905{_}You're always making such a noise--  SISTER  O fie, John; none but naughty boys        Say such rude words as you.
10130-8{_}4906{_}BROTHER  Because you're always speaking sharp: On the same thing you always harp.
10130-8{_}4907{_}A bird one may not catch, Nor find a nest, nor angle neither, Nor from the peacock pluck a feather,        But you are on the watch To moralise and lecture still.
10130-8{_}4908{_}SISTER  And ever lecture, John, I will,        When such sad things I hear.
10130-8{_}4909{_}But talk not now of what is past; The moments fly away too fast, Though endlessly they seem to last        To that poor soul in fear.
10130-8{_}4910{_}BROTHER  Well, soon (I say) I'll let it loose; But, sister, you talk like a goose,        There's no soul in a fly.
10130-8{_}4911{_}SISTER  It has a form and fibres fine, Were temper'd by the hand divine        Who dwells beyond the sky.
10130-8{_}4912{_}Look, brother, you have hurt its wing-- And plainly by its fluttering        You see it's in distress, Gay painted Coxcomb, spangled Beau, A Butterfly is call'd you know,        That's always in full dress: The finest gentleman of all Insects he is--he gave a Ball,        You know the Poet wrote.
10130-8{_}4913{_}Let's fancy this the very same, And then you'll own you've been to blame        To spoil his silken coat.
10130-8{_}4914{_}BROTHER  Your dancing, spangled, powder'd Beau, Look, through the air I've let him go:        And now we're friends again.
10130-8{_}4915{_}As sure as he is in the air, From this time, Ann, I will take care,        And try to be humane.
10130-8{_}4916{_}THE PEACH    Mamma gave us a single Peach,     She shar'd it among seven;   Now you may think that unto each     But a small piece was given.
10130-8{_}4917{_}Yet though each share was very small,     We own'd when it was eaten,   Being so little for us all     Did its fine flavour heighten.
10130-8{_}4918{_}The tear was in our parent's eye,     It seem'd quite out of season;   When we ask'd wherefore she did cry,     She thus explain'd the reason.
10130-8{_}4919{_}"The cause, my children, I may say,     Was joy, and not dejection;   The Peach, which made you all so gay,     Gave rise to this reflection:    "It's many a mother's lot to share,     Seven hungry children viewing,   A morsel of the coarsest fare,     As I this Peach was doing."
10130-8{_}4920{_}CHUSING A NAME    I have got a new-born sister;   I was nigh the first that kiss'd her.
10130-8{_}4921{_}When the nursing woman brought her   To Papa, his infant daughter,   How Papa's dear eyes did glisten!--   She will shortly be to christen:   And Papa has made the offer,   I shall have the naming of her.
10130-8{_}4922{_}Now I wonder what would please her,   Charlotte, Julia, or Louisa.
10130-8{_}4923{_}Ann and Mary, they're too common;   Joan's too formal for a woman;   Jane's a prettier name beside;   But we had a Jane that died.
10130-8{_}4924{_}They would say, if 'twas Rebecca,   That she was a little Quaker,   Edith's pretty, but that looks   Better in old English books;   Ellen's left off long ago;   Blanche is out of fashion now.
10130-8{_}4925{_}None that I have nam'd as yet   Are so good as Margaret.
10130-8{_}4926{_}Emily is neat and fine.
10130-8{_}4927{_}What do you think of Caroline?
10130-8{_}4928{_}How I'm puzzled and perplext   What to chuse or think of next!
10130-8{_}4929{_}I am in a little fever.
10130-8{_}4930{_}Lest the name that I shall give her   Should disgrace her or defame her   I will leave Papa to name her.
10130-8{_}4931{_}CRUMBS TO THE BIRDS    A bird appears a thoughtless thing,   He's ever living on the wing,   And keeps up such a carolling,   That little else to do but sing                     A man would guess had he.
10130-8{_}4932{_}No doubt he has his little cares,   And very hard he often fares,   The which so patiently he bears,   That, list'ning to those cheerful airs,                       Who knows but he may be    In want of his next meal of seeds?
10130-8{_}4933{_}I think for _that_ his sweet song pleads.
10130-8{_}4934{_}If so, his pretty art succeeds.
10130-8{_}4935{_}I'll scatter there among the weeds                     All the small crumbs I see.
10130-8{_}4936{_}THE ROOK AND THE SPARROWS    A little boy with crumbs of bread   Many a hungry sparrow fed.
10130-8{_}4937{_}It was a child of little sense,   Who this kind bounty did dispense;   For suddenly it was withdrawn,   And all the birds were left forlorn,   In a hard time of frost and snow,   Not knowing where for food to go.
10130-8{_}4938{_}He would no longer give them bread,   Because he had observ'd (he said)   That sometimes to the window came   A great blackbird, a rook by name,   And took away a small bird's share.
10130-8{_}4939{_}So foolish Henry did not care   What became of the great rook,   That from the little sparrows took,   Now and then, as 'twere by stealth,   A part of their abundant wealth;   Nor ever more would feed his sparrows.
10130-8{_}4940{_}_Thus ignorance a kind heart narrows._   I wish I had been there; I would   Have told the child, rooks live by food   In the same way that sparrows do.
10130-8{_}4941{_}I also would have told him too,   Birds act by instinct, and ne'er can   Attain the rectitude of man.
10130-8{_}4942{_}Nay that even, when distress   Does on poor human nature press,   We need not be too strict in seeing   The failings of a fellow being.
10130-8{_}4943{_}DISCONTENT AND QUARRELLING  JANE  Miss Lydia every day is drest Better than I am in my best        White cambric-muslin frock.
10130-8{_}4944{_}I wish I had one made of clear Work'd lawn, or leno very dear.--        And then my heart is broke  Almost to think how cheap my doll Was bought, when hers cost--yes, cost full        A pound, it did, my brother; Nor has she had it weeks quite five, Yet, 'tis as true as I'm alive,        She's soon to have another.
10130-8{_}4945{_}ROBERT  O mother, hear my sister Jane, How foolishly she does complain,        And teaze herself for nought.
10130-8{_}4946{_}But 'tis the way of all her sex, Thus foolishly themselves to vex.
10130-8{_}4947{_}Envy's a female fault.
10130-8{_}4948{_}JANE  O brother Robert, say not so; It is not very long ago,        Ah!
10130-8{_}4949{_}brother, you've forgot, When speaking of a boy you knew, Remember how you said that you        Envied his happy lot.
10130-8{_}4950{_}ROBERT  Let's see, what were the words I spoke?
10130-8{_}4951{_}Why, may be I was half in joke--         May be I just might say-- Besides that was not half so bad; For Jane, I only said he had        More time than I to play.
10130-8{_}4952{_}JANE  O _may be, may be_, very well: And may be, brother, I don't tell        Tales to mamma like you.
10130-8{_}4953{_}MOTHER  O cease your wrangling, cease, my dears; You would not wake a mother's fears        Thus, if you better knew.
10130-8{_}4954{_}REPENTANCE AND RECONCILIATION  JANE  Mamma is displeased and looks very grave,   And I own, brother, I was to blame Just now when I told her I wanted to have,   Like Miss Lydia, a very fine _name_.
10130-8{_}4955{_}'Twas foolish, for, Robert, Jane sounds very well,   When mamma says, "I love my good Jane."
10130-8{_}4956{_}I've been lately so naughty, I hardly can tell   If she ever will say so again.
10130-8{_}4957{_}ROBERT  We are each of us foolish, and each of us young,   And often in fault and to blame.
10130-8{_}4958{_}Jane, yesterday I was too free with my tongue,   I acknowledge it now to my shame.
10130-8{_}4959{_}For a speech in my good mother's hearing I made,   Which reflected upon her whole sex; And now like you, Jenny, I am much afraid   That this might my dear mother vex.
10130-8{_}4960{_}JANE  But yet, brother Robert, 'twas not quite so bad   As that naughty reflection of mine, When I grumbled because Liddy Bellenger had   Dolls and dresses expensive and fine.
10130-8{_}4961{_}For then 'twas of her, her own self, I complain'd;   Since mamma does provide all I have.
10130-8{_}4962{_}MOTHER  Your repentance, my children, I see is unfeign'd,   You are now my good Robert, and now my good Jane; And if you never will be naughty again,   Your fond mother will never look grave.
10130-8{_}4963{_}NEATNESS IN APPAREL    In your garb and outward clothing     A reserved plainness use;   By their neatness more distinguish'd     Than the brightness of their hues.
10130-8{_}4964{_}All the colours in the rainbow     Serve to spread the peacock's train;   Half the lustre of his feathers     Would turn twenty coxcombs vain.
10130-8{_}4965{_}Yet the swan that swims in rivers,     Pleases the judicious sight;   Who, of brighter colours heedless,     Trusts alone to simple white.
10130-8{_}4966{_}Yet all other hues, compared     With his whiteness, show amiss;   And the peacock's coat of colours     Like a fool's coat looks by his.
10130-8{_}4967{_}THE NEW-BORN INFANT    Whether beneath sweet beds of roses,   As foolish little Ann supposes,   The spirit of a babe reposes       Before it to the body come;   Or, as philosophy more wise   Thinks, it descendeth from the skies,--       We know the babe's now in the room.
10130-8{_}4968{_}And that is all which is quite clear,   Ev'n to philosophy, my dear.
10130-8{_}4969{_}The God that made us can alone   Reveal from whence a spirit's brought   Into young life, to light, and thought;       And this the wisest man must own.
10130-8{_}4970{_}We'll now talk of the babe's surprise,   When first he opens his new eyes,       And first receives delicious food.
10130-8{_}4971{_}Before the age of six or seven,   To mortal children is not given       Much reason; or I think he would    (And very naturally) wonder   What happy star he was born under,       That he should be the only care   Of the dear sweet-food-giving lady,   Who fondly calls him her own baby,       Her darling hope, her infant heir.
10130-8{_}4972{_}MOTES IN THE SUN-BEAMS    The motes up and down in the sun     Ever restlessly moving we see;   Whereas the great mountains stand still,     Unless terrible earthquakes there be.
10130-8{_}4973{_}If these atoms that move up and down     Were as useful as restless they are,   Than a mountain I rather would be     A mote in the sun-beam so fair.
10130-8{_}4974{_}THE BOY AND SNAKE    Henry was every morning fed   With a full mess of milk and bread.
10130-8{_}4975{_}One day the boy his breakfast took,   And eat it by a purling brook   Which through his mother's orchard ran.
10130-8{_}4976{_}From that time ever when he can   Escape his mother's eye, he there   Takes his food in th' open air.
10130-8{_}4977{_}Finding the child delight to eat   Abroad, and make the grass his seat,   His mother lets him have his way.
10130-8{_}4978{_}With free leave Henry every day   Thither repairs, until she heard   Him talking of a fine _grey bird_.
10130-8{_}4979{_}This pretty bird, he said, indeed,   Came every day with him to feed,   And it lov'd him, and lov'd his milk,   And it was smooth and soft like silk.
10130-8{_}4980{_}His mother thought she'd go and see   What sort of bird this same might be.
10130-8{_}4981{_}So the next morn she follows Harry,   And carefully she sees him carry   Through the long grass his heap'd-up mess.
10130-8{_}4982{_}What was her terror and distress,   When she saw the infant take   His bread and milk close to a snake!
10130-8{_}4983{_}Upon the grass he spreads his feast,   And sits down by his frightful guest,   Who had waited for the treat;   And now they both begin to eat.
10130-8{_}4984{_}Fond mother!
10130-8{_}4985{_}shriek not, O beware   The least small noise, O have a care--   The least small noise that may be made,   The wily snake will be afraid--   If he hear the lightest sound,   He will inflict th' envenom'd wound.
10130-8{_}4986{_}She speaks not, moves not, scarce does breathe,   As she stands the trees beneath;   No sound she utters; and she soon   Sees the child lift up its spoon,   And tap the snake upon the head,   Fearless of harm; and then he said,   As speaking to familiar mate,   "Keep on your own side, do, Grey Pate:"   The snake then to the other side,   As one rebuked, seems to glide;   And now again advancing nigh,   Again she hears the infant cry,   Tapping the snake, "Keep further, do;   Mind, Grey Pate, what I say to you."
10130-8{_}4987{_}The danger's o'er--she sees the boy   (O what a change from fear to joy!)
10130-8{_}4988{_}Rise and bid the snake "good-bye;"   Says he, "Our breakfast's done, and I   Will come again to-morrow day:"   Then, lightly tripping, ran away.
10130-8{_}4989{_}THE FIRST TOOTH  SISTER    Through the house what busy joy,   Just because the infant boy   Has a tiny tooth to show.
10130-8{_}4990{_}I have got a double row,   All as white, and all as small;   Yet no one cares for mine at all.
10130-8{_}4991{_}He can say but half a word,   Yet that single sound's preferr'd   To all the words that I can say   In the longest summer day.
10130-8{_}4992{_}He cannot walk, yet if he put   With mimic motion out his foot,   As if he thought, he were advancing,   It's prized more than my best dancing.
10130-8{_}4993{_}BROTHER    Sister, I know, you jesting are,   Yet O!
10130-8{_}4994{_}of jealousy beware.
10130-8{_}4995{_}If the smallest seed should be   In your mind of jealousy,   It will spring, and it will shoot,   Till it bear the baneful fruit.
10130-8{_}4996{_}I remember you, my dear,   Young as is this infant here.
10130-8{_}4997{_}There was not a tooth of those   Your pretty even ivory rows,   But as anxiously was watched,   Till it burst its shell new hatched,   As if it a Phoenix were,   Or some other wonder rare.
10130-8{_}4998{_}So when you began to walk--   So when you began to talk--   As now, the same encomiums past.
10130-8{_}4999{_}'Tis not fitting this should last   Longer than our infant days;   A child is fed with milk and praise.
10130-8{_}5000{_}TO A RIVER IN WHICH A CHILD WAS DROWNED  (_Text of 1818_)    Smiling river, smiling river,     On thy bosom sun-beams play;   Though they're fleeting and retreating,     Thou hast more deceit than they.
10130-8{_}5001{_}In thy channel, in thy channel,     Choak'd with ooze and grav'lly stones,   Deep immersed and unhearsed,     Lies young Edward's corse: his bones    Ever whitening, ever whitening,     As thy waves against them dash;   What thy torrent, in the current,     Swallow'd, now it helps to wash.    As if senseless, as if senseless     Things had feeling in this case;   What so blindly, and unkindly,     It destroy'd, it now does grace.
10130-8{_}5002{_}THE FIRST OF APRIL    "Tell me what is the reason you hang down your head;     From your blushes I plainly discern,   You have done something wrong.
10130-8{_}5003{_}Ere you go up to bed,     I desire that the truth I may learn."
10130-8{_}5004{_}"O mamma, I have long'd to confess all the day     What an ill-natured thing I have done;   I persuaded myself it was only in play,     But such play I in future will shun.
10130-8{_}5005{_}"The least of the ladies that live at the school,     Her whose eyes are so pretty and blue,   Ah!
10130-8{_}5006{_}would you believe it?
10130-8{_}5007{_}an April fool     I have made her, and call'd her so too.
10130-8{_}5008{_}"Yet the words almost choak'd me; and, as I spoke low,     I have hopes that she might them not hear.
10130-8{_}5009{_}I had wrapt up some rubbish in paper, and so,     The instant the school-girls drew near,    "I presented it with a fine bow to the child,     And much her acceptance I press'd;   When she took it, and thank'd me, and gratefully smil'd,     I never felt half so distress'd.
10130-8{_}5010{_}"No doubt she concluded some sweetmeats were there,     For the paper was white and quite clean,   And folded up neatly, as if with great care.
10130-8{_}5011{_}O what a rude boy I have been!
10130-8{_}5012{_}"Ever since I've been thinking how vex'd she will be,     Ever since I've done nothing but grieve.
10130-8{_}5013{_}If a thousand young ladies a walking I see,     I will never another deceive."
10130-8{_}5014{_}CLEANLINESS    Come my little Robert near--   Fie!
10130-8{_}5015{_}what filthy hands are here--   Who that e'er could understand   The rare structure of a hand,   With its branching fingers fine,   Work itself of hands divine,   Strong, yet delicately knit,   For ten thousand uses fit,   Overlaid with so clear skin   You may see the blood within,   And the curious palm, disposed   In such lines, some have supposed   You may read the fortunes there   By the figures that appear--   Who this hand would chuse to cover   With a crust of dirt all over,   Till it look'd in hue and shape   Like the fore-foot of an Ape?
10130-8{_}5016{_}Man or boy that works or plays   In the fields or the highways   May, without offence or hurt,   From the soil contract a dirt,   Which the next clear spring or river   Washes out and out for ever--   But to cherish stains impure,   Soil deliberate to endure,   On the skin to fix a stain   Till it works into the grain,   Argues a degenerate mind,   Sordid, slothful, ill inclin'd,   Wanting in that self-respect   Which does virtue best protect.
10130-8{_}5017{_}All-endearing Cleanliness,   Virtue next to Godliness,   Easiest, cheapest, needful'st duty,   To the body health and beauty,   Who that's human would refuse it,   When a little water does it?
10130-8{_}5018{_}THE LAME BROTHER    My parents sleep both in one grave;     My only friend's a brother.
10130-8{_}5019{_}The dearest things upon the earth     We are to one another.
10130-8{_}5020{_}A fine stout boy I knew him once,     With active form and limb;   Whene'er he leap'd, or jump'd, or ran,     O I was proud of him!
10130-8{_}5021{_}He leap'd too far, he got a hurt,     He now does limping go.--   When I think on his active days,     My heart is full of woe.
10130-8{_}5022{_}He leans on me, when we to school     Do every morning walk;   I cheer him on his weary way,     He loves to hear my talk:    The theme of which is mostly this,     What things he once could do.
10130-8{_}5023{_}He listens pleas'd--then sadly says,     "Sister, I lean on you."
10130-8{_}5024{_}Then I reply, "Indeed you're not     Scarce any weight at all.--   And let us now still younger years     To memory recall.
10130-8{_}5025{_}"Led by your little elder hand,     I learn'd to walk alone;   Careful you us'd to be of me,     My little brother John.
10130-8{_}5026{_}"How often, when my young feet tir'd,     You've carried me a mile!--   And still together we can sit,     And rest a little while.
10130-8{_}5027{_}"For our kind master never minds,     If we're the very last;   He bids us never tire ourselves     With walking on too fast."
10130-8{_}5028{_}GOING INTO BREECHES    Joy to Philip, he this day   Has his long coats cast away,   And (the childish season gone)   Puts the manly breeches on.
10130-8{_}5029{_}Officer on gay parade,   Red-coat in his first cockade,   Bridegroom in his wedding trim,   Birthday beau surpassing him,   Never did with conscious gait   Strut about in half the state,   Or the pride (yet free from sin)   Of my little MANIKIN:   Never was there pride, or bliss,   Half so rational as his.
10130-8{_}5030{_}Sashes, frocks, to those that need 'em--   Philip's limbs have got their freedom--   He can run, or he can ride,   And do twenty things beside,   Which his petticoats forbad:   Is he not a happy lad?
10130-8{_}5031{_}Now he's under other banners,   He must leave his former manners;   Bid adieu to female games,   And forget their very names,   Puss in Corners, Hide and Seek,   Sports for girls and punies weak!
10130-8{_}5032{_}Baste the Bear he now may play at,   Leap-frog, Foot-ball, sport away at,   Show his skill and strength at Cricket,   Mark his distance, pitch his wicket,   Run about in winter's snow   Till his cheeks and fingers glow,   Climb a tree, or scale a wall,   Without any fear to fall.
10130-8{_}5033{_}If he get a hurt or bruise,   To complain he must refuse,   Though the anguish and the smart   Go unto his little heart,   He must have his courage ready,   Keep his voice and visage steady,   Brace his eye-balls stiff as drum,   That a tear may never come,   And his grief must only speak   From the colour in his cheek.
10130-8{_}5034{_}This and more he must endure,   Hero he in miniature!
10130-8{_}5035{_}This and more must now be done   Now the breeches are put on.
10130-8{_}5036{_}NURSING    O hush, my little baby brother;     Sleep, my love, upon my knee.
10130-8{_}5037{_}What though, dear child, we've lost our mother;     That can never trouble thee.
10130-8{_}5038{_}You are but ten weeks old to-morrow;     What can you know of our loss?
10130-8{_}5039{_}The house is full enough of sorrow.
10130-8{_}5040{_}Little baby, don't be cross.
10130-8{_}5041{_}Peace, cry not so, my dearest love;     Hush, my baby-bird, lie still.--   He's quiet now, he does not move,     Fast asleep is little Will.
10130-8{_}5042{_}My only solace, only joy,     Since the sad day I lost my mother,   Is nursing her own Willy boy,     My little orphan brother.
10130-8{_}5043{_}THE TEXT    One Sunday eve a grave old man,     Who had not been at church, did say,   "Eliza, tell me, if you can,     What text our Doctor took to-day?"
10130-8{_}5044{_}She hung her head, she blush'd for shame,     One single word she did not know,   Nor verse nor chapter she could name,     Her silent blushes told him so.
10130-8{_}5045{_}Again said he, "My little maid,     What in the sermon did you hear;   Come tell me that, for that may aid     Me to find out the text, my dear."
10130-8{_}5046{_}A tear stole down each blushing cheek,     She wish'd she better had attended;   She sobbing said, when she could speak,     She heard not till 'twas almost ended.
10130-8{_}5047{_}"Ah!
10130-8{_}5048{_}little heedless one, why what     Could you be thinking on?
10130-8{_}5049{_}'tis clear   Some foolish fancies must have got     Possession of your head, my dear.
10130-8{_}5050{_}"What thoughts were they, Eliza, tell,     Nor seek from me the truth to smother."
10130-8{_}5051{_}--   "O I remember very well,     I whisper'd something to my brother.
10130-8{_}5052{_}"I said, 'Be friends with me, dear Will;'     We quarrell'd, Sir, at the church door,--   Though he cried, 'Hush, don't speak, be still,'     Yet I repeated these words o'er    "Sev'n or eight times, I have no doubt.
10130-8{_}5053{_}But here comes William, and if he   The good things he has heard about     Forgets too, Sir, the fault's in me."
10130-8{_}5054{_}"No, Sir," said William, "though perplext     And much disturbed by my sister,   I in this matter of the text,     I thank my memory, can assist her.
10130-8{_}5055{_}"I have, and pride myself on having,     A more retentive head than she."
10130-8{_}5056{_}--   Then gracefully his right hand waving,     He with no little vanity    Recited gospel, chapter, verse--     I should be loth to spoil in metre   All the good words he did rehearse,     As spoken by our Lord to Peter.
10130-8{_}5057{_}But surely never words from heaven     Of peace and love more full descended;   That we should seventy times seven     Forgive our brother that offended.
10130-8{_}5058{_}In every point of view he plac'd it,     As he the Doctor's self had been,   With emphasis and action grac'd it:     But from his self-conceit 'twas seen    Who had brought home the words, and who had     A little on the meaning thought;   Eliza now the old man knew had     Learn'd that which William never caught.
10130-8{_}5059{_}Without impeaching William's merit,     His head but served him for the letter,   Hers miss'd the words, but kept the spirit;     Her memory to her heart was debtor.
10130-8{_}5060{_}THE END OF MAY    "Our Governess is not in school,     So we may talk a bit;   Sit down upon this little stool,     Come, little Mary, sit:    "And, my dear play-mate, tell me why     In dismal black you're drest?
10130-8{_}5061{_}Why does the tear stand in your eye?
10130-8{_}5062{_}With sobs why heaves your breast?
10130-8{_}5063{_}"When we're in grief, it gives relief     Our sorrows to impart;   When you've told why, my dear, you cry,     'Twill ease your little heart."
10130-8{_}5064{_}"O, it is trouble very bad     Which causes me to weep;   All last night long we were so sad,     Not one of us could sleep.
10130-8{_}5065{_}"Beyond the seas my father went,     'Twas very long ago;   And he last week a letter sent     (I told you so, you know)    "That he was safe in Portsmouth bay,     And we should see him soon,   Either the latter end of May,     Or by the first of June.
10130-8{_}5066{_}"The end of May was yesterday,     We all expected him;   And in our best clothes we were drest,     Susan, and I, and Jim.
10130-8{_}5067{_}"O how my poor dear mother smil'd,     And clapt her hands for joy;   She said to me, 'Come here, my child,     And Susan, and my boy.
10130-8{_}5068{_}"'Come all, and let us think,' said she,     'What we can do to please   Your father, for to-day will he     Come home from off the seas.
10130-8{_}5069{_}"'That you have won, my dear young son,     A prize at school, we'll tell,   Because you can, my little man,     In writing all excel;    "'And you have made a poem, nearly     All of your own invention:   Will not your father love you dearly,     When this to him I mention?
10130-8{_}5070{_}"'Your sister Mary, she can say     Your poetry by heart;   And to repeat your verses may     Be little Mary's part,    "'Susan, for you, I'll say you do     Your needlework with care,   And stitch so true the wristbands new,     Dear father's soon to wear!'
10130-8{_}5071{_}"'O hark!'
10130-8{_}5072{_}said James; 'I hear one speak;     'Tis like a seaman's voice.'
10130-8{_}5073{_}--   Our mother gave a joyful shriek;     How did we all rejoice!
10130-8{_}5074{_}"'My husband's come!'
10130-8{_}5075{_}'My father's here!
10130-8{_}5076{_}But O, alas, it was not so;       It was not as we said:   A stranger seaman did appear,   On his rough cheek there stood a tear,     For he brought to us a tale of woe,       Our father dear was dead."
10130-8{_}5077{_}FEIGNED COURAGE    Horatio, of ideal courage vain,   Was flourishing in air his father's cane,   And, as the fumes of valour swell'd his pate,   Now thought himself _this_ Hero, and now _that_:   "And now," he cried, "I will Achilles be;   My sword I brandish; see, the Trojans flee.
10130-8{_}5078{_}Now I'll be Hector, when his angry blade   A lane through heaps of slaughter'd Grecians made!
10130-8{_}5079{_}And now by deeds still braver I'll evince,   I am no less than Edward the Black Prince.--   Give way, ye coward French:--" as thus he spoke,   And aim'd in fancy a sufficient stroke   To fix the fate of Cressy or Poictiers;   (The Muse relates the Hero's fate with tears)   He struck his milk-white hand against a nail,   Sees his own blood, and feels his courage fail.
10130-8{_}5080{_}Ah!
10130-8{_}5081{_}where is now that boasted valour flown,   That in the tented field so late was shown!
10130-8{_}5082{_}Achilles weeps, Great Hector hangs the head,   And the Black Prince goes whimpering to bed.
10130-8{_}5083{_}THE BROKEN DOLL    An infant is a selfish sprite;   But what of that?
10130-8{_}5084{_}the sweet delight   Which from participation springs,   Is quite unknown to these young things.
10130-8{_}5085{_}We elder children then will smile   At our dear little John awhile,   And bear with him, until he see   There is a sweet felicity   In pleasing more than only one   Dear little craving selfish John.
10130-8{_}5086{_}He laughs, and thinks it a fine joke,   That he our new wax doll has broke.
10130-8{_}5087{_}Anger will never teach him better;   We will the spirit and the letter   Of courtesy to him display,   By taking in a friendly way   These baby frolics, till he learn   True sport from mischief to discern.
10130-8{_}5088{_}Reproof a parent's province is;   A sister's discipline is this,   By studied kindness to effect   A little brother's young respect.
10130-8{_}5089{_}What is a doll?
10130-8{_}5090{_}a fragile toy.
10130-8{_}5091{_}What is its loss?
10130-8{_}5092{_}if the dear boy,   Who half perceives he's done amiss,   Retain impression of the kiss   That follow'd instant on his cheek;   If the kind loving words we speak   Of "Never mind it," "We forgive,"   If these in his short memory live   Only perchance for half a day--   Who minds a doll--if that should lay   The first impression in his mind   That sisters are to brothers kind?
10130-8{_}5093{_}For thus the broken doll may prove   Foundation to fraternal love.
10130-8{_}5094{_}THE DUTY OF A BROTHER    Why on your sister do you look,     Octavius, with an eye of scorn,   As scarce her presence you could brook?--     Under one roof you both were born.
10130-8{_}5095{_}Why, when she gently proffers speech,     Do you ungently turn your head?
10130-8{_}5096{_}Since the same sire gave life to each;     With the same milk ye both were fed.
10130-8{_}5097{_}Such treatment to a female, though     A perfect stranger she might be,   From you would most unmanly show;     In you to her 'tis worse to see.
10130-8{_}5098{_}When any ill-bred boys offend her,     Showing their manhood by their sneers,   It is your business to defend her     'Gainst their united taunts and jeers.
10130-8{_}5099{_}And not to join the illiberal crew     In their contempt of female merit;   What's bad enough in them, from you     Is want of goodness, want of spirit.
10130-8{_}5100{_}What if your rougher out-door sports     Her less robustious spirits daunt;   And if she join not the resorts,     Where you and your wild playmates haunt:    Her milder province is at home;     When your diversions have an end,   When over-toil'd from play you come,     You'll find in her an in-doors friend.
10130-8{_}5101{_}Leave not your sister to another;     As long as both of you reside   In the same house, who but her brother     Should point her books, her studies guide?
10130-8{_}5102{_}If Nature, who allots our cup,     Than her has made you stronger, wiser;   It is that you, as you grow up,     Should be her champion, her adviser.
10130-8{_}5103{_}It is the law that Hand intends,     Which fram'd diversity of sex;   The man the woman still defends,     The manly boy the girl protects.
10130-8{_}5104{_}WASPS IN A GARDEN    The wall-trees are laden with fruit;     The grape, and the plum, and the pear,   The peach, and the nect'rine, to suit     Ev'ry taste in abundance, are there.
10130-8{_}5105{_}Yet all are not welcome to taste     These kind bounties of nature; for one   From her open-spread table must haste,     To make room for a more favour'd son:    As that wasp will soon sadly perceive,     Who has feasted awhile on a plum;   And, his thirst thinking now to relieve,     For a sweet liquid draught he is come.
10130-8{_}5106{_}He peeps in the narrow-mouth'd glass,     Which depends from a branch of the tree;   He ventures to creep down,--alas!
10130-8{_}5107{_}To be drown'd in that delicate sea.
10130-8{_}5108{_}"Ah say," my dear friend, "is it right,     These glass bottles are hung upon trees:   'Midst a scene of inviting delight,     Should we find such mementoes as these?"
10130-8{_}5109{_}"From such sights," said my friend, "we may draw     A lesson, for look at that bee;   Compar'd with the wasp which you saw,     He will teach us what we ought to be.
10130-8{_}5110{_}"He in safety industriously plies     His sweet honest work all the day,   Then home with his earnings he flies;     Nor in thieving his time wastes away."
10130-8{_}5111{_}--    "O hush, nor with _fables_ deceive,"     I replied; "which, though pretty, can ne'er   Make me cease for that insect to grieve,     Who in agony still does appear.
10130-8{_}5112{_}"If a _simile_ ever you need,     You are welcome to make a wasp do;   But you ne'er should mix fiction indeed     With things that are serious and true."
10130-8{_}5113{_}WHAT IS FANCY?
10130-8{_}5114{_}SISTER    I am to write three lines, and you   Three others that will rhyme.
10130-8{_}5115{_}There--now I've done my task.
10130-8{_}5116{_}BROTHER    Three stupid lines as e'er I knew.
10130-8{_}5117{_}When you've the pen next time,   Some Question of me ask.
10130-8{_}5118{_}SISTER    Then tell me, brother, and pray mind,   Brother, you tell me true:   What sort of thing is _fancy_?
10130-8{_}5119{_}BROTHER    By all that I can ever find,   'Tis something that is very new,   And what no dunces _can see_.
10130-8{_}5120{_}SISTER    That is not half the way to tell   What _fancy_ is about;   So pray now tell me more.
10130-8{_}5121{_}BROTHER    Sister, I think 'twere quite as well   That you should find it out;   So think the matter o'er.
10130-8{_}5122{_}SISTER    It's what comes in our heads when we   Play at "Let's make believe,"   And when we play at "Guessing."
10130-8{_}5123{_}BROTHER    And I have heard it said to be   A talent often makes us grieve,   And sometimes proves a blessing.
10130-8{_}5124{_}ANGER    Anger in its time and place   May assume a kind of grace.
10130-8{_}5125{_}It must have some reason in it,   And not last beyond a minute.
10130-8{_}5126{_}If to further lengths it go,   It does into malice grow.
10130-8{_}5127{_}'Tis the difference that we see   'Twixt the Serpent and the Bee.
10130-8{_}5128{_}If the latter you provoke,   It inflicts a hasty stroke,   Puts you to some little pain,   But it _never stings again_.
10130-8{_}5129{_}Close in tufted bush or brake   Lurks the poison-swelled snake,   Nursing up his cherish'd wrath.
10130-8{_}5130{_}In the purlieus of his path,   In the cold, or in the warm,   Mean him good, or mean him harm,   Whensoever fate may bring you,   The vile snake will _always sting you_.
10130-8{_}5131{_}BLINDNESS    In a stage-coach, where late I chanc'd to be,     A little quiet girl my notice caught;   I saw she look'd at nothing by the way,     Her mind seem'd busy on some childish thought.
10130-8{_}5132{_}I with an old man's courtesy address'd     The child, and call'd her pretty dark-eyed maid   And bid her turn those pretty eyes and see     The wide extended prospect.
10130-8{_}5133{_}"Sir," she said,    "I cannot see the prospect, I am blind."
10130-8{_}5134{_}Never did tongue of child utter a sound   So mournful, as her words fell on my ear.
10130-8{_}5135{_}Her mother then related how she found    Her child was sightless.
10130-8{_}5136{_}On a fine bright day     She saw her lay her needlework aside,   And, as on such occasions mothers will,     For leaving off her work began to chide.
10130-8{_}5137{_}"I'll do it when 'tis day-light, if you please;     I cannot work, Mamma, now it is night."
10130-8{_}5138{_}The sun shone bright upon her when she spoke,     And yet her eyes receiv'd no ray of light.
10130-8{_}5139{_}THE MIMIC HARLEQUIN    "I'll _make believe_, and fancy something strange:   I will suppose I have the power to change   And make all things unlike to what they were,   To jump through windows and fly through the air,   And quite confound all places and all times,   Like Harlequins we see in Pantomimes.
10130-8{_}5140{_}These thread-papers my wooden sword must be,   Nothing more like one I at present see.
10130-8{_}5141{_}And now all round this drawing-room I'll range   And every thing I look at I will change.
10130-8{_}5142{_}Here's Mopsa, our old cat, shall be a bird;   To a Poll Parrot she is now transferr'd.
10130-8{_}5143{_}Here's Mamma's work-bag, now I will engage   To whisk this little bag into a cage;   And now, my pretty Parrot, get you in it,   Another change I'll shew you in a minute."
10130-8{_}5144{_}"O fie, you naughty child, what have you done?
10130-8{_}5145{_}There never was so mischievous a son.
10130-8{_}5146{_}You've put the cat among my work, and torn   A fine lac'd cap that I but once have worn."
10130-8{_}5147{_}WRITTEN IN THE FIRST LEAF OF A CHILD'S MEMORANDUM-BOOK    My neat and pretty book, when I thy small lines see,   They seem for any use to be unfit for me.
10130-8{_}5148{_}My writing, all misshaped, uneven as my mind,   Within this narrow space can hardly be confin'd.
10130-8{_}5149{_}Yet I will strive to make my hand less aukward look;   I would not willingly disgrace thee, my neat book!
10130-8{_}5150{_}The finest pens I'll use, and wond'rous pains I'll take,   And I these perfect lines my monitors will make.
10130-8{_}5151{_}And every day I will set down in order due,   How that day wasted is; and should there be a few   At the year's end that shew more goodly to the sight,   If haply here I find some days not wasted quite,   If a small portion of them I have pass'd aright,   Then shall I think the year not wholly was misspent,   And that my Diary has been by some good Angel sent.
10130-8{_}5152{_}MEMORY    "For gold could Memory be bought,     What treasures would she not be worth!
10130-8{_}5153{_}If from afar she could be brought,     I'd travel for her through the earth!"
10130-8{_}5154{_}This exclamation once was made     By one who had obtain'd the name   Of young forgetful Adelaide:     And while she spoke, lo!
10130-8{_}5155{_}Memory came.
