10130-8{_}5156{_}If Memory indeed it were,     Or such it only feign'd to be--   A female figure came to her,     Who said, "My name is Memory:    "Gold purchases in me no share,     Nor do I dwell in distant land;   Study, and thought, and watchful care,     In every place may me command.
10130-8{_}5157{_}"I am not lightly to be won;     A visit only now I make:   And much must by yourself be done,     Ere me you for an inmate take.
10130-8{_}5158{_}"The only substitute for me     Was ever found, is call'd a pen:   The frequent use of that will be     The way to make me come again."
10130-8{_}5159{_}THE REPROOF    Mamma heard me with scorn and pride   A wretched beggar boy deride.
10130-8{_}5160{_}"Do you not know," said I, "how mean   It is to be thus begging seen?
10130-8{_}5161{_}If for a week I were not fed,   I'm sure I would not beg my bread."
10130-8{_}5162{_}And then away she saw me stalk   With a most self-important walk.
10130-8{_}5163{_}But meeting her upon the stairs,   All these my consequential airs   Were chang'd to an entreating look.
10130-8{_}5164{_}"Give me," said I, "the Pocket Book,   Mamma, you promis'd I should have."
10130-8{_}5165{_}The Pocket Book to me she gave;   After reproof and counsel sage,   She bade me write in the first page   This naughty action all in rhyme;   No food to have until the time,   In writing fair and neatly worded,   The unfeeling fact I had recorded.
10130-8{_}5166{_}Slow I compose, and slow I write;   And now I feel keen hunger bite.
10130-8{_}5167{_}My mother's pardon I entreat,   And beg she'll give me food to eat.
10130-8{_}5168{_}Dry bread would be received with joy   By her repentant Beggar Boy.
10130-8{_}5169{_}THE TWO BEES    But a few words could William say,     And those few could not speak plain.
10130-8{_}5170{_}Yet thought he was a man one day;     Never saw I a boy so vain.
10130-8{_}5171{_}From what could vanity proceed     In such a little lisping lad?
10130-8{_}5172{_}Or was it vanity indeed?
10130-8{_}5173{_}Or was he only very glad?
10130-8{_}5174{_}For he without his maid may go     To the heath with elder boys,   And pluck ripe berries where they grow:     Well may William then rejoice.
10130-8{_}5175{_}Be careful of your little charge;     Elder boys, let him not rove;   The heath is wide, the heath is large,     From your sight he must not move.
10130-8{_}5176{_}But rove he did: they had not been     One short hour the heath upon,   When he was no where to be seen;     "Where," said they, "is William gone?"
10130-8{_}5177{_}Mind not the elder boys' distress;     Let them run, and let them fly.
10130-8{_}5178{_}Their own neglect and giddiness     They are justly suffering by.
10130-8{_}5179{_}William his little basket fill'd     With his berries ripe and red;   Then, naughty boy, two bees he kill'd,     Under foot he stamp'd them dead.
10130-8{_}5180{_}William had cours'd them o'er the heath,     After them his steps did wander;   When he was nearly out of breath,     The last bee his foot was under.
10130-8{_}5181{_}A cruel triumph, which did not     Last but for a moment's space,   For now he finds that he has got     Out of sight of every face.
10130-8{_}5182{_}What are the berries now to him?
10130-8{_}5183{_}What the bees which he hath slain?
10130-8{_}5184{_}Fear now possesses every limb,     He cannot trace his steps again.
10130-8{_}5185{_}The poor bees William had affrighted     In more terror did not haste,   Than he from bush to bush, benighted     And alone amid the waste.
10130-8{_}5186{_}Late in the night the child was found:     He who these two bees had crush'd   Was lying on the cold damp ground,     Sleep had then his sorrows hush'd.
10130-8{_}5187{_}A fever follow'd from the fright,     And from sleeping in the dew;   He many a day and many a night     Suffer'd ere he better grew.
10130-8{_}5188{_}His aching limbs while sick he lay     Made him learn the crush'd bees' pain;   Oft would he to his mother say,     "I ne'er will kill a bee again."
10130-8{_}5189{_}THE JOURNEY FROM SCHOOL AND TO SCHOOL    O what a joyous joyous day     Is that on which we come   At the recess from school away,     Each lad to his own home!
10130-8{_}5190{_}What though the coach is crammed full,     The weather very warm;   Think you a boy of us is dull,     Or feels the slightest harm?
10130-8{_}5191{_}The dust and sun is life and fun;     The hot and sultry weather   A higher zest gives every breast,     Thus jumbled all together.
10130-8{_}5192{_}Sometimes we laugh aloud aloud,     Sometimes huzzah, huzzah.
10130-8{_}5193{_}Who is so buoyant, free, and proud,     As we home-travellers are?
10130-8{_}5194{_}But sad, but sad is every lad     That day on which we come,   That last last day on which away     We all come from our home.
10130-8{_}5195{_}The coach too full is found to be:     Why is it crammed thus?
10130-8{_}5196{_}Now every one can plainly see     There's not half room for us.
10130-8{_}5197{_}Soon we exclaim, O shame, O shame,     This hot and sultry weather,   Who but our master is to blame,     Who pack'd us thus together!
10130-8{_}5198{_}Now dust and sun does every one     Most terribly annoy;   Complaints begun, soon every one     Elbows his neighbour boy.
10130-8{_}5199{_}Not now the joyous laugh goes round,     We shout not now huzzah;   A sadder group may not be found     Than we returning are.
10130-8{_}5200{_}THE ORANGE    The month was June, the day was hot,   And Philip had an orange got.
10130-8{_}5201{_}The fruit was fragrant, tempting, bright,   Refreshing to the smell and sight;   Not of that puny size which calls   Poor customers to common stalls,   But large and massy, full of juice,   As any Lima can produce.
10130-8{_}5202{_}The liquor would, if squeezed out,   Have fill'd a tumbler thereabout--      The happy boy, with greedy eyes,   Surveys and re-surveys his prize.
10130-8{_}5203{_}He turns it round, and longs to drain,   And with the juice his lips to stain.
10130-8{_}5204{_}His throat and lips were parch'd with heat;   The orange seem'd to cry, _Come eat_.
10130-8{_}5205{_}He from his pocket draws a knife--   When in his thoughts there rose a strife,   Which folks experience when they wish,   Yet scruple to begin a dish,   And by their hesitation own   It is too good to eat alone.
10130-8{_}5206{_}But appetite o'er indecision   Prevails, and Philip makes incision.
10130-8{_}5207{_}The melting fruit in quarters came--   Just then there passed by a dame--   One of the poorer sort she seem'd,   As by her garb you would have deem'd--   Who in her toil-worn arms did hold   A sickly infant ten months old;   That from a fever, caught in spring,   Was slowly then recovering.
10130-8{_}5208{_}The child, attracted by the view   Of that fair orange, feebly threw   A languid look--perhaps the smell   Convinc'd it that there sure must dwell   A corresponding sweetness there,   Where lodg'd a scent so good and rare--   Perhaps the smell the fruit did give   Felt healing and restorative--   For never had the child been grac'd   To know such dainties by their taste.
10130-8{_}5209{_}When Philip saw the infant crave,   He straitway to the mother gave   His quarter'd orange; nor would stay   To hear her thanks, but tript away.
10130-8{_}5210{_}Then to the next clear spring he ran   To quench his drought, a happy man!
10130-8{_}5211{_}THE YOUNG LETTER-WRITER    _Dear Sir, Dear Madam_, or _Dear Friend_,     With ease are written at the top;   When those two happy words are penn'd,     A youthful writer oft will stop,    And bite his pen, and lift his eyes,     As if he thinks to find in air   The wish'd-for following words, or tries     To fix his thoughts by fixed stare.
10130-8{_}5212{_}But haply all in vain--the next     Two words may be so long before   They'll come, the writer, sore perplext,     Gives in despair the matter o'er;    And when maturer age he sees     With ready pen so swift inditing,   With envy he beholds the ease     Of long-accustom'd letter-writing.
10130-8{_}5213{_}Courage, young friend; the time may be,     When you attain maturer age,   Some young as you are now may see     You with like ease glide down a page.
10130-8{_}5214{_}Ev'n then when you, to years a debtor,     In varied phrase your meanings wrap,   The welcom'st words in all your letter     May be those two kind words at top.
10130-8{_}5215{_}THE THREE FRIENDS  (_Text of 1818_)    Three young maids in friendship met;   Mary, Martha, Margaret.
10130-8{_}5216{_}Margaret was tall and fair,   Martha shorter by a hair;   If the first excell'd in feature,   Th' other's grace and ease were greater;   Mary, though to rival loth,   In their best gifts equall'd both.
10130-8{_}5217{_}They a due proportion kept;   Martha mourn'd if Margaret wept;   Margaret joy'd when any good   She of Martha understood;   And in sympathy for either   Mary was outdone by neither.
10130-8{_}5218{_}Thus far, for a happy space,   All three ran an even race,   A most constant friendship proving,   Equally belov'd and loving;   All their wishes, joys, the same;   Sisters only not in name.
10130-8{_}5219{_}Fortune upon each one smil'd,   As upon a fav'rite child;   Well to do and well to see   Were the parents of all three;   Till on Martha's father crosses   Brought a flood of worldly losses,   And his fortunes rich and great   Chang'd at once to low estate;   Under which o'erwhelming blow   Martha's mother was laid low;   She a hapless orphan left,   Of maternal care bereft,   Trouble following trouble fast,   Lay in a sick bed at last.
10130-8{_}5220{_}In the depth of her affliction   Martha now receiv'd conviction,   That a true and faithful friend   Can the surest comfort lend.
10130-8{_}5221{_}Night and day, with friendship tried,   Ever constant by her side   Was her gentle Mary found,   With a love that knew no bound;   And the solace she imparted   Sav'd her dying' broken-hearted.
10130-8{_}5222{_}In this scene of earthly things   Not one good unmixed springs.
10130-8{_}5223{_}That which had to Martha proved   A sweet consolation, moved   Different feelings of regret   In the mind of Margaret.
10130-8{_}5224{_}She, whose love was not less dear,   Nor affection less sincere   To her friend, was, by occasion   Of more distant habitation,   Fewer visits forc'd to pay her,   When no other cause did stay her;   And her Mary living nearer,   Margaret began to fear her,   Lest her visits day by day   Martha's heart should steal away.
10130-8{_}5225{_}That whole heart she ill could spare her,   Where till now she'd been a sharer.
10130-8{_}5226{_}From this cause with grief she pined,   Till at length her health declined.
10130-8{_}5227{_}All her chearful spirits flew,   Fast as Martha gather'd new;   And her sickness waxed sore,   Just when Martha felt no more.
10130-8{_}5228{_}Mary, who had quick suspicion   Of her alter'd friend's condition,   Seeing Martha's convalescence   Less demanded now her presence,   With a goodness, built on reason,   Chang'd her measures with the season;   Turn'd her steps from Martha's door,   Went where she was wanted more;   All her care and thoughts were set   Now to tend on Margaret.
10130-8{_}5229{_}Mary living 'twixt the two,   From her home could oft'ner go,   Either of her friends to see,   Than they could together be.
10130-8{_}5230{_}Truth explain'd is to suspicion   Evermore the best physician.
10130-8{_}5231{_}Soon her visits had the effect;   All that Margaret did suspect,   From her fancy vanish'd clean;   She was soon what she had been,   And the colour she did lack   To her faded cheek came back.
10130-8{_}5232{_}Wounds which love had made her feel,   Love alone had power to heal.
10130-8{_}5233{_}Martha, who the frequent visit   Now had lost, and sore did miss it,   With impatience waxed cross,   Counted Margaret's gain her loss:   All that Mary did confer   On her friend, thought due to her.
10130-8{_}5234{_}In her girlish bosom rise   Little foolish jealousies,   Which into such rancour wrought,   She one day for Margaret sought;   Finding her by chance alone,   She began, with reasons shown,   To insinuate a fear   Whether Mary was sincere;   Wish'd that Margaret would take heed   Whence her actions did proceed.
10130-8{_}5235{_}For herself, she'd long been minded   Not with outsides to be blinded;   All that pity and compassion,   She believ'd was affectation;   In her heart she doubted whether   Mary car'd a pin for either.
10130-8{_}5236{_}She could keep whole weeks at distance,   And not know of their existence,   While all things remain'd the same;   But, when some misfortune came,   Then she made a great parade   Of her sympathy and aid,--   Not that she did really grieve,   It was only _make-believe_,   And she car'd for nothing, so   She might her fine feelings shew,   And get credit, on her part,   For a soft and tender heart.
10130-8{_}5237{_}With such speeches, smoothly made,   She found methods to persuade   Margaret (who, being sore   From the doubts she'd felt before,   Was prepared for mistrust)   To believe her reasons just;   Quite destroy'd that comfort glad,   Which in Mary late she had;   Made her, in experience' spite,   Think her friend a hypocrite,   And resolve, with cruel scoff,   To renounce and cast her off.
10130-8{_}5238{_}See how good turns are rewarded!
10130-8{_}5239{_}She of both is now discarded,   Who to both had been so late   Their support in low estate,   All their comfort, and their stay--   Now of both is cast away.
10130-8{_}5240{_}But the league her presence cherish'd,   Losing its best prop, soon perish'd;   She, that was a link to either,   To keep them and it together,   Being gone, the two (no wonder)   That were left, soon fell asunder;--   Some civilities were kept,   But the heart of friendship slept;   Love with hollow forms was fed,   But the life of love lay dead:--   A cold intercourse they held   After Mary was expell'd.
10130-8{_}5241{_}Two long years did intervene   Since they'd either of them seen,   Or, by letter, any word   Of their old companion heard,--   When, upon a day, once walking,   Of indifferent matters talking,   They a female figure met;--   Martha said to Margaret,   "That young maid in face does carry   A resemblance strong of Mary."
10130-8{_}5242{_}Margaret, at nearer sight,   Own'd her observation right:   But they did not far proceed   Ere they knew 'twas she indeed.
10130-8{_}5243{_}She--but ah!
10130-8{_}5244{_}how chang'd they view her   From that person which they knew her!
10130-8{_}5245{_}Her fine face disease had scarr'd,   And its matchless beauty marr'd:--   But enough was left to trace   Mary's sweetness--Mary's grace.
10130-8{_}5246{_}When her eye did first behold them,   How they blush'd!--but, when she told them   How on a sick bed she lay   Months, while they had kept away,   And had no inquiries made   If she were alive or dead;--   How, for want of a true friend,   She was brought near to her end,   And was like so to have died,   With no friend at her bed-side;--   How the constant irritation,   Caus'd by fruitless expectation   Of their coming, had extended   The illness, when she might have mended,--   Then, O then, how did reflection   Come on them with recollection!
10130-8{_}5247{_}All that she had done for them,   How it did their fault condemn!
10130-8{_}5248{_}But sweet Mary, still the same,   Kindly eas'd them of their shame;   Spoke to them with accents bland,   Took them friendly by the hand;   Bound them both with promise fast,   Not to speak of troubles past;   Made them on the spot declare   A new league of friendship there;   Which, without a word of strife,   Lasted thenceforth long as life.
10130-8{_}5249{_}Martha now and Margaret   Strove who most should pay the debt   Which they ow'd her, nor did vary   Ever after from their Mary.
10130-8{_}5250{_}ON THE LORD'S PRAYER    I have taught your young lips the good words to say over,     Which form the petition we call the Lord's Pray'r,   And now let me help my dear child to discover     The meaning of all the good words that are there.
10130-8{_}5251{_}"Our Father," the same appellation is given     To a parent on earth, and the parent of all--   O gracious permission, the God that's in heaven     Allows his poor creatures him Father to call.
10130-8{_}5252{_}To "hallow his name," is to think with devotion     Of it, and with reverence mention the same;   Though you are so young, you should strive for some notion     Of the awe we should feel at the Holy One's name.
10130-8{_}5253{_}His "will done on earth, as it is done in heaven,"     Is a wish and a hope we are suffer'd to breathe,   That such grace and favour to us may be given,     Like good angels on high we may live here beneath.
10130-8{_}5254{_}"Our daily bread give us," your young apprehension     May well understand is to pray for our food;   Although we ask bread, and no other thing mention,     God's bounty gives all things sufficient and good.
10130-8{_}5255{_}You pray that your "trespasses may be forgiven,     As you forgive those that are done unto you;"   Before this you say to the God that's in heaven,     Consider the words which you speak.
10130-8{_}5256{_}Are they true?
10130-8{_}5257{_}If any one has in the past time offended     Us angry creatures who soon take offence,   These words in the prayer are surely intended     To soften our minds, and expel wrath from thence.
10130-8{_}5258{_}We pray that "temptations may never assail us,"     And "deliverance beg from all evil" we find;   But we never can hope that our pray'r will avail us,     If we strive not to banish ill thoughts from our mind.
10130-8{_}5259{_}"For thine is the kingdom, the power, and the glory,     For ever and ever," these titles are meant   To express God's dominion and majesty o'er ye:     And "Amen" to the sense of the whole gives assent.
10130-8{_}5260{_}"SUFFER LITTLE CHILDREN, AND FORBID THEM NOT, TO COME UNTO ME"    To Jesus our Saviour some parents presented     Their children--what fears and what hopes they must feel!
10130-8{_}5261{_}When this the disciples would fain have prevented,     Our Saviour reprov'd their unseas'nable zeal.
10130-8{_}5262{_}Not only free leave to come to him was given,     But "Of such" were the blessed words Christ our Lord spake,   "Of such is composed the kingdom of heaven:"     The disciples, abashed, perceiv'd their mistake.
10130-8{_}5263{_}With joy then the parents their children brought nigher,     And earnestly begg'd that his hands he would lay   On their heads; and they made a petition still higher,     That he for a blessing upon them would pray.
10130-8{_}5264{_}O happy young children, thus brought to adore him,     To kneel at his feet, and look up in his face;   No doubt now in heaven they still are before him,     Children still of his love, and enjoying his grace.
10130-8{_}5265{_}For being so blest as to come to our Saviour,     How deep in their innocent hearts it must sink!
10130-8{_}5266{_}'Twas a visit divine; a most holy behaviour     Must flow from that spring of which then they did drink.
10130-8{_}5267{_}THE MAGPYE'S NEST OR A LESSON OF DOCILITY  A FABLE    When the arts in their infancy were,     In a fable of old 'tis exprest,   A wise Magpye constructed that rare     Little house for young birds, call'd a nest.
10130-8{_}5268{_}This was talk'd of the whole country round,     You might hear it on every bough sung,   "Now no longer upon the rough ground     Will fond mothers brood over their young.
10130-8{_}5269{_}"For the Magpye with exquisite skill     Has invented a moss-cover'd cell,   Within which a whole family will     In the utmost security dwell."
10130-8{_}5270{_}To her mate did each female bird say,     "Let us fly to the Magpye, my dear;   If she will but teach us the way,     A nest we will build us up here.
10130-8{_}5271{_}"It's a thing that's close arch'd over head,     With a hole made to creep out and in;   We, my bird, might make just such a bed,     If we only knew how to begin."
10130-8{_}5272{_}To the Magpye soon every bird went,     And in modest terms made their request,   That she would be pleas'd to consent     To teach them to build up a nest.
10130-8{_}5273{_}She replied, "I will shew you the way,     So observe every thing that I do.
10130-8{_}5274{_}First two sticks cross each other I lay--"     "To be sure," said the Crow; "why, I knew,    "It must be begun with two sticks,     And I thought that they crossed should be."
10130-8{_}5275{_}Said the Pye, "Then some straw and moss mix,     In the way you now see done by me."
10130-8{_}5276{_}"O yes, certainly," said the Jack Daw,     "That must follow of course, I have thought;   Though I never before building saw,     I guess'd that without being taught."
10130-8{_}5277{_}"More moss, straw, and feathers, I place,     In this manner," continued the Pye.
10130-8{_}5278{_}"Yes, no doubt, Madam, that is the case;     Though no builder myself, even I,"    Said the Starling, "conjectur'd 'twas so;     It must of necessity follow:   For more moss, straw, and feathers, I know,     It requires, to be soft, round, and hollow."
10130-8{_}5279{_}Whatever she taught them beside,     In his turn every bird of them said,   Though the nest-making art he ne'er tried,     He had just such a thought in his head.
10130-8{_}5280{_}Still the Pye went on shewing her art,     Till a nest she had built up half way;   She no more of her skill would impart,     But in anger went flutt'ring away.
10130-8{_}5281{_}And this speech in their hearing she made,     As she perched o'er their heads on a tree,   "If ye all were well skill'd in my trade,     Pray, why came ye to learn it of me?"
10130-8{_}5282{_}--    When a scholar is willing to learn,     He with silent submission should hear.
10130-8{_}5283{_}Too late they their folly discern;     The effect to this day does appear:    For whenever a Pye's nest you see,     Her charming warm canopy view,   All birds' nests but hers seem to be     A Magpye's nest just cut in two.
10130-8{_}5284{_}THE BOY AND THE SKY-LARK  A FABLE    "A wicked action fear to do,   When you are by yourselves; for though     You think you can conceal it,   A little bird that's in the air   The hidden trespass shall declare,     And openly reveal it."
10130-8{_}5285{_}Richard this saying oft had heard,   Until the sight of any bird     Would set his heart a quaking;   He saw a host of winged spies   For ever o'er him in the skies,     Note of his actions taking.
10130-8{_}5286{_}This pious precept, while it stood   In his remembrance, kept him good     When nobody was by him;   For though no human eye was near,   Yet Richard still did wisely fear     The little bird should spy him.
10130-8{_}5287{_}But best resolves will sometimes sleep;   Poor frailty will not always keep     From that which is forbidden;   And Richard one day, left alone,   Laid hands on something not his own,     And hop'd the theft was hidden.
10130-8{_}5288{_}His conscience slept a day or two,   As it is very apt to do     When we with pain suppress it;   And though at times a slight remorse   Would raise a pang, it had not force     To make him yet confess it.
10130-8{_}5289{_}When on a day, as he abroad   Walk'd by his mother, in their road     He heard a sky-lark singing;   Smit with the sound, a flood of tears   Proclaim'd the superstitious fears     His inmost bosom wringing.
10130-8{_}5290{_}His mother, wond'ring, saw him cry,   And fondly ask'd the reason why;     Then Richard made confession,   And said, he fear'd the little bird   He singing in the air had heard     Was telling his transgression.
10130-8{_}5291{_}The words which Richard spoke below,   As sounds by nature upwards go,     Were to the sky-lark carried;   The airy traveller with surprise   To hear his sayings, in the skies     On his mid journey tarried.
10130-8{_}5292{_}His anger then the bird exprest:   "Sure, since the day I left the nest,     I ne'er heard folly utter'd   So fit to move a sky-lark's mirth,   As what this little son of earth     Hath in his grossness mutter'd.
10130-8{_}5293{_}"Dull fool!
10130-8{_}5294{_}to think we sons of air   On man's low actions waste a care,     His virtues or his vices;   Or soaring on the summer gales,   That we should stoop to carry tales     Of him or his devices!
10130-8{_}5295{_}"Our songs are all of the delights   We find in our wild airy flights,     And heavenly exaltation;   The earth you mortals have at heart   Is all too gross to have a part     In sky-lark's conversation.
10130-8{_}5296{_}"Unless it be in what green field   Or meadow we our nest may build,     Midst flowering broom, or heather;   From whence our new-fledg'd offspring may   With least obstruction wing their way     Up to the walks of ether.
10130-8{_}5297{_}"Mistaken fool!
10130-8{_}5298{_}man needs not us   His secret merits to discuss,     Or spy out his transgression;   When once he feels his conscience stirr'd,   That voice within him is the _bird_     That moves him to confession."
10130-8{_}5299{_}THE MEN AND WOMEN, AND THE MONKEYS  A FABLE    When beasts by words their meanings could declare,   Some well-drest men and women did repair   To gaze upon two monkeys at a fair:    And one who was the spokesman in the place   Said, in their count'nance you might plainly trace   The likeness of a wither'd old man's face.
10130-8{_}5300{_}His observation none impeach'd or blam'd,   But every man and woman when 'twas nam'd   Drew in the head, or slunk away asham'd.
10130-8{_}5301{_}One monkey, who had more pride than the other,   His infinite chagrin could scarcely smother;   But Pug the wiser said unto his brother:    "The slights and coolness of this human nation   Should give a sensible ape no mort'fication;   'Tis thus they always serve a poor relation."
10130-8{_}5302{_}LOVE, DEATH, AND REPUTATION  A FABLE    Once on a time, Love, Death, and Reputation,     Three travellers, a tour together went;   And, after many a long perambulation,     Agreed to part by mutual consent.
10130-8{_}5303{_}Death said: "My fellow tourists, I am going     To seek for harvests in th' embattled plain;   Where drums are beating, and loud trumpets blowing,     There you'll be sure to meet with me again"    Love said: "My friends, I mean to spend my leisure     With some young couple, fresh in Hymen's bands;   Or 'mongst relations, who in equal measure     Have had bequeathed to them house or lands."
10130-8{_}5304{_}But Reputation said: "If once we sever,     Our chance of future meeting is but vain:   Who parts from me, must look to part for ever,     For _Reputation lost comes not again_."
10130-8{_}5305{_}THE SPARROW AND THE HEN    A Sparrow, when Sparrows like Parrots could speak,     Addressed an old Hen who could talk like a Jay:   Said he, "It's unjust that we Sparrows must seek     Our food, when your family's fed every day.
10130-8{_}5306{_}"Were you like the Peacock, that elegant bird,     The sight of whose plumage her master may please,   I then should not wonder that you are preferr'd     To the yard, where in affluence you live at your ease.
10130-8{_}5307{_}"I affect no great style, am not costly in feathers,     A good honest brown I find most to my liking,   It always looks neat, and is fit for all weathers,     But I think your gray mixture is not very striking.
10130-8{_}5308{_}"We know that the bird from the isles of Canary     Is fed, foreign airs to sing in a fine cage;   But your note from a cackle so seldom does vary,     The fancy of man it cannot much engage.
10130-8{_}5309{_}"My chirp to a song sure approaches much nearer,     Nay, the Nightingale tells me I sing not amiss;   If voice were in question I ought to be dearer;     But the Owl he assures me there's nothing in this.
10130-8{_}5310{_}"Nor is it your proneness to domestication,     For he dwells in man's barn, and I build in man's thatch,   As we say to each other--but, to our vexation,     O'er your safety alone man keeps diligent watch."
10130-8{_}5311{_}"Have you e'er learned to read?"
10130-8{_}5312{_}said the Hen to the Sparrow.
10130-8{_}5313{_}"No, Madam," he answer'd, "I can't say I have,"   "Then that is the reason your sight is so narrow,"     The old Hen replied, with a look very grave.
10130-8{_}5314{_}"Mrs. Glasse in a Treatise--I wish you could read--     Our importance has shown, and has prov'd to us why   Man shields us and feeds us: of us he has need     Ev'n before we are born, even after we die."
10130-8{_}5315{_}WHICH IS THE FAVOURITE?
10130-8{_}5316{_}Brothers and sisters I have many:   Though I know there is not any   Of them but I love, yet I   Will just name them all; and try,   As one by one I count them o'er,   If there be one a little more   Lov'd by me than all the rest.
10130-8{_}5317{_}Yes; I do think, that I love best   My brother Henry, because he   Has always been most fond of me.
10130-8{_}5318{_}Yet, to be sure, there's Isabel;   I think I love her quite as well.
10130-8{_}5319{_}And, I assure you, little Ann,   No brother nor no sister can   Be more dear to me than she.
10130-8{_}5320{_}Only, I must say, Emily,   Being the eldest, it's right her   To all the rest I should prefer.
10130-8{_}5321{_}Yet after all I've said, suppose   My greatest fav'rite should be Rose.
10130-8{_}5322{_}No, John and Paul are both more dear   To me than Rose, that's always here,   While they are half the year at school;   And yet that neither is no rule.
10130-8{_}5323{_}I've nam'd them all, there's only seven;   I find my love to all so even,   To every sister, every brother,   I love not one more than another.
10130-8{_}5324{_}THE BEGGAR-MAN    Abject, stooping, old, and wan,   See yon wretched beggar man;   Once a father's hopeful heir,   Once a mother's tender care.
10130-8{_}5325{_}When too young to understand   He but scorch'd his little hand,   By the candle's flaming light   Attracted, dancing, spiral, bright,   Clasping fond her darling round,   A thousand kisses heal'd the wound.
10130-8{_}5326{_}Now abject, stooping, old, and wan,   No mother tends the beggar man.
10130-8{_}5327{_}Then nought too good for him to wear,   With cherub face and flaxen hair,   In fancy's choicest gauds array'd,   Cap of lace with rose to aid,   Milk-white hat and feather blue,   Shoes of red, and coral too   With silver bells to please his ear,   And charm the frequent ready tear.
10130-8{_}5328{_}Now abject, stooping, old, and wan,   Neglected is the beggar man.
10130-8{_}5329{_}See the boy advance in age,   And learning spreads her useful page;   In vain!
10130-8{_}5330{_}for giddy pleasure calls,   And shews the marbles, tops, and balls.
10130-8{_}5331{_}What's learning to the charms of play?
10130-8{_}5332{_}The indulgent tutor must give way.
10130-8{_}5333{_}A heedless wilful dunce, and wild,   The parents' fondness spoil'd the child;   The youth in vagrant courses ran;   Now abject, stooping, old, and wan,   Their fondling is the beggar man.
10130-8{_}5334{_}CHOOSING A PROFESSION    A Creole boy from the West Indies brought,   To be in European learning taught,   Some years before to Westminster he went,   To a Preparatory School was sent.
10130-8{_}5335{_}When from his artless tale the mistress found,   The child had not one friend on English ground,   She, ev'n as if she his own mother were,   Made the dark Indian her peculiar care.
10130-8{_}5336{_}Oft on her fav'rite's future lot she thought;   To know the bent of his young mind she sought,   For much the kind preceptress wish'd to find   To what profession he was most inclin'd,   That where his genius led they might him train;   For nature's kindly bent she held not vain.
10130-8{_}5337{_}But vain her efforts to explore his will;   The frequent question he evaded still:   Till on a day at length he to her came,   Joy sparkling in his eyes; and said, the same   Trade he would be those boys of colour were,   Who danc'd so happy in the open air.
10130-8{_}5338{_}It was a troop of chimney-sweeping boys,   With wooden music and obstrep'rous noise,   In tarnish'd finery and grotesque array,   Were dancing in the street the first of May.
10130-8{_}5339{_}BREAKFAST    A dinner party, coffee, tea,   Sandwich, or supper, all may be   In their way pleasant.
10130-8{_}5340{_}But to me   Not one of these deserves the praise   That welcomer of new-born days,   _A breakfast_, merits; ever giving   Cheerful notice we are living   Another day refresh'd by sleep,   When its festival we keep.
10130-8{_}5341{_}Now although I would not slight   Those kindly words we use "Good night,"   Yet parting words are words of sorrow,   And may not vie with sweet "Good morrow,"   With which again our friends we greet,   When in the breakfast-room we meet,   At the social table round,   Listening to the lively sound   Of those notes which never tire,   Of urn, or kettle on the fire.
10130-8{_}5342{_}Sleepy Robert never hears   Or urn, or kettle; he appears   When all have finish'd, one by one   Dropping off, and breakfast done.
10130-8{_}5343{_}Yet has he too his own pleasure,   His breakfast hour's his hour of leisure;   And, left alone, he reads or muses,   Or else in idle mood he uses   To sit and watch the vent'rous fly,   Where the sugar's piled high,   Clambering o'er the lumps so white,   Rocky cliffs of sweet delight.
10130-8{_}5344{_}WEEDING    As busy Aurelia, 'twixt work and 'twixt play,     Was lab'ring industriously hard   To cull the vile weeds from the flow'rets away,     Which grew in her father's court-yard;    In her juvenile anger, wherever she found,     She pluck'd, and she pull'd, and she tore;   The poor passive suff'rers bestrew'd all the ground;     Not a weed of them all she forbore.
10130-8{_}5345{_}At length 'twas her chance on some nettles to light     (Things, till then, she had scarcely heard nam'd);   The vulgar intruders call'd forth all her spite;     In a transport of rage she exclaim'd,    "Shall briars so unsightly and worthless as those     Their great sprawling leaves thus presume   To mix with the pink, the jonquil, and the rose,     And take up a flower's sweet room?"
10130-8{_}5346{_}On the odious offenders enraged she flew;     But she presently found to her cost   A tingling unlook'd for, a pain that was new,     And rage was in agony lost.
10130-8{_}5347{_}To her father she hastily fled for relief,     And told him her pain and her smart;   With kindly caresses he soothed her grief,     Then smiling he took the weed's part.
10130-8{_}5348{_}"The world, my Aurelia, this garden of ours     Resembles: too apt we're to deem   In the world's larger garden ourselves as the flow'rs,     And the poor but as weeds to esteem.
10130-8{_}5349{_}"But them if we rate, or with rudeness repel,     Though some will be passive enough,   From others who're more independent 'tis well     If we meet not a _stinging rebuff_."
10130-8{_}5350{_}PARENTAL RECOLLECTIONS    A child's a plaything for an hour;     Its pretty tricks we try   For that or for a longer space;     Then tire, and lay it by.
10130-8{_}5351{_}But I knew one, that to itself     All seasons could controul;   That would have mock'd the sense of pain     Out of a grieved soul.
10130-8{_}5352{_}Thou, straggler into loving arms,     Young climber up of knees,   When I forget thy thousand ways,     Then life and all shall cease.
10130-8{_}5353{_}THE TWO BOYS    I saw a boy with eager eye   Open a book upon a stall,   And read as he'd devour it all:   Which when the stall-man did espy,   Soon to the boy I heard him call,   "You, Sir, you never buy a book,   Therefore in one you shall not look."
10130-8{_}5354{_}The boy pass'd slowly on, and with a sigh   He wish'd he never had been taught to read,   Then of the old churl's books he should have had no need.
10130-8{_}5355{_}Of sufferings the poor have many,   Which never can the rich annoy.
10130-8{_}5356{_}I soon perceiv'd another boy   Who look'd as if he'd not had any   Food for that day at least, enjoy   The sight of cold meat in a tavern larder.
10130-8{_}5357{_}This boy's case, thought I, is surely harder,   Thus hungry longing, thus without a penny,   Beholding choice of dainty dressed meat:   No wonder if he wish he ne'er had learn'd to eat.
10130-8{_}5358{_}THE OFFER      "Tell me, would you rather be   Chang'd by a fairy to the fine   Young orphan heiress Geraldine,     Or still be Emily?
10130-8{_}5359{_}"Consider, ere you answer me,   How many blessings are procur'd   By riches, and how much endur'd     By chilling poverty."
10130-8{_}5360{_}After a pause, said Emily:   "In the words orphan heiress I   Find many a solid reason why     I would not changed be.
10130-8{_}5361{_}"What though I live in poverty,   And have of sisters eight--so many,   That few indulgences, if any,     Fall to the share of me;      "Think you that for wealth I'd be   Of ev'n the least of them bereft,   Or lose my parent, and be left     An orphan'd Emily?
10130-8{_}5362{_}"Still should I be Emily,   Although I look'd like Geraldine;   I feel within this heart of mine     No change could worked be."
10130-8{_}5363{_}THE SISTER'S EXPOSTULATION ON THE BROTHER'S LEARNING LATIN    Shut these odious books up, brother--   They have made you quite another   Thing from what you us'd to be--   Once you lik'd to play with me--   Now you leave me all alone,   And are so conceited grown   With your Latin, you'll scarce look   Upon any English book.
10130-8{_}5364{_}We had us'd on winter eyes   To con over Shakespeare's leaves,   Or on Milton's harder sense   Exercise our diligence--   And you would explain with ease   The obscurer passages,   Find me out the prettiest places   The poetic turns, and graces,   Which alas!
10130-8{_}5365{_}now you are gone,   I must puzzle out alone,   And oft miss the meaning quite,   Wanting you to set me right.
10130-8{_}5366{_}All this comes since you've been under   Your new master.
10130-8{_}5367{_}I much wonder   What great charm it is you see   In those words, _musa, musæ_;   Or in what they do excel   Our word, _song_.
10130-8{_}5368{_}It sounds as well   To my fancy as the other.
10130-8{_}5369{_}Now believe me, dearest brother,   I would give my finest frock,   And my cabinet, and stock   Of new playthings, every toy,   I would give them all with joy,   Could I you returning see   Back to English and to me.
10130-8{_}5370{_}THE BROTHER'S REPLY    Sister, fie, for shame, no more,   Give this ignorant babble o'er,   Nor with little female pride   Things above your sense deride.
10130-8{_}5371{_}Why this foolish under-rating   Of my first attempts at Latin?
10130-8{_}5372{_}Know you not each thing we prize   Does from small beginnings rise?
10130-8{_}5373{_}'Twas the same thing with your writing,   Which you now take such delight in.
10130-8{_}5374{_}First you learnt the down-stroke line,   Then the hair-stroke thin and fine,   Then a curve, and then a better,   Till you came to form a letter;   Then a new task was begun,   How to join them two in one;   Till you got (these first steps past)   To your fine text-hand at last.
10130-8{_}5375{_}So though I at first commence   With the humble accidence,   And my study's course affords   Little else as yet but words,   I shall venture in a while   At construction, grammar, style,   Learn my syntax, and proceed   Classic authors next to read,   Such as wiser, better, make us,   Sallust, Phædrus, Ovid, Flaccus:   All the poets (with their wit),   All the grave historians writ,   Who the lives and actions show   Of men famous long ago;   Ev'n their very sayings giving   In the tongue they us'd when living.
10130-8{_}5376{_}Think not I shall do that wrong   Either to my native tongue,   English authors to despise,   Or those books which you so prize;   Though from them awhile I stray,   By new studies call'd away,   Them when next I take in hand,   I shall better understand.
10130-8{_}5377{_}For I've heard wise men declare   Many words in English are   From the Latin tongue deriv'd,   Of whose sense girls are depriv'd   'Cause they do not Latin know.--   But if all this anger grow   From this cause, that you suspect   By proceedings indirect,   I would keep (as misers pelf)   All this learning to myself;   Sister, to remove this doubt,   Rather than we will fall out,   (If our parents will agree)   You shall Latin learn with me.
10130-8{_}5378{_}NURSE GREEN    "Your prayers you have said, and you've wished Good night:     What cause is there yet keeps my darling awake?
10130-8{_}5379{_}This throb in your bosom proclaims some affright     Disturbs your composure.
10130-8{_}5380{_}Can innocence quake?
10130-8{_}5381{_}"Why thus do you cling to my neck, and enfold me,     What fear unimparted your quiet devours?"
10130-8{_}5382{_}"O mother, there's reason--for Susan has told me,     A dead body lies in the room next to ours."
10130-8{_}5383{_}"I know it; and, but for forgetfulness, dear,     I meant you the coffin this day should have seen,   And read the inscription, and told me the year     And day of the death of your poor old Nurse Green."
10130-8{_}5384{_}"O not for the wealth of the world would I enter     A chamber wherein a dead body lay hid,   Lest somebody bolder than I am should venture     To go near the coffin and lift up the lid."
10130-8{_}5385{_}"And should they do so and the coffin uncover,     The corpse underneath it would be no ill sight;   This frame, when its animal functions are over,     Has nothing of horror the living to fright.
10130-8{_}5386{_}"To start at the dead is preposterous error,     To shrink from a foe that can never contest;   Shall that which is motionless move thee to terror;     Or thou become restless, 'cause they are at rest?
10130-8{_}5387{_}"To think harm of her our good feelings forbid us     By whom when a babe you were dandled and fed;   Who living so many good offices did us,     I ne'er can persuade me would hurt us when dead.
10130-8{_}5388{_}"But if no endeavour your terrors can smother,     If vainly against apprehension you strive,   Come, bury your fears in the arms of your mother;     My darling, cling close to me, I am alive."
10130-8{_}5389{_}GOOD TEMPER    In whatsoever place resides   Good Temper, she o'er all presides;   The most obdurate heart she guides.
10130-8{_}5390{_}Even Anger yields unto her power,   And sullen Spite forgets to lour,   Or reconciled weeps a shower;    Reserve she softens into Ease,   Makes Fretfulness leave off to teaze,   She Waywardness itself can please.
10130-8{_}5391{_}Her handmaids they are not a few:   Sincerity that's ever true,   And Prompt Obedience always new,    Urbanity that ever smiles,   And Frankness that ne'er useth wiles,   And Friendliness that ne'er beguiles,    And Firmness that is always ready   To make young good-resolves more steady,   The only safeguard of the giddy;    And blushing Modesty, and sweet   Humility in fashion neat;   Yet still her train is incomplete,    Unless meek Piety attend   Good Temper as her surest friend,   Abiding with her to the end.
10130-8{_}5392{_}MODERATION IN DIET    The drunkard's sin, excess in wine,     Which reason drowns, and health destroys,   As yet no failing is of thine,     Dear Jim; strong drink's not given to boys.
10130-8{_}5393{_}You from the cool fresh steam allay     Those thirsts which sultry suns excite;   When choak'd with dust, or hot with play,     A cup of water yields delight.
10130-8{_}5394{_}And reverence still that temperate cup,     And cherish long the blameless taste;   To learn the faults of men grown up,     Dear Jim, be wise and do not haste.
10130-8{_}5395{_}They'll come too soon.--But there's a vice,     That shares the world's contempt no less;   To be in eating over-nice,     Or to court surfeits by excess.
10130-8{_}5396{_}The first, as finical, avoid;     The last is proper to a swine:   By temperance meat is best enjoy'd;     Think of this maxim when you dine.
10130-8{_}5397{_}Prefer with plain food to be fed,     Rather than what are dainties styl'd;   A sweet tooth in an infant's head     Is pardon'd, not in a grown child.
10130-8{_}5398{_}If parent, aunt, or liberal friend,     With splendid shilling line your purse,   Do not the same on sweetmeats spend,     Nor appetite with pampering nurse.
10130-8{_}5399{_}Go buy a book; a dainty eaten     Is vanish'd, and no sweets remain;   They who their minds with knowledge sweeten,     The savour long as life retain.
10130-8{_}5400{_}Purchase some toy, a horse of wood,     A pasteboard ship; their structure scan;   Their mimic uses understood,     The school-boy make a kind of man.
10130-8{_}5401{_}Go see some show; pictures or prints;     Or beasts far brought from Indian land;   Those foreign sights oft furnish hints,     That may the youthful mind expand.
10130-8{_}5402{_}And something of your store impart,     To feed the poor and hungry soul;   What buys for you the needless tart,     May purchase him a needful roll.
10130-8{_}5403{_}INCORRECT SPEAKING    Incorrectness in your speech     Carefully avoid, my Anna;   Study well the sense of each     Sentence, lest in any manner   It misrepresent the truth;   Veracity's the charm of youth.
10130-8{_}5404{_}You will not, I know, tell lies,     If you know what you are speaking.--   Truth is shy, and from us flies;     Unless diligently seeking   Into every word we pry,   Falsehood will her place supply.
10130-8{_}5405{_}Falsehood is not shy, not she,--     Ever ready to take place of   Truth, too oft we Falsehood see,     Or at least some latent trace of   Falsehood, in the incorrect   Words of those who Truth respect.
10130-8{_}5406{_}CHARITY    O why your good deeds with such pride do you scan,     And why that self-satisfied smile   At the shilling you gave to the poor working man,     That lifted you over the stile?
10130-8{_}5407{_}'Tis not much; all the bread that can with it be bought     Will scarce give a morsel to each   Of his eight hungry children;--reflection and thought     Should you more humility teach.
10130-8{_}5408{_}Vain glory's a worm which the very best action     Will taint, and its soundness eat thro';   But to give one's self airs for a small benefaction,     Is folly and vanity too.
10130-8{_}5409{_}The money perhaps by your father or mother     Was furnish'd you but with that view;   If so, you were only the steward of another,     And the praise you usurp is their due.
10130-8{_}5410{_}Perhaps every shilling you give in this way     Is paid back with two by your friends;   Then the bounty you so ostentatious display,     Has little and low selfish ends.
10130-8{_}5411{_}But if every penny you gave were your own,     And giving diminish'd your purse;   By a child's slender means think how little is done,     And how little for it you're the worse.
10130-8{_}5412{_}You eat, and you drink; when you rise in the morn,     You are cloth'd; you have health and content;   And you never have known, from the day you were born,     What hunger or nakedness meant.
10130-8{_}5413{_}The most which your bounty from you can subtract     Is an apple, a sweetmeat, a toy;   For so easy a virtue, so trifling an act,     You are paid with an innocent joy.
10130-8{_}5414{_}Give thy bread to the hungry, the thirsty thy cup;     Divide with th' afflicted thy lot:   This can only be practis'd by persons grown up,     Who've possessions which children have not.
10130-8{_}5415{_}Having two cloaks, give one (said our Lord) to the poor;     In such bounty as that lies the trial:   But a child that gives half of its infantile store     Has small praise, because small self-denial.
10130-8{_}5416{_}MY BIRTH-DAY    A dozen years since in this house what commotion,     What bustle, what stir, and what joyful ado;   Ev'ry soul in the family at my devotion,     When into the world I came twelve years ago.
10130-8{_}5417{_}I've been told by my friends (if they do not belie me)     My promise was such as no parent would scorn;   The wise and the aged who prophesied by me,     Augur'd nothing but good of me when I was born.
10130-8{_}5418{_}But vain are the hopes which are form'd by a parent,     Fallacious the marks which in infancy shine;   My frail constitution soon made it apparent,     I nourish'd within me the seeds of decline.
10130-8{_}5419{_}On a sick bed I lay, through the flesh my bones started,     My grief-wasted frame to a skeleton fell;   My physicians foreboding took leave and departed,     And they wish'd me dead now, who wished me well.
10130-8{_}5420{_}Life and soul were kept in by a mother's assistance,     Who struggled with faith, and prevail'd 'gainst despair;   Like an angel she watch'd o'er the lamp of existence,     And never would leave while a glimmer was there.
10130-8{_}5421{_}By her care I'm alive now--but what retribution     Can I for a life twice bestow'd thus confer?
10130-8{_}5422{_}Were I to be silent, each year's revolution     Proclaims--each new birth-day is owing to her.
10130-8{_}5423{_}The chance-rooted tree that by way-sides is planted,     Where no friendly hand will watch o'er its young shoots,   Has less blame if in autumn, when produce is wanted,     Enrich'd by small culture it put forth small fruits.
10130-8{_}5424{_}But that which with labour in hot-beds is reared,     Secur'd by nice art from the dews and the rains,   Unsound at the root may with justice be feared,     If it pay not with int'rest the tiller's hard pains.
10130-8{_}5425{_}THE BEASTS IN THE TOWER    Within the precincts of this yard,   Each in his narrow confines barr'd,   Dwells every beast that can be found   On Afric or on Indian ground.
10130-8{_}5426{_}How different was the life they led   In those wild haunts where they were bred,   To this tame servitude and fear,   Enslav'd by man, they suffer here!
10130-8{_}5427{_}In that uneasy close recess   Couches a sleeping Lioness;   The next den holds a Bear; the next   A Wolf, by hunger ever vext;   There, fiercer from the keeper's lashes,   His teeth the fell Hyena gnashes;   That creature on whose back abound   Black spots upon a yellow ground,   A Panther is, the fairest beast   That haunteth in the spacious East.
10130-8{_}5428{_}He underneath a fair outside   Does cruelty and treach'ry hide.
10130-8{_}5429{_}That cat-like beast that to and fro   Restless as fire does ever go,   As if his courage did resent   His limbs in such confinement pent,   That should their prey in forests take,   And make the Indian jungles quake,   A Tiger is.
10130-8{_}5430{_}Observe how sleek   And glossy smooth his coat: no streak   On sattin ever match'd the pride   Of that which marks his furry hide.
10130-8{_}5431{_}How strong his muscles!
10130-8{_}5432{_}he with ease   Upon the tallest man could seize,   In his large mouth away could bear him,   And into thousand pieces tear him:   Yet cabin'd so securely here,   The smallest infant need not fear.
10130-8{_}5433{_}That lordly creature next to him   A Lion is.
10130-8{_}5434{_}Survey each limb.
10130-8{_}5435{_}Observe the texture of his claws,   The massy thickness of those jaws;   His mane that sweeps the ground in length,   Like Samson's locks, betok'ning strength.
10130-8{_}5436{_}In force and swiftness he excels   Each beast that in the forest dwells;   The savage tribes him king confess   Throughout the howling wilderness.
10130-8{_}5437{_}Woe to the hapless neighbourhood,   When he is press'd by want of food!
10130-8{_}5438{_}Of man, or child, of bull, or horse,   He makes his prey; such is his force.
10130-8{_}5439{_}A waste behind him he creates,   Whole villages depopulates.
10130-8{_}5440{_}Yet here within appointed lines   How small a grate his rage confines!
10130-8{_}5441{_}This place methinks resembleth well   The world itself in which we dwell.
10130-8{_}5442{_}Perils and snares on every ground   Like these wild beasts beset us round.
10130-8{_}5443{_}But Providence their rage restrains,   Our heavenly Keeper sets them chains;   His goodness saveth every hour   His darlings from the Lion's power.
10130-8{_}5444{_}THE CONFIDANT    Anna was always full of thought     As if she'd many sorrows known,   Yet mostly her full heart was fraught     With troubles that were not her own;   For the whole school to Anna us'd to tell   Whatever small misfortunes unto them befell.
10130-8{_}5445{_}And being so by all belov'd,     That all into her bosom pour'd   Their dearest secrets, she was mov'd     To pity all--her heart a hoard,   Or storehouse, by this means became for all   The sorrows can to girls of tender age befall.
10130-8{_}5446{_}Though individually not much     Distress throughout the school prevail'd,   Yet as she shar'd it all, 'twas such     A weight of woe that her assail'd,   She lost her colour, loath'd her food, and grew   So dull, that all their confidence from her withdrew.
10130-8{_}5447{_}Released from her daily care,     No longer list'ning to complaint,   She seems to breathe a different air,     And health once more her cheek does paint.
10130-8{_}5448{_}Still Anna loves her friends, but will not hear   Again their list of grievances which cost so dear.
10130-8{_}5449{_}THOUGHTLESS CRUELTY    There, Robert, you have kill'd that fly--   And should you thousand ages try   The life you've taken to supply,       You could not do it.
10130-8{_}5450{_}You surely must have been devoid   Of thought and sense, to have destroy'd   A thing which no way you annoy'd--       You'll one day rue it.
10130-8{_}5451{_}'Twas but a fly perhaps you'll say,   That's born in April, dies in May;   That does but just learn to display       His wings one minute,    And in the next is vanish'd quite.
10130-8{_}5452{_}A bird devours it in his flight--   Or come a cold blast in the night,       There's no breath in it.
10130-8{_}5453{_}The bird but seeks his proper food--   And Providence, whose power endu'd   That fly with life, when it thinks good,       May justly take it.
10130-8{_}5454{_}But you have no excuses for't--   A life by Nature made so short,   Less reason is that you for sport       Should shorter make it.
10130-8{_}5455{_}A fly a little thing you rate--   But, Robert, do not estimate   A creature's pain by small or great;       The greatest being    Can have but fibres, nerves, and flesh,   And these the smallest ones possess,   Although their frame and structure less       Escape our seeing.
10130-8{_}5456{_}EYES    Lucy, what do you espy   In the cast in Jenny's eye   That should you to laughter move?
10130-8{_}5457{_}I far other feelings prove.
10130-8{_}5458{_}When on me she does advance   Her good-natur'd countenance,   And those eyes which in their way   Saying much, so much would say,   They to me no blemish seem,   Or as none I them esteem;   I their imperfection prize   Above other clearer eyes.
10130-8{_}5459{_}Eyes do not as jewels go   By the brightness and the show,   But the meanings which surround them,   And the sweetness shines around them.
10130-8{_}5460{_}Isabel's are black as jet,   But she cannot that forget,   And the pains she takes to show them   Robs them of the praise we owe them.
10130-8{_}5461{_}Ann's, though blue, affected fall;   Kate's are bright, but fierce withal;   And the sparklers of her sister   From ill-humour lose their lustre.
10130-8{_}5462{_}Only Jenny's eyes we see,   By their very plainness, free   From the vices which do smother   All the beauties of the other.
10130-8{_}5463{_}PENNY PIECES      "I keep it, dear Papa, within my glove."
10130-8{_}5464{_}"You do--what sum then usually, my love,   Is there deposited?
10130-8{_}5465{_}I make no doubt,   Some Penny Pieces you are not without."
10130-8{_}5466{_}"O no, Papa, they'd soil my glove, and be   Quite odious things to carry.
10130-8{_}5467{_}O no--see,   This little bit of gold is surely all   That I shall want; for I shall only call   For a small purchase I shall make, Papa,   And a mere trifle I'm to buy Mamma,   Just to make out the change: so there's no need   To carry Penny Pieces, Sir, indeed."
10130-8{_}5468{_}"O now I know then why a blind man said   Unto a dog which this blind beggar led,--   'Where'er you see some fine young ladies, Tray,   Be sure you lead me quite another way.
10130-8{_}5469{_}The poor man's friend fair ladies us'd to be;   But now I find no tale of misery   Will ever from their pockets draw a penny.'
10130-8{_}5470{_}--   The blind man did not see _they wear not any_."
10130-8{_}5471{_}THE RAINBOW    After the tempest in the sky   How sweet yon Rainbow to the eye!
10130-8{_}5472{_}Come, my Matilda, now while some   Few drops of rain are yet to come,   In this honeysuckle bower   Safely shelter'd from the shower,   We may count the colours o'er.--   Seven there are, there are no more;   Each in each so finely blended,   Where they begin, or where are ended,   The finest eye can scarcely see.
10130-8{_}5473{_}A fixed thing it seems to be;   But, while we speak, see how it glides   Away, and now observe it hides   Half of its perfect arch--now we   Scarce any part of it can see.
10130-8{_}5474{_}What is colour?
10130-8{_}5475{_}If I were   A natural philosopher,   I would tell you what does make   This meteor every colour take:   But an unlearned eye may view   Nature's rare sights, and love them too.
10130-8{_}5476{_}Whenever I a Rainbow see,   Each precious tint is dear to me;   For every colour find I there,   Which flowers, which fields, which ladies wear;   My favourite green, the grass's hue,   And the fine deep violet-blue,   And the pretty pale blue-bell,   And the rose I love so well,   All the wondrous variations   Of the tulip, pinks, carnations,   This woodbine here both flower and leaf;--   'Tis a truth that's past belief,   That every flower and every tree,   And every living thing we see,   Every face which we espy,   Every cheek and every eye,   In all their tints, in every shade,   Are from the Rainbow's colours made.
10130-8{_}5477{_}THE FORCE OF HABIT    A little child, who had desired   To go and see the Park guns fired,   Was taken by his maid that way   Upon the next rejoicing day.
10130-8{_}5478{_}Soon as the unexpected stroke   Upon his tender organs broke,   Confus'd and stunn'd at the report,   He to her arms fled for support,   And begg'd to be convey'd at once   Out of the noise of those great guns,   Those naughty guns, whose only sound   Would kill (he said) without a wound:   So much of horror and offence   The shock had giv'n his infant sense.
10130-8{_}5479{_}Yet this was He in after days   Who fill'd the world with martial praise,   When from the English quarter-deck   His steady courage sway'd the wreck   Of hostile fleets, disturb'd no more   By all that vast conflicting roar,   That sky and sea did seem to tear,   When vessels whole blew up in air,   Than at the smallest breath that heaves,   When Zephyr hardly stirs the leaves.
10130-8{_}5480{_}CLOCK STRIKING    Did I hear the church-clock a few minutes ago,   I was ask'd, and I answer'd, I hardly did know,     But I thought that I heard it strike three.
10130-8{_}5481{_}Said my friend then, "The blessings we always possess   We know not the want of, and prize them the less;     The church-clock was no new sound to thee.
10130-8{_}5482{_}"A young woman, afflicted with deafness a year,   By that sound you scarce heard, first perceiv'd she could _hear;_     I was near her, and saw the girl start   With such exquisite wonder, such feelings of pride,   A happiness almost to terror allied,     She shew'd the sound went to her heart."
10130-8{_}5483{_}WHY NOT DO IT, SIR, TO-DAY?
10130-8{_}5484{_}"Why so I will, you noisy bird,       This very day I'll advertise you,       Perhaps some busy ones may prize you.
10130-8{_}5485{_}A fine-tongu'd parrot as was ever heard,   I'll word it thus--set forth all charms about you,   And say no family should be without you."
10130-8{_}5486{_}Thus far a gentleman address'd a bird,   Then to his friend: "An old procrastinator,   Sir, I am: do you wonder that I hate her?
10130-8{_}5487{_}Though she but seven words can say,     Twenty and twenty times a day     She interferes with all my dreams,     My projects, plans, and airy schemes,     Mocking my foible to my sorrow:     I'll advertise this bird to-morrow."
10130-8{_}5488{_}To this the bird seven words did say:     "Why not do it, Sir, to-day?"
10130-8{_}5489{_}HOME DELIGHTS    To operas and balls my cousins take me,   And fond of plays my new-made friend would make me.
10130-8{_}5490{_}In summer season, when the days are fair,   In my godmother's coach I take the air.
10130-8{_}5491{_}My uncle has a stately pleasure barge,   Gilded and gay, adorn'd with wondrous charge;   The mast is polish'd, and the sails are fine,   The awnings of white silk like silver shine;   The seats of crimson sattin, where the rowers   Keep time to music with their painted oars;   In this on holydays we oft resort   To Richmond, Twickenham, or to Hampton Court.
10130-8{_}5492{_}By turns we play, we sing--one baits the hook,   Another angles--some more idle look   At the small fry that sport beneath the tides,   Or at the swan that on the surface glides.
10130-8{_}5493{_}My married sister says there is no feast   Equal to sight of foreign bird or beast.
10130-8{_}5494{_}With her in search of these I often roam:   My kinder parents make me blest at home.
10130-8{_}5495{_}Tir'd of excursions, visitings, and sights,   No joys are pleasing to these home delights.
10130-8{_}5496{_}THE COFFEE SLIPS    Whene'er I fragrant coffee drink,   I on the generous Frenchman think,   Whose noble perseverance bore   The tree to Martinico's shore.
10130-8{_}5497{_}While yet her colony was new,   Her island products but a few,   Two shoots from off a coffee-tree   He carried with him o'er the sea.
10130-8{_}5498{_}Each little tender coffee slip   He waters daily in the ship,   And as he tends his embryo trees,   Feels he is raising midst the seas   Coffee groves, whose ample shade   Shall screen the dark Creolian maid.
10130-8{_}5499{_}But soon, alas!
10130-8{_}5500{_}his darling pleasure   In watching this his precious treasure   Is like to fade,--for water fails   On board the ship in which he sails.
10130-8{_}5501{_}Now all the reservoirs are shut,   The crew on short allowance put;   So small a drop is each man's share,   Few leavings you may think there are   To water these poor coffee plants;--   But he supplies their gasping wants,   Ev'n from his own dry parched lips   He spares it for his coffee slips.
10130-8{_}5502{_}Water he gives his nurslings first,   Ere he allays his own deep thirst;   Lest, if he first the water sip,   He bear too far his eager lip.
10130-8{_}5503{_}He sees them droop for want of more;--   Yet when they reached the destin'd shore,   With pride th' heroic gardener sees   A living sap still in his trees.
10130-8{_}5504{_}The islanders his praise resound;   Coffee plantations rise around;   And Martinico loads her ships   With produce from those dear-sav'd slips.
10130-8{_}5505{_}[1]  [Footnote 1: The name of this man was Desclieux, and the story is to be found in the Abbé Raynal's History of the Settlements and Trade of the Europeans in the East and West Indies, book XIII.]
10130-8{_}5506{_}THE DESSERT    With the apples and the plums   Little Carolina comes,   At the time of the dessert she   Comes and drops her new last curt'sy;   Graceful curt'sy, practis'd o'er   In the nursery before.
10130-8{_}5507{_}What shall we compare her to?
10130-8{_}5508{_}The dessert itself will do.
10130-8{_}5509{_}Like preserves she's kept with care,   Like blanch'd almonds she is fair,   Soft as down on peach her hair,   And so soft, so smooth is each   Pretty cheek as that same peach,   Yet more like in hue to cherries;   Then her lips, the sweet strawberries,   Caroline herself shall try them   If they are not like when nigh them;   Her bright eyes are black as sloes,   But I think we've none of those   Common fruit here--and her chin   From a round point does begin,   Like the small end of a pear;   Whiter drapery she does wear   Than the frost on cake; and sweeter   Than the cake itself, and neater,   Though bedeck'd with emblems fine,   Is our little Caroline.
10130-8{_}5510{_}TO A YOUNG LADY, ON BEING TOO FOND OF MUSIC    Why is your mind thus all day long     Upon your music set;   Till reason's swallow'd in a song,     Or idle canzonet?
10130-8{_}5511{_}I grant you, Melesinda, when     Your instrument was new,   I was well pleas'd to see you then     Its charms assiduous woo.
10130-8{_}5512{_}The rudiments of any art     Or mast'ry that we try,   Are only on the learner's part     Got by hard industry.
10130-8{_}5513{_}But you are past your first essays;     Whene'er you play, your touch,   Skilful, and light, ensures you praise:     All beyond that's too much.
10130-8{_}5514{_}Music's sweet uses are, to smooth     Each rough and angry passion;   To elevate at once, and soothe:     A heavenly recreation.
10130-8{_}5515{_}But we misconstrue, and defeat     The end of any good;   When what should be our casual treat,     We make our constant food.
10130-8{_}5516{_}While, to th' exclusion of the rest,     This single art you ply,   Your nobler studies are supprest,     Your books neglected lie.
10130-8{_}5517{_}Could you in what you so affect     The utmost summit reach;   Beyond what fondest friends expect,     Or skilful'st masters teach:    The skill you learn'd would not repay     The time and pains it cost,   Youth's precious season thrown away,     And reading-leisure lost.
10130-8{_}5518{_}A benefit to books we owe,     Music can ne'er dispense;   The one does only _sound_ bestow,     The other gives us _sense_.
10130-8{_}5519{_}TIME SPENT IN DRESS    In many a lecture, many a book,     You all have heard, you all have read,   That time is precious.
10130-8{_}5520{_}Of its use     Much has been written, much been said.
10130-8{_}5521{_}The accomplishments which gladden life,     As music, drawing, dancing, are   Encroachers on our precious time;     Their praise or dispraise I forbear.
10130-8{_}5522{_}They should be practis'd or forborne,     As parents wish, or friends desire:   What rests alone in their own will     Is all I of the young require.
10130-8{_}5523{_}There's not a more productive source     Of waste of time to the young mind   Than dress; as it regards our hours     My view of it is now confin'd.
10130-8{_}5524{_}Without some calculation, youth     May live to age and never guess,   That no one study they pursue     Takes half the time they give to dress.
10130-8{_}5525{_}Write in your memorandum-book     The time you at your toilette spend;   Then every moment which you pass,     Talking of dress with a young friend:    And ever when your silent thoughts     Have on this subject been intent,   Set down as nearly as you can     How long on dress your thoughts were bent.
10130-8{_}5526{_}If faithfully you should perform     This task, 'twould teach you to repair   Lost hours, by giving unto dress     Not more of time than its due share.
10130-8{_}5527{_}THE FAIRY    Said Ann to Matilda, "I wish that we knew   If what we've been reading of fairies be true.
10130-8{_}5528{_}Do you think that the poet himself had a sight of   The fairies he here does so prettily write of?
10130-8{_}5529{_}O what a sweet sight if he really had seen   The graceful Titania, the Fairy-land Queen!
10130-8{_}5530{_}If I had such dreams, I would sleep a whole year;   I would not wish to wake while a fairy was near.--   Now I'll fancy that I in my sleep have been seeing   A fine little delicate lady-like being,   Whose steps and whose motions so light were and airy,   I knew at one glance that she must be a fairy.
10130-8{_}5531{_}Her eyes they were blue, and her fine curling hair   Of the lightest of browns, her complexion more fair   Than I e'er saw a woman's; and then for her height,   I verily think that she measur'd not quite   Two feet, yet so justly proportion'd withal,   I was almost persuaded to think she was tall.
10130-8{_}5532{_}Her voice was the little thin note of a sprite--   There--d'ye think I have made out a fairy aright?
10130-8{_}5533{_}You'll confess, I believe, I've not done it amiss."
10130-8{_}5534{_}"Pardon me," said Matilda, "I find in all this   Fine description, you've only your young sister Mary   Been taking a copy of here for a fairy."
10130-8{_}5535{_}CONQUEST OF PREJUDICE    Unto a Yorkshire school was sent     A Negro youth to learn to write,   And the first day young Juba went     All gaz'd on him as a rare sight.
10130-8{_}5536{_}But soon with alter'd looks askance     They view his sable face and form,   When they perceive the scornful glance     Of the head boy, young Henry Orme.
10130-8{_}5537{_}He in the school was first in fame:     Said he, "It does to me appear   To be a great disgrace and shame     A black should be admitted here."
10130-8{_}5538{_}His words were quickly whisper'd round,     And every boy now looks offended;   The master saw the change, and found     That Orme a mutiny intended.
10130-8{_}5539{_}Said he to Orme, "This African     It seems is not by you approv'd;   I'll find a way, young Englishman,     To have this prejudice remov'd.
10130-8{_}5540{_}"Nearer acquaintance possibly     May make you tolerate his hue;   At least 'tis my intent to try     What a short month may chance to do."
10130-8{_}5541{_}Young Orme and Juba then he led     Into a room, in which there were   For each of the two boys a bed,     A table, and a wicker chair.
10130-8{_}5542{_}He lock'd them in, secur'd the key,     That all access to them was stopt;   They from without can nothing see;     Their food is through a sky-light dropt.
10130-8{_}5543{_}A month in this lone chamber Orme     Is sentenc'd during all that time   To view no other face or form     Than Juba's parch'd by Afric clime.
10130-8{_}5544{_}One word they neither of them spoke     The first three days of the first week;   On the fourth day the ice was broke;     Orme was the first that deign'd to speak.
10130-8{_}5545{_}The dreary silence o'er, both glad     To hear of human voice the sound,   The Negro and the English lad     Comfort in mutual converse found.
10130-8{_}5546{_}Of ships and seas, and foreign coast,     Juba can speak, for he has been   A voyager: and Orme can boast     He London's famous town has seen.
10130-8{_}5547{_}In eager talk they pass the day,     And borrow hours ev'n from the night;   So pleasantly time past away,     That they have lost their reckoning quite.
10130-8{_}5548{_}And when their master set them free,     They thought a week was sure remitted,   And thank'd him that their liberty     Had been before the time permitted.
10130-8{_}5549{_}Now Orme and Juba are good friends;     The school, by Orme's example won,   Contend who most shall make amends     For former slights to Afric's son.
10130-8{_}5550{_}THE GREAT GRANDFATHER    My father's grandfather lives still,     His age is fourscore years and ten;   He looks a monument of time,     The agedest of aged men.
10130-8{_}5551{_}Though years lie on him like a load,     A happier man you will not see   Than he, whenever he can get     His great grand-children on his knee.
10130-8{_}5552{_}When we our parents have displeas'd,     He stands between us as a screen;   By him our good deeds in the sun,     Our bad ones in the shade are seen.
10130-8{_}5553{_}His love's a line that's long drawn out,     Yet lasteth firm unto the end;   His heart is oak, yet unto us     It like the gentlest reed can bend.
10130-8{_}5554{_}A fighting soldier he has been--     Yet by his manners you would guess,   That he his whole long life had spent     In scenes of country quietness.
10130-8{_}5555{_}His talk is all of things long past,     For modern facts no pleasure yield--   Of the fam'd year of forty-five,     Of William, and Culloden's field.
10130-8{_}5556{_}The deeds of this eventful age,     Which princes from their thrones have hurl'd,   Can no more interest wake in him     Than stories of another world.
10130-8{_}5557{_}When I his length of days revolve,     How like a strong tree he hath stood,   It brings into my mind almost     Those patriarchs old before the flood.
10130-8{_}5558{_}THE SPARTAN BOY    When I the memory repeat   Of the heroic actions great,   Which, in contempt of pain and death,   Were done by men who drew their breath   In ages past, I find no deed   That can in fortitude exceed   The noble Boy, in Sparta bred,   Who in the temple minist'red.
10130-8{_}5559{_}By the sacrifice he stands,   The lighted incense in his hands.
10130-8{_}5560{_}Through the smoking censer's lid   Dropp'd a burning coal, which slid   Into his sleeve, and passed in   Between the folds ev'n to the skin.
10130-8{_}5561{_}Dire was the pain which then he prov'd;   But not for this his sleeve he mov'd,   Or would the scorching ember shake   Out from the folds, lest it should make   Any confusion, or excite   Disturbance at the sacred rite.
10130-8{_}5562{_}But close he kept the burning coal,   Till it eat itself a hole   In his flesh.
10130-8{_}5563{_}The slanders by   Saw no sign, and heard no cry,   Of his pangs had no discerning,   Till they smell'd the flesh aburning   All this he did in noble scorn,   And for he was a Spartan born.
10130-8{_}5564{_}Young student, who this story readest,   And with the same thy thoughts now feedest,   Thy weaker nerves might thee forbid   To do the thing the Spartan did;   Thy feebler heart could not sustain   Such dire extremity of pain.
10130-8{_}5565{_}But in this story thou mayst see,   What may useful prove to thee.
10130-8{_}5566{_}By his example thou wilt find,   That to the ingenuous mind   Shame can greater anguish bring   Than the body's suffering;   That pain is not the worst of ills,   Not when it the body kills;   That in fair religion's cause,   For thy country, or the laws,   When occasion due shall offer   'Tis reproachful _not to suffer._   If thou shouldst a soldier be,   And a wound should trouble thee,   If without the soldier's fame   Thou to chance shouldst owe a maim,   Do not for a little pain   On thy manhood bring a stain;   But to keep thy spirits whole,   Think on the Spartan and the _coal._   QUEEN ORIANA'S DREAM  (_Text of 1818_)    On a bank with roses shaded,   Whose sweet scent the violets aided,   Violets whose breath alone   Yields but feeble smell or none,   (Sweeter bed Jove ne'er repos'd on   When his eyes Olympus closed on,)   While o'er head six slaves did hold   Canopy of cloth o' gold,   And two more did music keep,   Which might Juno lull to sleep,   Oriana who was queen   To the mighty Tamerlane,   That was lord of all the land   Between Thrace and Samarchand,   While the noon-tide fervor beam'd,   Mused herself to sleep, and _dream'd_.
10130-8{_}5567{_}Thus far, in magnific strain,   A young poet sooth'd his vein,   But he had nor prose nor numbers   To express a princess' slumbers.--   Youthful Richard had strange fancies,   Was deep versed in old romances,   And could talk whole hours upon   The great Cham and Prester John,--   Tell the field in which the Sophi   From the Tartar won a trophy--   What he read with such delight of,   Thought he could as eas'ly write of--   But his over-young invention   Kept not pace with brave intention.
10130-8{_}5568{_}Twenty suns did rise and set,   And he could no further get;   But, unable to proceed,   Made a virtue out of need,   And, his labours wiselier deem'd of,   Did omit _what the queen dream'd of._   ON A PICTURE OF THE FINDING OF MOSES BY PHARAOH'S DAUGHTER    This Picture does the story express   Of Moses in the Bulrushes.
10130-8{_}5569{_}How livelily the painter's hand   By colours makes us understand!
10130-8{_}5570{_}Moses that little infant is.
10130-8{_}5571{_}This figure is his sister.
10130-8{_}5572{_}This   Fine stately lady is no less   A personage than a princess,   Daughter of Pharaoh, Egypt's king;   Whom Providence did hither bring   This little Hebrew child to save.
10130-8{_}5573{_}See how near the perilous wave   He lies exposed in the ark,   His rushy cradle, his frail bark!
10130-8{_}5574{_}Pharaoh, king of Egypt land,   In his greatness gave command   To his slaves, they should destroy   Every new-born Hebrew boy.
10130-8{_}5575{_}This Moses was an Hebrew's son.
10130-8{_}5576{_}When he was born, his birth to none   His mother told, to none reveal'd,   But kept her goodly child conceal'd.
10130-8{_}5577{_}Three months she hid him; then she wrought   With Bulrushes this ark, and brought   Him in it to this river's side,   Carefully looking far and wide   To see that no Egyptian eye   Her ark-hid treasure should espy.
10130-8{_}5578{_}Among the river-flags she lays   The child.
10130-8{_}5579{_}Near him his sister stays.
10130-8{_}5580{_}We may imagine her affright,   When the king's daughter is in sight.
10130-8{_}5581{_}Soon the princess will perceive   The ark among the flags, and give   Command to her attendant maid   That its contents shall be display'd.
10130-8{_}5582{_}Within the ark the child is found,   And now he utters mournful sound.
10130-8{_}5583{_}Behold he weeps, as if he were   Afraid of cruel Egypt's heir!
10130-8{_}5584{_}She speaks, she says, "This little one   I will protect, though he the son   Be of an Hebrew."
10130-8{_}5585{_}Every word   She speaks is by the sister heard.
10130-8{_}5586{_}And now observe, this is the part   The painter chose to show his art.
10130-8{_}5587{_}Look at the sister's eager eye,   As here she seems advancing nigh.
10130-8{_}5588{_}Lowly she bends, says, "Shall I go   And call a nurse to thee?
10130-8{_}5589{_}I know   A Hebrew woman liveth near,   Great lady, shall I bring her here?"
10130-8{_}5590{_}See!
10130-8{_}5591{_}Pharaoh's daughter answers, "Go."
10130-8{_}5592{_}--   No more the painter's art can show.
10130-8{_}5593{_}He cannot make his figures move.--   On the light wings of swiftest love   The girl will fly to bring the mother   To be the nurse, she'll bring no other.
10130-8{_}5594{_}To her will Pharaoh's daughter say,   "Take this child from me away:   For wages nurse him.
10130-8{_}5595{_}To my home   At proper age this child may come.
10130-8{_}5596{_}When to our palace he is brought,   Wise masters shall for him be sought   To train him up, befitting one   I would protect as my own son.
10130-8{_}5597{_}And Moses be a name unto him,   Because I from the waters drew him."
10130-8{_}5598{_}DAVID    It is not always to the strong   Victorious battle shall belong.
10130-8{_}5599{_}This found Goliath huge and tall:   Mightiest giant of them all,   Who in the proud Philistian host   Defied Israel with boast.
10130-8{_}5600{_}With loud voice Goliath said:   "Hear, armed Israel, gathered,   And in array against us set:   Ye shall alone by me be met.
10130-8{_}5601{_}For am not I a Philistine?
10130-8{_}5602{_}What strength may be compar'd to mine?
10130-8{_}5603{_}"Chuse ye a man of greatest might:   And if he conquer me in fight,   Then we will all servants be,   King of Israel, unto thee.
10130-8{_}5604{_}But if I prove the victor, then   Shall Saul and all his armed men   Bend low beneath Philistian yoke."
10130-8{_}5605{_}Day by day these words he spoke,   Singly traversing the ground.
10130-8{_}5606{_}But not an Israelite was found   To combat man to man with him,   Who such prodigious force of limb   Display'd.
10130-8{_}5607{_}Like to a weaver's beam   The pond'rous spear he held did seem.
10130-8{_}5608{_}In height six cubits he did pass,   And he was arm'd all o'er in brass.
10130-8{_}5609{_}Him we will leave awhile--and speak   Of one, the soft down on whose cheek   Of tender youth the tokens bare.
10130-8{_}5610{_}Ruddy he was and very fair.
10130-8{_}5611{_}David, the son of Jesse he,   Small-siz'd, yet beautiful to see.
