10130-8{_}5612{_}Three brothers had he in the band   Of warriors under Saul's command;   Himself at home did private keep   In Bethlem's plains his father's sheep.
10130-8{_}5613{_}Jesse said to this his son:   "David, to thy brothers run,   Where in the camp they now abide,   And learn what of them may betide.
10130-8{_}5614{_}These presents for their captains take,   And of their fare inquiries make."
10130-8{_}5615{_}With joy the youth his sire obey'd.--   David was no whit dismay'd   When he arrived at the place   Where he beheld the strength and face   Of dread Goliath, and could hear   The challenge.
10130-8{_}5616{_}Of the people near   Unmov'd he ask'd, what should be done   To him who slew that boasting one,   Whose words such mischiefs did forebode   To th' armies of the living God?
10130-8{_}5617{_}"The king," they unto David say,   "Most amply will that man repay,   He and his father's house shall be   Evermore in Israel free.
10130-8{_}5618{_}With mighty wealth Saul will endow   That man: and he has made a vow;   Whoever takes Goliath's life,   Shall have Saul's daughter for his wife."
10130-8{_}5619{_}His eldest brother, who had heard   His question, was to anger stirr'd   Against the youth: for (as he thought)   Things out of his young reach he sought.
10130-8{_}5620{_}Said he, "What mov'd thee to come here,   To question warlike men?
10130-8{_}5621{_}say, where   And in whose care are those few sheep,   That in the wilderness you keep?
10130-8{_}5622{_}I know thy thoughts, how proud thou art:   In the naughtiness of thy heart,   Hoping a battle thou mayst see,   Thou comest hither down to me."
10130-8{_}5623{_}Then answer'd Jesse's youngest son   In these words: "What have I done?
10130-8{_}5624{_}Is there not cause?"
10130-8{_}5625{_}Some there which heard,   And at the manner of his word   Admir'd, report this to the king.
10130-8{_}5626{_}By his command they David bring   Into his presence.
10130-8{_}5627{_}Fearless then,   Before the king and his chief men,   He shews his confident design   To combat with the Philistine.
10130-8{_}5628{_}Saul with wonder heard the youth,   And thus address'd him: "Of a truth,   No pow'r thy untried sinew hath   To cope with this great man of Gath."
10130-8{_}5629{_}Lowly David bow'd his head,   And with firm voice the stripling said:   "Thy servant kept his father's sheep.--   Rushing from a mountain steep   There came a lion, and a bear,   The firstlings of my flock to tear.
10130-8{_}5630{_}Thy servant hath that lion kill'd,   And kill'd that bear, when from the field   Two young lambs by force they seiz'd.
10130-8{_}5631{_}The Lord was mercifully pleas'd   Me to deliver from the paw   Of the fierce bear, and cruel jaw   Of the strong lion.
10130-8{_}5632{_}I shall slay   Th' unrighteous Philistine this day,   If God deliver him also   To me."
10130-8{_}5633{_}He ceas'd.
10130-8{_}5634{_}The king said, "Go:   Thy God, the God of Israel, be   In the battle still with thee."
10130-8{_}5635{_}David departs, unarmed, save   A staff in hand he chanc'd to have.
10130-8{_}5636{_}Nothing to the fight he took,   Save five smooth stones from out a brook;   These in his shepherd's scrip he plac'd,   That was fasten'd round his waist.
10130-8{_}5637{_}With staff and sling alone he meets   The armed giant, who him greets   With nought but scorn.
10130-8{_}5638{_}Looking askance   On the fair ruddy countenance   Of his young enemy--"Am I   A dog, that thou com'st here to try   Thy strength upon me with a staff--?"
10130-8{_}5639{_}Goliath said with scornful laugh.
10130-8{_}5640{_}"Thou com'st with sword, with spear, with shield,   Yet thou to me this day must yield.
10130-8{_}5641{_}The Lord of Hosts is on my side,   Whose armies boastful thou'st defied.
10130-8{_}5642{_}All nations of the earth shall hear   He saveth not with shield and spear."
10130-8{_}5643{_}Thus David spake, and nigher went,   Then chusing from his scrip, he sent   Out of his slender sling a stone.--   The giant utter'd fearful moan.
10130-8{_}5644{_}The stone though small had pierced deep   Into his forehead, endless sleep   Giving Goliath--and thus died   Of Philistines the strength and pride.
10130-8{_}5645{_}DAVID IN THE CAVE OF ADULLAM  (_Text of 1818_)    David and his three captains bold   Kept ambush once within a hold.
10130-8{_}5646{_}It was in Adullam's cave,   Nigh which no water they could have,   Nor spring, nor running brook was near   To quench the thirst that parch'd them there.
10130-8{_}5647{_}Then David, king of Israel,   Strait bethought him of a well,   Which stood beside the city gate,   At Bethlem; where, before his state   Of kingly dignity, he had   Oft drunk his fill, a shepherd lad;   But now his fierce Philistine foe   Encamp'd before it he does know.
10130-8{_}5648{_}Yet ne'er the less, with heat opprest,   Those three bold captains he addrest,   And wish'd that one to him would bring   Some water from his native spring.
10130-8{_}5649{_}His valiant captains instantly   To execute his will did fly.
10130-8{_}5650{_}The mighty Three the ranks broke through   Of armed foes, and water drew   For David, their beloved king,   At his own sweet native spring.
10130-8{_}5651{_}Back through their armed foes they haste,   With the hard earn'd treasure graced.
10130-8{_}5652{_}But when the good king David found   What they had done, he on the ground   The water pour'd.
10130-8{_}5653{_}"Because," said he,   "That it was at the jeopardy   Of your three lives this thing ye did,   That I should drink it, God forbid."
10130-8{_}5654{_}THREE POEMS NOT IN _POETRY FOR CHILDREN_   SUMMER FRIENDS    The Swallow is a summer bird;     He in our chimneys, when the weather   Is fine and warm, may then be heard     Chirping his notes for weeks together.
10130-8{_}5655{_}Come there but one cold wintry day,     Away will fly our guest the Swallow:   And much like him we find the way     Which many a gay young friend will follow.
10130-8{_}5656{_}In dreary days of snow and frost     Closer to Man will cling the Sparrow:   Old friends, although in life we're crost,     Their hearts to us will never narrow.
10130-8{_}5657{_}Give me the bird--'give me the friend--     Will sing in frost--will love in sorrow--   Whate'er mischance to-day may send,     Will greet me with his sight to-morrow.
10130-8{_}5658{_}A BIRTH-DAY THOUGHT    Can I, all gracious Providence!
10130-8{_}5659{_}Can I deserve thy care:   Ah!
10130-8{_}5660{_}no; I've not the least pretence     To bounties which I share.
10130-8{_}5661{_}Have I not been defended still     From dangers and from death;   Been safe preserv'd from ev'ry ill     E'er since thou gav'st me breath?
10130-8{_}5662{_}I live once more to see the day     That brought me first to light;   Oh!
10130-8{_}5663{_}teach my willing heart the way     To take thy mercies right!
10130-8{_}5664{_}Tho' dazzling splendour, pomp, and show,     My fortune has denied,   Yet more than grandeur can bestow,     Content hath well supplied.
10130-8{_}5665{_}I envy no one's birth or fame,     Their titles, train, or dress;   Nor has my pride e'er stretched its aim     Beyond what I possess.
10130-8{_}5666{_}I ask and wish not to appear     More beauteous, rich, or gay:   Lord, make me wiser every year,     And better every day.
10130-8{_}5667{_}THE BOY, THE MOTHER, AND THE BUTTERFLY  [1827]    Young William held the Butterfly in chase,   And it was pretty to observe the race   Betwixt the Fly and Child, who nigh had caught him   But for a merry jest his Mother taught him.
10130-8{_}5668{_}"My valiant Huntsman, fie!"
10130-8{_}5669{_}she said, "for shame,   You are too big a match for so small game,   To catch the Hare, or nimble Squirrel try,   Remember, William, He is BUT A FLY."
10130-8{_}5670{_}Not always is Humanity imprest   By serious schooling; a light word or jest   Will sometimes leave a moral sting behind   When graver lessons vanish out of mind.
10130-8{_}5671{_}PRINCE DORUS  OR  FLATTERY PUT OUT OF COUNTENANCE   A POETICAL VERSION OF AN ANCIENT TALK    In days of yore, as Ancient Stories tell,   A King in love with a great Princess fell.
10130-8{_}5672{_}Long at her feet submiss the Monarch sigh'd,   While she with stern repulse his suit denied.
10130-8{_}5673{_}Yet was he form'd by birth to please the fair,   Dress'd, danc'd, and courted with a Monarch's air;   But Magic Spells her frozen breast had steel'd   With stubborn pride, that knew not how to yield.
10130-8{_}5674{_}This to the King' a courteous Fairy told,   And bade the Monarch in his suit be bold;   For he that would the charming Princess wed,   Had only on her cat's black tail to tread,   When straight the Spell would vanish into air,   And he enjoy for life the yielding fair.
10130-8{_}5675{_}He thank'd the Fairy for her kind advice.--   Thought he, "If this be all, I'll not be nice;   Rather than in my courtship I will fail   I will to mince-meat tread Minon's black tail."
10130-8{_}5676{_}To the Princess's court repairing strait,   He sought the cat that must decide his fate;   But when he found her, how the creature stared!
10130-8{_}5677{_}How her back bristled, and her great eyes glared!
10130-8{_}5678{_}That [tail] which he so fondly hop'd his prize,   Was swell'd by wrath to twice its usual size;   And all her cattish gestures plainly spoke   She thought the affair he came upon, no joke.
10130-8{_}5679{_}With wary step the cautious King draws near,   And slyly means to attack her in her rear;   But when he thinks upon her tail to pounce,   Whisk--off she skips--three yards upon a bounce--   Again he tries, again his efforts fail--   Minon's a witch--the deuce is in her tail--    The anxious chase for weeks the Monarch tried,   Till courage fail'd, and hope within him died.
10130-8{_}5680{_}A desperate suit 'twas useless to prefer,   Or hope to catch a tail of quicksilver.--   When on a day, beyond his hopes, he found   Minon, his foe, asleep upon the ground;   Her ample tail behind her lay outspread,   Full to the eye, and tempting to the tread.
10130-8{_}5681{_}The King with rapture the occasion bless'd.
10130-8{_}5682{_}And with quick foot the fatal part he press'd.
10130-8{_}5683{_}Loud squalls were heard, like howlings of a storm,   And sad he gazed on Minon's altered form,--   No more a cat, but chang'd into a man   Of giant size, who frown'd, and thus began:    "Rash King, that dared with impious design   To violate that tail, that once was mine;   What though the spell be broke, and burst the charms,   That kept the Princess from thy longing arms,--   Not unrevenged shall thou my fury dare,   For by that violated tail I swear,   From your unhappy nuptials shall be born   A Prince, whose Nose shall be thy subjects' scorn.
10130-8{_}5684{_}Bless'd in his love thy son shall never be,   Till he his foul deformity shall see,   Till he with tears his blemish shall confess,   Discern its odious length, and wish it less!"
10130-8{_}5685{_}This said, he vanish'd; and the King awhile   Mused at his words, then answer'd with a smile   "Give me a child in happy wedlock born,   And let his Nose be made like a French horn;   His knowledge of the fact I ne'er can doubt,--   If he have eyes, or hands, he'll find it out."
10130-8{_}5686{_}So spake the King, self-flatter'd in his thought,   Then with impatient step the Princess sought.
10130-8{_}5687{_}His urgent suit no longer she withstands,   But links with him in Hymen's knot her hands.
10130-8{_}5688{_}Almost as soon a widow as a bride,   Within a year the King her husband died;   And shortly after he was dead and gone,   She was deliver'd of a little son,   The prettiest babe, with lips as red as rose,   And eyes like little stars--but such a nose--   The tender Mother fondly took the boy   Into her arms, and would have kiss'd her joy;   His luckless nose forbade the fond embrace--   He thrust the hideous feature in her face.
10130-8{_}5689{_}Then all her Maids of Honour tried in turn,   And for a Prince's kiss in envy burn;   By sad experience taught, their hopes they miss'd,   And mourn'd a Prince that never could be kiss'd.
10130-8{_}5690{_}In silent tears the Queen confess'd her grief,   Till kindest Flattery came to her relief.
10130-8{_}5691{_}Her maids, as each one takes him in her arms,   Expatiate freely o'er his world of charms--   His eyes, lips, mouth--his forehead was divine--   And for the nose--they called it Aquiline--   Declared that Cæsar, who the world subdued,   Had such a one--just of that longitude--   That Kings like him compelled folks to adore them,   And drove the short-nos'd sons of men before them--   That length of nose portended length of days,   And was a great advantage many ways--   To mourn the gifts of Providence was wrong--   Besides, _the Nose was not so very long_.--    These arguments in part her grief redrest,   A mother's partial fondness did the rest;   And Time, that all things reconciles by use,   Did in her notions such a change produce.
10130-8{_}5692{_}That, as she views her babe, with favour blind,   She thinks him handsomest of human kind.
10130-8{_}5693{_}Meantime in spite of his disfigured face,   Dorus (for so he's call'd) grew up apace;   In fair proportion all his features rose,   Save that most prominent of all--his Nose.
10130-8{_}5694{_}That Nose, which in the infant could annoy,   Was grown a perfect nuisance in the boy.
10130-8{_}5695{_}Whene'er he walk'd, his Handle went before,   Long as the snout of Ferret, or Wild Boar;   Or like the Staff, with which on holy day   The solemn Parish Beadle clears the way.
10130-8{_}5696{_}But from their cradle to their latest year,   How seldom Truth can reach a Prince's ear!
10130-8{_}5697{_}To keep th' unwelcome knowledge out of view,   His lesson well each flattering Courtier knew;   The hoary Tutor, and the wily Page,   Unmeet confederates!
10130-8{_}5698{_}dupe his tender age.
10130-8{_}5699{_}They taught him that whate'er vain mortals boast--   Strength, Courage, Wisdom--all they value most--   Whate'er on human life distinction throws--   Was all comprised--in what?--a length of nose!
10130-8{_}5700{_}Ev'n Virtue's self (by some suppos'd chief merit)   In short-nosed folks was only want of spirit.
10130-8{_}5701{_}While doctrines such as these his guides instill'd,   His Palace was with long-nosed people fill'd;   At Court, whoever ventured to appear   With a short nose, was treated with a sneer.
10130-8{_}5702{_}Each courtier's wife, that with a babe is blest,   Moulds its young nose betimes; and does her best,   By pulls, and hauls, and twists, and lugs and pinches,   To stretch it to the standard of the Prince's.
10130-8{_}5703{_}Dup'd by these arts, Dorus to manhood rose,   Nor dream'd of aught more comely than his Nose,   Till Love, whose pow'r ev'n Princes have confest,   Claim'd the soft empire o'er his youthful breast.
10130-8{_}5704{_}Fair Claribel was she who caused his care;   A neighb'ring Monarch's daughter, and sole heir.
10130-8{_}5705{_}For beauteous Claribel his bosom burn'd;   The beauteous Claribel his flame return'd;   Deign'd with kind words his passion to approve,   Met his soft vows, and yielded love for love.
10130-8{_}5706{_}If in her mind some female pangs arose   At sight (and who can blame her?)
10130-8{_}5707{_}of his Nose.
10130-8{_}5708{_}Affection made her willing to be blind;   She loved him for the beauties of his mind;   And in his lustre, and his royal race,   Contented sunk--one feature of his face.
10130-8{_}5709{_}Blooming to sight, and lovely to behold,   Herself was cast in Beauty's richest mould;   Sweet female majesty her person deck'd,   Her face an angel's--save for one defect--   Wise Nature, who to Dorus over kind,   A length of nose too liberal had assign'd,   As if with us poor mortals to make sport,   Had giv'n to Claribel a nose too short:   But turned up with a sort of modest grace;   It took not much of beauty from her face;   And subtle Courtiers, who their Prince's mind   Still watch'd, and turned about with every wind,   Assur'd the Prince, that though man's beauty owes   Its charm to a majestic length of nose,   The excellence of Woman (softer creature)   Consisted in the shortness of that feature.
10130-8{_}5710{_}Few arguments were wanted to convince   The already more than half persuaded Prince;   Truths, which we hate, with slowness we receive,   But what we wish to credit, soon believe.
10130-8{_}5711{_}The Princess's affections being gain'd,   What but her Sire's approval now remain'd?
10130-8{_}5712{_}Ambassadors with solemn pomp are sent   To win the aged Monarch to consent   (Seeing their States already were allied)   That Dorus might have Claribel to bride.
10130-8{_}5713{_}Her Royal Sire, who wisely understood   The match propos'd was for both kingdoms' good,   Gave his consent; and gentle Claribel   With weeping bids her Father's court farewell.
10130-8{_}5714{_}With gallant pomp, and numerous array,   Dorus went forth to meet her on her way;   But when the Princely pair of lovers met,   Their hearts on mutual gratulations set,   Sudden the Enchanter from the ground arose,   (The same who prophesied the Prince's nose)   And with rude grasp, unconscious of her charms,   Snatch'd up the lovely Princess in his arms,   Then bore her out of reach of human eyes,   Up in the pathless regions of the skies.
10130-8{_}5715{_}Bereft of her that was his only care,   Dorus resign'd his soul to wild despair;   Resolv'd to leave the land that gave him birth,   And seek fair Claribel throughout the earth.
10130-8{_}5716{_}Mounting his horse, he gives the beast the reins,   And wanders lonely through the desert plains;   With fearless heart the savage heath explores,   Where the wolf prowls, and where the tiger roars,   Nor wolf, nor tiger, dare his way oppose;   The wildest creatures see, and shun, his NOSE.
10130-8{_}5717{_}Ev'n lions fear!
10130-8{_}5718{_}the elephant alone   Surveys with pride a trunk so like his own.
10130-8{_}5719{_}At length he to a shady forest came,   Where in a cavern lived an aged dame;   A reverend Fairy, on whose silver head   A hundred years their downy snows had shed.
10130-8{_}5720{_}Here ent'ring in, the Mistress of the place   Bespoke him welcome with a cheerful grace,   Fetch'd forth her dainties, spread her social board   With all the Store her dwelling could afford.
10130-8{_}5721{_}The Prince with toil and hunger sore opprest,   Gladly accepts, and deigns to be her guest.
10130-8{_}5722{_}But when the first civilities were paid,   The dishes rang'd, and Grace in order said;   The Fairy, who had leisure now to view   Her guest more closely, from her pocket drew   Her spectacles, and wip'd them from the dust,   Then on her nose endeavour'd to adjust;   With difficulty she could find a place   To hang them on in her unshapely face;   For if the Princess's was somewhat small,   This Fairy scarce had any nose at all.
10130-8{_}5723{_}But when by help of spectacles the Crone   Discern'd a Nose so different from her own,   What peals of laughter shook her aged sides!
10130-8{_}5724{_}While with sharp jests the Prince she thus derides.
10130-8{_}5725{_}FAIRY    "Welcome, great Prince of Noses, to my cell;   'Tis a poor place,--but thus we Fairies dwell.
10130-8{_}5726{_}Pray, let me ask you, if from far you come--   And don't you sometimes find it cumbersome?"
10130-8{_}5727{_}PRINCE    "Find what?"
10130-8{_}5728{_}FAIRY            "Your Nose--."
10130-8{_}5729{_}PRINCE                    "My Nose, Ma'am!"
10130-8{_}5730{_}FAIRY                                 "No offence.--   The King your Father was a man of sense,   A handsome man (but lived not to be old)   And had a Nose cast in the common mould.
10130-8{_}5731{_}Ev'n I myself, that now with age am grey,   Was thought to have some beauty in my day,   And am the Daughter of a King.
10130-8{_}5732{_}Your sire   In this poor face saw something to admire--   And I to shew my gratitude made shift--   Have stood his friend--and help'd him at a lift--   'Twas I that, when his hopes began to fail,   Shew'd him the spell that lurk'd in Minon's tail--   Perhaps you have heard--but come, Sir, you don't eat--   That Nose of yours requires both wine and meat--   Fall to, and welcome, without more ado--   You see your fare--what shall I help you to?
10130-8{_}5733{_}This dish the tongues of nightingales contains;   This, eyes of peacocks; and that, linnets' brains;   That next you is a Bird of Paradise--   We fairies in our food are somewhat nice.--   And pray, Sir, while your hunger is supplied,   Do lean your Nose a little on one side;   The shadow, which it casts upon the meat,   Darkens my plate, I see not what I eat "--    The Prince on dainty after dainty feeding,   Felt inly shock'd at the old Fairy's breeding;   And held it want of manners in the Dame,   And did her country education blame.
10130-8{_}5734{_}One thing he only wonder'd at,--what she   So very comic in his nose could see.
10130-8{_}5735{_}Hers, it must be confest, was somewhat short,   And time and shrinking age accounted for't;   But for his own, thank heaven, he could not tell   That it was ever thought remarkable;   A decent nose, of reasonable size,   And handsome thought, rather than otherwise.
10130-8{_}5736{_}But that which most of all his wonder paid,   Was to observe the Fairy's waiting Maid;   How at each word the aged Dame let fall   She courtsied low, and smil'd assent to all;   But chiefly when the rev'rend Grannam told   Of conquests, which her beauty made of old.--   He smiled to see how Flattery sway'd the Dame,   Nor knew himself was open to the same!
10130-8{_}5737{_}He finds her raillery now increase so fast,   That making hasty end of his repast,   Glad to escape her tongue, he bids farewell   To the old Fairy, and her friendly cell.
10130-8{_}5738{_}But his kind Hostess, who had vainly tried   The force of ridicule to cure his pride,   Fertile in plans, a surer method chose,   To make him see the error of his nose;   For till he view'd that feature with remorse,   The Enchanter's direful spell must be in force.
10130-8{_}5739{_}Midway the road by which the Prince must pass,   She rais'd by magic art a House of Glass;   No mason's hand appear'd, nor work of wood;   Compact of glass the wondrous fabric stood.
10130-8{_}5740{_}Its stately pillars, glittering in the sun,   Conspicuous from afar, like silver, shone.
10130-8{_}5741{_}Here, snatch'd and rescued from th' Enchanter's might,   She placed the beauteous Claribel in sight.
10130-8{_}5742{_}The admiring Prince the chrystal dome survey'd,   And sought access unto his lovely Maid;   But, strange to tell, in all that mansion's bound,   Nor door, nor casement, was there to be found.
10130-8{_}5743{_}Enrag'd, he took up massy stones, and flung   With such a force, that all the palace rung;   But made no more impression on the glass,   Than if the solid structure had been brass.
10130-8{_}5744{_}To comfort his despair, the lovely maid   Her snowy hand against her window laid;   But when with eager haste he thought to kiss,   His Nose stood out, and robb'd him of the bliss.
10130-8{_}5745{_}Thrice he essay'd th' impracticable feat;   The window and his lips can never meet.
10130-8{_}5746{_}The painful Truth, which Flattery long conceal'd,   Rush'd on his mind, and "O!"
10130-8{_}5747{_}he cried, "I yield;   Wisest of Fairies, thou wert right, I wrong--   _I own, I own, I have a Nose too long_."
10130-8{_}5748{_}The frank confession was no sooner spoke,   But into shivers all the palace broke,   His Nose of monstrous length, to his surprise   Shrunk to the limits of a common size;   And Claribel with joy her Lover view'd,   Now grown as beautiful as he was good.
10130-8{_}5749{_}The aged Fairy in their presence stands,   Confirms their mutual vows, and joins their hands.
10130-8{_}5750{_}The Prince with rapture hails the happy hour,   That rescued him from self-delusion's power;   And trains of blessings crown the future life   Of Dorus, and of Claribel, his wife.
10130-8{_}5751{_}NOTES  CHARLES LAMB AND BOOKS FOR CHILDREN   Charles Lamb's activities as a writer for children seem to have begun and ended in the service of Godwin.
10130-8{_}5752{_}The earliest effort in this direction of which we have any knowledge is _The King and Queen of Hearts_, 1805, and the latest _Prince Dorus_, 1810 or 1811, unless we count _Beauty and the Beast_, possibly 1811, which in my opinion he did not write.
10130-8{_}5753{_}Lamb first met William Godwin (1756-1836), the philosopher, probably through the instrumentality of their mutual friend Thomas Holcroft, not long after Gillray had satirised Lamb and Lloyd, in his plate in the first number of _The Anti-Jacobin Review and Magazine_, August, 1798, as a frog and a toad, seated in the vicinity of Coleridge and Southey and reading together a volume labelled "Blank Verse, by Toad and Frog."
10130-8{_}5754{_}"Pray, Mr. Lamb," said Godwin when he first made Lamb's acquaintance, "are you toad or frog?"
10130-8{_}5755{_}It was feared that trouble might ensue, but Lamb and Godwin were found the next morning at breakfast together and they became good, though never very intimate, friends.
10130-8{_}5756{_}Godwin, who had been for a while a minister at Ware, in Hertfordshire, came to London in 1779, and took up literature as a profession seriously in 1783.
10130-8{_}5757{_}His _Political Justice_ was published in 1793, _Caleb Williams_ in 1794, and _St.
10130-8{_}5758{_}Leon_ in 1799.
10130-8{_}5759{_}After loving at a distance Mrs. Opie and Mrs. Inchbald, Godwin married Mary Wollstonecraft in 1797.
10130-8{_}5760{_}Their daughter afterwards became Mrs. Shelley, the wife of the poet.
10130-8{_}5761{_}Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin died in the year of her marriage, and in 1801 Godwin married again, a Mrs. Clairmont, a widow.
10130-8{_}5762{_}Lamb detested her.
10130-8{_}5763{_}None the less it was she who took to publishing and who incited him and his sister to write the charming children's books in this volume.
10130-8{_}5764{_}Lamb helped Godwin with other literary ventures before the publishing business was started.
10130-8{_}5765{_}In 1800 he wrote an epilogue to his tragedy of "Antonio" (see the essay in Vol.
10130-8{_}5766{_}II., "The Old Actors," for a description of the luckless first night), and he advised him in the composition of "Faulkener," another tragedy, which failed in 1807 and which also had a prologue by Lamb.
10130-8{_}5767{_}And a letter is extant showing Lamb toiling at a review of Godwin's _Chaucer_ in 1803, but the review itself is not forthcoming.
10130-8{_}5768{_}The publishing business was started in 1805 on Mrs. Godwin's initiative.
10130-8{_}5769{_}At first, owing to the undesirability of connecting the name of a political and moral firebrand like Godwin with books for children, it was arranged that the business, which was in Hanway Street, Oxford Street, should bear the name of the manager, Thomas Hodgkins, while the books contributed by Godwin were to be signed Edward Baldwin.
10130-8{_}5770{_}In 1806, however, Mrs. Godwin opened a shop at 41 Skinner Street, Snow Hill (now demolished), and published in her own name as M.J. Godwin & Co., at The Children's Library.
10130-8{_}5771{_}For her the Lambs wrote _The King and Queen of Hearts_ (by Charles Lamb), 1805; _Tales from Shakespear_, 1807; _The Adventures of Ulysses_ (by Charles Lamb), 1808; _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5772{_}Leicester's School and Poetry for Children_, 1809; and _Prince Dorus_ (by Charles Lamb), 1811.
10130-8{_}5773{_}Mrs. Godwin translated tales from the French, Godwin contributed _Baldwin's Fables_, _Baldwin's Pantheon_, and histories of Greece, England and Rome, and Hazlitt wrote an English Grammar.
10130-8{_}5774{_}The principal illustrator to the firm was William Mulready.
10130-8{_}5775{_}Although Lamb had the most cordial disliking for Mrs. Godwin, he always stood by his old friend her husband.
10130-8{_}5776{_}Between 1811 and 1821 the two men seem to have had little to do with each other; but in 1822 Lamb came to Godwin's assistance to much purpose.
10130-8{_}5777{_}The title to Godwin's house in Skinner Street was successfully contested in that year, and Godwin became a bankrupt.
10130-8{_}5778{_}A fund was therefore set on foot for him by Lamb and others, Lamb's own contribution being £50.
10130-8{_}5779{_}Godwin, however, never rightly rallied, and thenceforward lived very quietly, wrote the _History of the Commonwealth_ and _Lives of the Necromancers_, and died in 1836.
10130-8{_}5780{_}Mrs. Godwin survived him until 1841.
10130-8{_}5781{_}Knowing what we do--from Dowden's _Shelley_ and other sources--it is not possible greatly to admire Godwin's character, nor is the second Mrs. Godwin a subject for enthusiasm; but the part played by them in the Lambs' literary life was extremely valuable.
10130-8{_}5782{_}Charles Lamb had, it is true, other stimulus, and without his work for children, sweet though it is, his name would still be a household word; but Mary Lamb might, but for the Godwins, have gone almost silent to the grave.
10130-8{_}5783{_}Her writings, with their sweet gravity and tender simplicity, were called forth wholly by the Bad Baby, as Lamb called Mrs. Godwin.
10130-8{_}5784{_}Lamb's views on the literature of the nursery had crystallised long before he began to write children's books himself.
10130-8{_}5785{_}In a letter to Coleridge, October 23,1802, he had said:--  "'Goody Two Shoes' is almost out of print.
10130-8{_}5786{_}Mrs. Barbauld's stuff has banished all the old classics of the nursery; and the shopman at Newberry's hardly deigned to reach them off an old exploded corner of a shelf, when Mary asked for them.
10130-8{_}5787{_}Mrs.
10130-8{_}5788{_}B.
10130-8{_}5789{_}'s and Mrs.
10130-8{_}5790{_}Trimmer's nonsense lay in piles about.
10130-8{_}5791{_}Knowledge insignificant and vapid as Mrs. Barbauld's books convey, it seems, must come to a child in the _shape of knowledge_, and his empty noddle must be turned with conceit of his own powers when he has learnt, that a horse is an animal, and Billy is better than a horse, and such like; instead of that beautiful interest in wild tales, which made the child a man, while all the while he suspected himself to be no bigger than a child.
10130-8{_}5792{_}Science has succeeded to poetry no less in the little walks of children than with men.
10130-8{_}5793{_}Is there no possibility of averting this sore evil?
10130-8{_}5794{_}Think what you would have been now, if, instead of being fed with tales and old wives' fables in childhood, you had been crammed with geography and natural history!"
10130-8{_}5795{_}Hence when the time came Lamb was all ready with a nursery method of his own.
10130-8{_}5796{_}*       *       *       *       *  Page 1.
10130-8{_}5797{_}TALES FROM SHAKESPEAR.
10130-8{_}5798{_}Mary Lamb was asked to write the _Tales from Shakespear_, with help from her brother, in the spring of 1806 or the winter of 1805.
10130-8{_}5799{_}I have seen the statement that this was at the instigation of Hazlitt, but Lamb does not say so.
10130-8{_}5800{_}The first mention of the work is in Lamb's letter to Manning, May 10, 1806:--  "She [Mary] says you saw her writings about the other day, and she wishes you should know what they are.
10130-8{_}5801{_}She is doing for Godwin's bookseller twenty of Shakspeare's plays, to be made into children's tales.
10130-8{_}5802{_}Six are already done by her, to wit, 'The Tempest,' 'Winter's Tale,' 'Midsummer Night,' 'Much Ado,' 'Two Gentlemen of Verona,' and 'Cymbeline'; and the 'Merchant of Venice' is in forwardness.
10130-8{_}5803{_}I have done 'Othello' and 'Macbeth,' and mean to do all the tragedies.
10130-8{_}5804{_}I think it will be popular among the little people, besides money.
10130-8{_}5805{_}It's to bring in sixty guineas.
10130-8{_}5806{_}Mary has done them capitally, I think, you'd think.
10130-8{_}5807{_}These are the humble amusements we propose, while you are gone to plant the cross of Christ among barbarous pagan anthropophagi.
10130-8{_}5808{_}Quam homo homini præstat!
10130-8{_}5809{_}but then, perhaps, you'll get murdered, and we shall die in our beds with a fair literary reputation."
10130-8{_}5810{_}Mary Lamb's letters to Sarah Stoddart (afterwards Sarah Hazlitt), continue the story.
10130-8{_}5811{_}This is on June 2, 1806:--  My _Tales_ are to be published in separate story-books; I mean, in single stories, like the children's little shilling books.
10130-8{_}5812{_}I cannot send you them in Manuscript, because they are all in the Godwins' hands; but one will be published very soon, and then you shall have it _all in print_.
10130-8{_}5813{_}I go on very well, and have no doubt but I shall always be able to hit upon some such kind of job to keep going on.
10130-8{_}5814{_}I think I shall get fifty pounds a year at the lowest calculation; but as I have not yet seen any _money_ of my own earning, for we do not expect to be paid till Christmas, I do not feel the good fortune, that has so unexpectedly befallen me, half so much as I ought to do.
10130-8{_}5815{_}But another year, no doubt, I shall perceive it.
10130-8{_}5816{_}When I write again, you will hear tidings of the farce, for Charles is to go in a few days to the Managers to inquire about it.
10130-8{_}5817{_}But that must now be a next-year's business too, even if it does succeed; so it's all looking forward, and no prospect of present gain.
10130-8{_}5818{_}But that's better than no hopes at all, either for present or future times.
10130-8{_}5819{_}Charles has written Macbeth, Othello, King Lear, and has begun Hamlet; you would like to see us, as we often sit writing on one table (but not on one cushion sitting), like Hermia and Helena in the Midsummer Night's Dream; or, rather, like an old literary Darby and Joan: I taking snuff; and he groaning all the while, and saying he can make nothing of it, which he always says till he has finished, and then he finds out he has made something of it....  Martin [Burney] has just been here.
10130-8{_}5820{_}My Tales (_again_) and Charles's Farce has made the boy mad to turn Author; and he has written a Farce, and he has made the Winter's Tale into a story; but what Charles says of himself is really true of Martin, for _he can make nothing at all of it_; and I have been talking very eloquently this morning, to convince him that nobody can write farces, &c., under thirty years of age.
10130-8{_}5821{_}And so I suppose he will go home and new model his farce.
10130-8{_}5822{_}A little later, June 26, Lamb writes to Wordsworth:--  "Mary is just stuck fast in All's Well that Ends Well.
10130-8{_}5823{_}She complains of having to set forth so many female characters in boy's clothes.
10130-8{_}5824{_}She begins to think Shakspear must have wanted Imagination.
10130-8{_}5825{_}I to encourage her, for she often faints in the prosecution of her great work, flatter her with telling how well such and such a play is done.
10130-8{_}5826{_}But she is stuck fast and I have been obliged to promise to assist her."
10130-8{_}5827{_}Then we have Mary Lamb to Sarah Stoddart again (early in July, 1806): "I am in good spirits just at this present time, for Charles has been reading over the _Tale_ I told you plagued me so much, and he thinks it one of the very best: it is 'All's Well that Ends Well.'"
10130-8{_}5828{_}The work was finished in the autumn of 1806 and published at the end of the year, dated 1807.
10130-8{_}5829{_}Lamb sent Wordsworth a copy on January 29, 1807, with the following letter:--      "We have book'd off from Swan and Two Necks, Lad Lane, this day     (per Coach) the Tales from Shakespear.
10130-8{_}5830{_}You will forgive the     plates, when I tell you they were left to the direction of Godwin,     who left the choice of subjects to the bad baby, who from mischief     (I suppose) has chosen one from damn'd beastly vulgarity (vide     'Merch.
10130-8{_}5831{_}Venice'), where no atom of authority was in the tale to     justify it--to another has given a name which exists not in the     tale, Nic Bottom, and which she thought would be funny, though in     this I suspect _his_ hand, for I guess her reading does not reach     far enough to know Bottom's Christian name--and one of Hamlet, and     Grave digging, a scene which is not hinted at in the story, and     you might as well have put King Canute the Great reproving his     courtiers--the rest are Giants and Giantesses.
10130-8{_}5832{_}Suffice it, to save     our taste and damn our folly, that we left it all to a friend W.G.
10130-8{_}5833{_}who in the first place cheated me into putting a name to them,     which I did not mean, but do not repent, and then wrote a puff     about their _simplicity_, &c., to go with the advertisement as in     my name!
10130-8{_}5834{_}Enough of this egregious dupery.
10130-8{_}5835{_}I will try to abstract     the load of teazing circumstances from the Stories and tell you     that I am answerable for Lear, Macbeth, Timon, Romeo, Hamlet,     Othello, for occasionally a tail piece or correction of grammar,     for none of the cuts and all of the spelling.
10130-8{_}5836{_}The rest is my     Sister's.--We think Pericles of hers the best, and Othello of     mine--but I hope all have some good.
10130-8{_}5837{_}As You Like It, we like     least.
10130-8{_}5838{_}"So much, only begging you to tear out the cuts and give them to     Johnny, as 'Mrs.
10130-8{_}5839{_}Godwin's fancy'.
10130-8{_}5840{_}"C.L.
10130-8{_}5841{_}"_Our love to all_.
10130-8{_}5842{_}"I had almost forgot, My part of the Preface begins in the middle     of a sentence, in last but one page, after a colon, thus:--      ":--_which if they be happily so done_, &c. (see page 2, line 7     from foot).
10130-8{_}5843{_}The former part hath a more feminine turn and does hold me up     something as an instructor to young ladies: but upon my modesty's     honour I wrote it not.
10130-8{_}5844{_}"Godwin told my Sister that the Baby chose the subjects: a fact in     taste."
10130-8{_}5845{_}This letter not only tells us how the preface was written--the first part, I take it, by William Godwin--but what Lamb himself thought of the pictures; which I reproduce in the large edition.
10130-8{_}5846{_}It is customary to attribute the designs to Mulready and the engraving to William Blake.
10130-8{_}5847{_}I have set up the _Tales_ from the second edition, 1809, because it embodies certain corrections and was probably the last edition in which the Lambs took any interest.
10130-8{_}5848{_}The changes of word are few.
10130-8{_}5849{_}I note the more important; Page 5, line 1, "recollection" was "remembrance" in the first edition; page 10, line 27, "voracious" was "ugly" in the first edition; page 15, line 21, "vessel" was "churn"; page 42, line 30, "continued" was in the first edition "remained"; page 108, foot, "But she being a woman" had run in the first edition, "But she being a bad ambitious woman."
10130-8{_}5850{_}I leave other minute differences to the Bibliographer.
10130-8{_}5851{_}The second edition was issued in two forms: one similar to the first edition and one with only frontispiece, a portrait of Shakespear, and the following foreword from the pen, I imagine, of Mr. Godwin:--      ADVERTISEMENT TO THE SECOND EDITION      The Proprietors of this work willingly pay obedience to the voice     of the public.
10130-8{_}5852{_}It has been the general sentiment, that the style     in which these Tales are written, is not so precisely adapted for     the amusement of mere children, as for an acceptable and improving     present to young ladies advancing to the state of womanhood.
10130-8{_}5853{_}They therefore now offer to the public an edition prepared with     suitable elegance.
10130-8{_}5854{_}In the former impression they gave twenty     prints, illustrative of the twenty tales which compose these     volumes, for they knew that it was a grievous thing and a     disappointment to a child, to find some tales without the     recommendation of a print, which the others possessed.
10130-8{_}5855{_}The prints     were therefore made from spirited designs, but did not pretend to     high finishing in the execution.
10130-8{_}5856{_}To this edition they have annexed     merely a beautiful head of our immortal Dramatist, from a much     admired painting by Zoust.--They are satisfied that every reader     of taste will thank them for not suppressing the former Preface,     though not exactly applicable on the present occasion.
10130-8{_}5857{_}N.B.--A few copies have been worked off on the plan of the former     impression, for the use of those who rather coincide in the     original conception of the writer, than in the opinion above     stated.
10130-8{_}5858{_}Lamb, we may be sure, had no hand in this manifesto, but whatever protest he may have made was unsuccessful.
10130-8{_}5859{_}It reappears in the third edition, while the preface there has the general alteration of the first person singular to the first person plural: "our young readers" for "my young readers," and so forth.
10130-8{_}5860{_}But this was probably Godwinian work.
10130-8{_}5861{_}The Godwins also issued some or all of the _Tales_ separately at sixpence each (the two ordinary volumes cost eight shillings) with three plates to each, of a different design from those in the two-volume edition.
10130-8{_}5862{_}These little books are exceedingly rare, but copies have been discovered both plain and coloured.
10130-8{_}5863{_}The plates are attributed to Blake.
10130-8{_}5864{_}The Lambs' _Tales from Shakespear_ were not, Mr. Bertram Dobell has pointed out, the first experiment of the kind.
10130-8{_}5865{_}In 1783 was published in Paris _Contes Moraux, Amusans et Instructifs, à l'usage de la Jeunesse tirés des Tragédies de Shakespear_.
10130-8{_}5866{_}Par M. Perrin.
10130-8{_}5867{_}The Lambs did not, however, borrow anything from M. Perrin, even if they were aware of his work.
10130-8{_}5868{_}The _Tales_ are peculiarly their own.
10130-8{_}5869{_}The _Tales from Shakespear_ are, and probably will continue to be, the most widely distributed of all the Lambs' work.
10130-8{_}5870{_}In England it may be that _Elia_ has had as many readers; but abroad the _Tales from Shakespear_ easily lead.
10130-8{_}5871{_}In the British Museum catalogue I find translations in French, German, Swedish, Spanish, and Polish.
10130-8{_}5872{_}(No complete translation of _Elia_ into any language is known, not even in French, although a selection of the essays will be found at the end of Depret's monograph, _De L'Humeur Littéraire en Angleterre_, 1877.)
10130-8{_}5873{_}In England almost every Christmas brings a new edition of the _Tales_ and often an imitation.
10130-8{_}5874{_}Although Mary Lamb was the true author of the book, as of _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5875{_}Leicester's School_ and of _Poetry for Children_, her share being much greater than her brother's in all of these, she was not until many years later associated publicly with any of them.
10130-8{_}5876{_}The _Tales_ were attributed to Charles Lamb, presumably against his wish, as we see from a sentence in the letter to Wordsworth quoted above, and the other two books had no name attached to them at all.
10130-8{_}5877{_}Why Mary Lamb preserved such strict anonymity we do not now know; but it was probably from a natural shrinking from any kind of publicity after the unhappy publicity which she had once gained by her misfortune.
10130-8{_}5878{_}*       *       *       *       *  Page 240.
10130-8{_}5879{_}THE ADVENTURES OF ULYSSES.
10130-8{_}5880{_}Lamb must have been as busy in the years 1806-1808 as in any of his life; for he then not only had his India House work, but wrote his share of the _Tales from Shakespear_, _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5881{_}Leicester's School_ and _Poetry for Children_, wrote all of _The Adventures of Ulysses_, and finally prepared his _Dramatic Specimens_.
10130-8{_}5882{_}Moreover in 1806 he had the harassment of the alterations and impending production of "Mr. H."  On February 26, 1808, he tells Manning that he has just finished _The Adventures of Ulysses_ and the _Specimens_, describing _The Adventures of Ulysses_ as "intended to be an introduction to the reading of Telemachus!
10130-8{_}5883{_}it is done out of the Odyssey, not from the Greek.
10130-8{_}5884{_}I would not mislead you: nor yet from Pope's Odyssey, but from an older translation of one Chapman.
10130-8{_}5885{_}The 'Shakspeare Tales' suggested the doing it."
10130-8{_}5886{_}Many years after Lamb wrote to Barton (August 10, 1827): "Did you ever read my 'Adventures of Ulysses,' founded on Chapman's old translation of it?
10130-8{_}5887{_}for children or _men_.
10130-8{_}5888{_}Ch.
10130-8{_}5889{_}is divine, and my abridgment has not quite emptied him of his divinity."
10130-8{_}5890{_}Chapman's _Homer_ was the folio which Leigh Hunt tells us he once saw Lamb kiss.
10130-8{_}5891{_}Writing to Coleridge on October 23, 1802, Lamb says:--      "I have just finished Chapman's Homer.
10130-8{_}5892{_}Did you ever read it?--it     has most the continuous power of interesting you all along, like a     rapid original, of any; and in the uncommon excellence of the more     finished parts goes beyond Fairfax or any of 'em.
10130-8{_}5893{_}The metre is     fourteen syllables, and capable of all sweetness and grandeur.
10130-8{_}5894{_}Cowper's ponderous blank verse detains you every step with some     heavy Miltonism; Chapman gallops off with you his own free     pace....      "I will tell you more about Chapman and his peculiarities in my     next.
10130-8{_}5895{_}I am much interested in him."
10130-8{_}5896{_}A brief correspondence which passed between Godwin and Lamb just before the publication of _The Adventures of Ulysses_ may be given here.
10130-8{_}5897{_}WILLIAM GODWIN TO CHARLES LAMB      Skinner Street, _March_ 10, 1808.
10130-8{_}5898{_}Dear Lamb,--I address you with all humility, because I know you to     be _tenax propositi_.
10130-8{_}5899{_}Hear me, I entreat you, with patience.
10130-8{_}5900{_}It is strange with what different feelings an author and     a bookseller looks at the same manuscript.
10130-8{_}5901{_}I know this by     experience: I was an author, I am a bookseller.
10130-8{_}5902{_}The author thinks     what will conduce to his honour: the bookseller what will cause     his commodities to sell.
10130-8{_}5903{_}You, or some other wise man, I have heard to say, It is children     that read children's books, when they are read, but it is parents     that choose them.
10130-8{_}5904{_}The critical thought of the tradesman put itself     therefore into the place of the parent, and what the parent will     condemn.
10130-8{_}5905{_}We live in squeamish days.
10130-8{_}5906{_}Amid the beauties of your manuscript,     of which no man can think more highly than I do, what will the     squeamish say to such expressions as these,--'devoured their     limbs, yet warm and trembling, lapping the blood,' page 10.
10130-8{_}5907{_}Or     to the giant's vomit, page 14; or to the minute and shocking     description of the extinguishing the giant's eye in the page     following.
10130-8{_}5908{_}You, I daresay, have no formed plan of excluding the     female sex from among your readers, and I, as a bookseller, must     consider that if you have you exclude one half of the human     species.
10130-8{_}5909{_}Nothing is more easy than to modify these things if you please,     and nothing, I think, is more indispensable.
10130-8{_}5910{_}Give me, as soon as possible, your thoughts on the matter.
10130-8{_}5911{_}I should also like a preface.
10130-8{_}5912{_}Half our customers know not Homer,     or know him only as you or I know the lost authors of antiquity.
10130-8{_}5913{_}What can be more proper than to mention one or two of those     obvious recommendations of his works, which must lead every human     creature to desire a nearer acquaintance.--Believe me, ever     faithfully yours,      W. GODWIN.
10130-8{_}5914{_}CHARLES LAMB TO WILLIAM GODWIN      _March_ 11, 1808.
10130-8{_}5915{_}Dear Godwin,--The giant's vomit was perfectly nauseous, and I am     glad you pointed it out.
10130-8{_}5916{_}I have removed the objection.
10130-8{_}5917{_}To the     other passages I can find no other objection but what you may     bring to numberless passages besides, such as of Scylla snatching     up the six men, etc.,--that is to say, they are lively images of     _shocking_ things.
10130-8{_}5918{_}If you want a book, which is not occasionally     to _shock_, you should not have thought of a tale which was so     full of anthropophagi and wonders.
10130-8{_}5919{_}I cannot alter these things     without enervating the Book, and I will not alter them if the     penalty should be that you and all the London booksellers should     refuse it.
10130-8{_}5920{_}But speaking as author to author, I must say that I     think _the terrible_ in those two passages seems to me so much to     preponderate over the nauseous, as to make them rather fine than     disgusting.
10130-8{_}5921{_}Who is to read them, I don't know: who is it that     reads Tales of Terror and Mysteries of Udolpho?
10130-8{_}5922{_}Such things sell.
10130-8{_}5923{_}I only say that I will not consent to alter such passages, which     I know to be some of the best in the book.
10130-8{_}5924{_}As an author I say to     you, an author, Touch not my work.
10130-8{_}5925{_}As to a bookseller I say, Take     the work such as it is, or refuse it.
10130-8{_}5926{_}You are as free to refuse it     as when we first talked of it.
10130-8{_}5927{_}As to a friend I say, Don't plague     yourself and me with nonsensical objections.
10130-8{_}5928{_}I assure you I will     not alter one more word.
10130-8{_}5929{_}As the reader will see, Lamb made only the one alteration; nor did he add a preface recommending the works of Homer.
10130-8{_}5930{_}I have set up _The Adventures of Ulysses_ from the second edition, 1819, because it probably contains Lamb's final revision of the text.
10130-8{_}5931{_}The punctuation differs considerably from that of the first edition, but there are, I think, only four changes of words.
10130-8{_}5932{_}On page 251, line 34, "and" was inserted before "snout"; on page 257, line g, "does" was substituted for "do"; on page 266, line 7 from foot, "over" was substituted for "above"; and on page 276, line 5 from foot, "it" was inserted after "keep."
10130-8{_}5933{_}The suggestion has been made that, since Lamb states in the preface that this work was designed as a supplement to _The Adventures of Telemachus_, he was also the author of one of the versions of Fénélon's popular tale.
10130-8{_}5934{_}But this, I think, has no foundation in fact.
10130-8{_}5935{_}We know from Lamb's letter to Godwin that the impulse to write _The Adventures of Ulysses_ came from Godwin, and it was natural that he, a bookseller, should wish to associate this new venture with a volume so well known and so acceptable as the _Telemachus_.
10130-8{_}5936{_}Now and then in the story Lamb deliberately refers to Fénélon's work, as when in the fourth chapter he says:--  "It were useless to describe over again what has been so well told already; or to relate those soft arts of courtship which the goddess used to detain Ulysses; the same in kind which she afterwards practised upon his less wary son, whom Minerva, in the shape of Mentor, hardly preserved from her snares when they came to the Delightful Island together in search of the scarce departed Ulysses."
10130-8{_}5937{_}This is drawn not from Chapman or Homer, but from the Archbishop of Cambrai.
10130-8{_}5938{_}Lamb introduced it in accordance with the first sentence of his preface.
10130-8{_}5939{_}Lamb adapted Chapman very freely.
10130-8{_}5940{_}For the material in Chapter I. we must go to Chapman, Books IX.
10130-8{_}5941{_}and X.; for Chapter II., to Books X. and XL; for Chapter III., to Book XII.
10130-8{_}5942{_}; for Chapter IV., to the early books; for Chapters V., VI.
10130-8{_}5943{_}and VII., to Chapman, Books V.-IX.
10130-8{_}5944{_}and XIII.
10130-8{_}5945{_}; for Chapter VIII., to Books XIII.
10130-8{_}5946{_}and XIV.
10130-8{_}5947{_}; and for Chapter IX.
10130-8{_}5948{_}to the end, to Chapman, Book XVI.
10130-8{_}5949{_}and onwards.
10130-8{_}5950{_}It must be agreed that Lamb performed a difficult task with great skill and success, especially when we consider his want of interest, frequently admitted, in stories.
10130-8{_}5951{_}But the pleasure of adding dignity and sweetness to the character of Ulysses seems to have been very considerable as he worked (or so I imagine), and he made practically a new thing, a very persuasive blend of ancient and modern.
10130-8{_}5952{_}The book has not been so popular as the _Tales from Shakespear_, but it has, I think, finer literary merits and may perhaps be read by older intellects with more satisfaction.
10130-8{_}5953{_}*       *       *       *       *  Page 316.
10130-8{_}5954{_}MRS. LEICESTER'S SCHOOL.
10130-8{_}5955{_}This charming little book was published by Mrs. Godwin at the end of 1808, dated 1809, with no author's name attached.
10130-8{_}5956{_}Besides, however, ample internal evidence as to its authorship, there are many references to it in Lamb's letters.
10130-8{_}5957{_}Why it was issued anonymously we cannot now learn; probably, as I have suggested, from Mary Lamb's unwillingness to have her name in print.
10130-8{_}5958{_}The _Tales from Shakespear_, it will be remembered, were described always as being by Charles Lamb, although Mary did far more than half, and it was at the outset her book.
10130-8{_}5959{_}Her share of _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5960{_}Leicester's School_ was equally great, and a sentence in one of her letters to Sarah Stoddart suggests that it was hers in inception also: "I have been busy making waistcoats, and plotting new work to succeed the _Tales_."
10130-8{_}5961{_}Possibly it was because his share in the book was so small that Lamb refused to sign _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5962{_}Leicester's School_ as he had the _Tales from Shakespear_; possibly he had other reasons, the title-page of his _Dramatic Specimens_ being one of them.
10130-8{_}5963{_}When, a little while afterwards, the _Poetry for Children_ was published, it was stated to be "by the author of _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5964{_}Leicester's School_," while several of the poems when reprinted by Mylius (see notes below) were signed Mrs. Leicester.
10130-8{_}5965{_}Thus, Mary Lamb's last chance of seeing her name on a title-page vanished.
10130-8{_}5966{_}But we may feel confident that her own wishes were consulted in the matter.
10130-8{_}5967{_}Lamb's share in _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5968{_}Leicester's School_ we know from a letter to Bernard Barton (January 23, 1824): "My Sister's part in the Leicester School (about two thirds) was purely her own; as it was (to the same quantity) in the Shakspeare Tales which bear my name.
10130-8{_}5969{_}I wrote only the Witch Aunt, the first going to Church, and the final Story, about a little Indian girl in a ship."
10130-8{_}5970{_}The little book was well received, and was quietly popular for some years, running into eight editions by 1823.
10130-8{_}5971{_}I imagine, however, that it was little known between 1830 and the end of the century.
10130-8{_}5972{_}Latterly there has been a revival in interest.
10130-8{_}5973{_}One or two critics have touched rapturous heights in their praise.
10130-8{_}5974{_}Landor wrote to Crabb Robinson in April, 1831:--      It is now several days since I read the book you recommended to     me, "Mrs. Leicester's School;" and I feel as if I owed you a debt     in deferring to thank you for many hours of exquisite delight.
10130-8{_}5975{_}Never have I read anything in prose so many times over within so     short a space of time as "The Father's Wedding-day."
10130-8{_}5976{_}Most people,     I understand, prefer the first tale--in truth a very admirable     one--but others could have written it.
10130-8{_}5977{_}Show me the man or woman,     modern or ancient, who could have written this one sentence: "When     I was dressed in my new frock, I wished poor mamma was alive,     to see how fine I was on papa's wedding day; and I ran to my     favourite station at her bedroom door."
10130-8{_}5978{_}How natural, in a little     girl, is this incongruity--this impossibility!
10130-8{_}5979{_}Richardson would     have given his "Clarissa," and Rousseau his "Heloïse" to have     imagined it.
10130-8{_}5980{_}A fresh source of the pathetic bursts out before     us, and not a bitter one.
10130-8{_}5981{_}If your Germans can show us anything     comparable to what I have transcribed, I would almost undergo a     year's gargle of their language for it.
10130-8{_}5982{_}The story is admirable     throughout--incomparable, inimitable....  Landor wrote to Lady Blessington to the same effect.
10130-8{_}5983{_}Praise of this book is so pleasant to read that I quote his second letter too:--      One of her tales is, with the sole exception of the _Bride of     Lammermoor_, the most beautiful tale in prose composition in any     language, ancient or modern.
10130-8{_}5984{_}A young girl has lost her mother, the     father marries again, and marries a friend of his former wife.
10130-8{_}5985{_}The     child is ill reconciled to it, but being dressed in new clothes     for the marriage, she runs up to her mother's chamber, filled with     the idea how happy that dear mother would be at seeing her in all     her glory--not reflecting, poor soul!
10130-8{_}5986{_}that it was only by her     mother's death that she appeared in it.
10130-8{_}5987{_}How natural, how novel is     all this!
10130-8{_}5988{_}Did you ever imagine that a fresh source of the pathetic     would burst forth before us in this trodden and hardened world?
10130-8{_}5989{_}I     never did, and when I found myself upon it, I pressed my temples     with both hands, and tears ran down to my elbows.
10130-8{_}5990{_}And Coleridge remarked to Allsop:--      It at once soothes and amuses me to think--nay, to know--that     the time will come when this little volume of my dear and     well-nigh oldest friend, Mary Lamb, will be not only enjoyed but     acknowledged as a rich jewel in the treasury of our permanent     English literature; and I cannot help running over in my mind the     long list of celebrated writers, astonishing geniuses, Novels,     Romances, Poems, Histories and dense Political Economy quartos     which, compared with _Mrs.
10130-8{_}5991{_}Leicester's School_, will be remembered     as often and prized as highly as Wilkie's and Glover's _Epics_ and     Lord Bolingbroke's _Philosophies_ compared with _Robinson Crusoe_.
10130-8{_}5992{_}I have set up the book from the second edition, 1809, because the Lambs' final text is probably to be found there.
10130-8{_}5993{_}Although certain additional minor differences were made in the eighth and ninth editions, 1821 and 1825, I think it very unlikely that they were made by Mary or Charles Lamb.
10130-8{_}5994{_}The principal alteration between the second and first editions is page 317, line 6, "your eyes were red with weeping," for "The traces of tears might still be seen on your cheeks."
10130-8{_}5995{_}The other differences are very slight, mostly being in punctuation, but there are also a few changes of word.
10130-8{_}5996{_}I leave these, however, to the Bibliographer.
10130-8{_}5997{_}The eighth edition was furnished with the following preface; which, though it is signed "The Author," is not, I think, from either Mary or Charles Lamb's pen.
10130-8{_}5998{_}I rather suspect Mrs. Godwin.
10130-8{_}5999{_}"Tell me a story, Mamma," was almost the first request my own     child made me when she understood the meaning of a story, and     I soon discovered I had no easier method of managing a very     difficult temper than by adapting my stories to the errors she     committed, or the good qualities she announced; but as I found it     a very difficult and troublesome task to repeat the same story     precisely the same each time, and as a sensible child, even at     so early a period as three years of age, will remember where the     narrator forgets, and never fail to detect the mistakes of the     second repetition, I came to the resolution to print a small     collection of stories for very young children, composed merely of     circumstances incidental to their age.
10130-8{_}6000{_}The great error of many juvenile books is their deviation from truth; and as so much is absolutely necessary to be taught, why add to the labour by impressing false ideas on the mind of an infant, and thus lose the opportunity of making amusement the vehicle to convey instruction?
10130-8{_}6001{_}A Mother only is, perhaps, capable of adapting stories to the capacities of very young Children; for a Mother only watches the unfolding of their ideas, and the bent of their dispositions.
10130-8{_}6002{_}If one good Mother finds these tales of service to her in her arduous but pleasing task, my purpose will be answered.
10130-8{_}6003{_}It is stated that a French version of _Mrs.
10130-8{_}6004{_}Leicester's School_, under the title _Les Jeunes Pensionnaires_, was published.
10130-8{_}6005{_}I have seen, however, only _Petits Conies à l'usage de la Feunesse traduits de l'Anglais par M'me M. D'Avot_, 1823, which contains "Elisabeth Villiers, ou l'Oncle marin," "Charlotte Wilmot," "Marguerite Green, ou la jeune Mahométane," and "Arabella Hardy, ou la Traversée."
10130-8{_}6006{_}_Mrs.
10130-8{_}6007{_}Leicester's School_ calls for little annotation, except for the purpose of relating the stories to the lives of their writers; for it contains some very valuable autobiographical matter.
10130-8{_}6008{_}But there are a few minor points too.
10130-8{_}6009{_}Page 316.
10130-8{_}6010{_}_Dedication_.
10130-8{_}6011{_}In the choice of Amwell School as the name of Mrs. Leicester's establishment Mary (or Charles) returned after an inveterate Lamb habit to the old Hertfordshire days.
10130-8{_}6012{_}Amwell, where the New River rises, is only a few miles from Widford and Blakesware.
10130-8{_}6013{_}The signature to the dedication, "M.B.," may have been a little joke for the amusement of Martin Burney, who had taken such interest in the progress of the _Tales from Shakespear_ and was in those days a special favourite with Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6014{_}Page 319.
10130-8{_}6015{_}I.--_Elizabeth Villiers_.
10130-8{_}6016{_}"The Sailor Uncle."
10130-8{_}6017{_}By Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6018{_}The story of the little girl learning her letters from her mother's grave may have belonged to Widford churchyard; otherwise there seems to be no personal memory here.
10130-8{_}6019{_}Page 328.
10130-8{_}6020{_}II.--_Louisa Manners_.
10130-8{_}6021{_}"The Farm House."
10130-8{_}6022{_}By Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6023{_}Much of the description of the farm and country is probably from memory of the old days at Mackery End, where we know Mary Lamb to have gone with her little brother Charles some time about 1780, and perhaps herself earlier.
10130-8{_}6024{_}It is, however, possible that Blakesware is meant, since Mary Lamb speaks of the grandmother: Mrs. Bruton of Mackery End was her great aunt.
10130-8{_}6025{_}One feels that the grandmother's sorrow at not being remembered (on page 329) is from life; and also the episode with Will Tasker (on the same page), and the description (and probably the name) of Old Spot, the shepherd, on page 333.
10130-8{_}6026{_}Page 334.
10130-8{_}6027{_}III.--_Ann Withers_.
10130-8{_}6028{_}"The Changeling."
10130-8{_}6029{_}By Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6030{_}In one of the later editions of this story certain small changes were made, not, I fancy, by Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6031{_}For example, on page 349, line 19, the sentence was made to read: "Neither dancing, nor any foolish lectures, could do much for Miss Lesley, she remained _for some time_ wanting in gracefulness of carriage; but all that is usually attributed to dancing music _finally effected_."
10130-8{_}6032{_}The italics indicate the additions of the nice editorial hand.
10130-8{_}6033{_}Page 350.
10130-8{_}6034{_}IV.--_Elinor Forester_.
10130-8{_}6035{_}"The Father's Wedding Day."
10130-8{_}6036{_}By Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6037{_}It is this story which Landor so much admired (see above).
10130-8{_}6038{_}The pretty song, "Balow, my babe," was probably "Ann Bothwell's Lament," beginning "Balow, my boy."
10130-8{_}6039{_}Page 354.
10130-8{_}6040{_}V.--_Margaret Green_.
10130-8{_}6041{_}"The Young Mahometan."
10130-8{_}6042{_}By Mary Lamb, and perhaps her most perfect work.
10130-8{_}6043{_}Here we have a description of Blakesware, the home of the Plumers, which for many years was uninhabited by the family, and left from 1778 to 1792 in the sole charge of Mrs. Field, Charles and Mary's maternal grandmother.
10130-8{_}6044{_}Charles, since he was born in 1775, would on his visits have known no power superior to his grandmother; but Mary, who was born in 1764, would have occasionally encountered Mrs. Plumer, just as Margaret Green met Mrs. Beresford.
10130-8{_}6045{_}Probably Mrs. Plumer and Mrs. Beresford were very like.
10130-8{_}6046{_}Probably also Mrs. Field maintained silence with her grandchild, for we know that neither she nor her daughter rightly understood Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6047{_}Mrs. Field used to speak of her "poor moythered brains."
10130-8{_}6048{_}Mary's description of the old house should be compared with Charles's in the _Elia_ essays "Blakesmoor in H----shire" and "Dream-Children."
10130-8{_}6049{_}In one point they are at variance; for Mary says that the twelve Cæsars "hung" round the hall, and her brother that they were life-size busts.
10130-8{_}6050{_}I have the authority of a gentleman who remembers them at Gilston, whither they were removed, for saying that Charles Lamb's memory was the more accurate.
10130-8{_}6051{_}The picture of the little girl with a lamb seems to have made an equal impression on both their minds; and both mention the shuttlecocks on the table.
10130-8{_}6052{_}Page 360.
10130-8{_}6053{_}VI.--_Emily Barton_.
10130-8{_}6054{_}"Visit to the Cousins."
10130-8{_}6055{_}By Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6056{_}Possibly autobiographical in the matter of the first play.
10130-8{_}6057{_}Charles Lamb's first play was the opera "Artaxerxes;" Mary's may quite well have been Congreve's "Mourning Bride."
10130-8{_}6058{_}The book-shop at the corner of St. Paul's Churchyard would be Harris's (late Newbery's); that in Skinner Street (No.
10130-8{_}6059{_}41) was, of course, Godwin's, where _Mrs.
10130-8{_}6060{_}Leicester's School_ was published and sold.
10130-8{_}6061{_}This pleasant art of advertising one's wares in one's own children's books was brought to perfection by Newbery, and by Harris, his successor, whose tiny histories are full of reminders of the merits of the corner of St. Paul's Churchyard.
10130-8{_}6062{_}By making Mr. Barton hesitate between the two shops and then go to Mrs. Godwin's, Lamb (for here it was probably he and not his sister) carried the joke a step farther than Newbery.
10130-8{_}6063{_}The following account of the figures on old St. Dunstan's Church (the children of to-day are taken to Cheapside to see Bennett's clock) is given in Hughson's _London_ (1805):--      On the outside of the church, within a niche and pediment at the     south-west end, over the clock, are two figures of savages or wild     men, carved in wood, and painted natural colour, as big as the     life, standing erect, with each a knotty club in his hand, with     which they alternately strike the quarters, not only their arms,     but even their heads, moving at every blow.
10130-8{_}6064{_}Moxon tells us that when the old church was pulled down and the figures were removed, Lamb shed tears.
10130-8{_}6065{_}The figures I am told still exist in the garden of the villa in Regent's Park--"St. Dunstan's"--that once belonged to the Marquis of Hertford and is now the Earl of Londesborough's London House.
10130-8{_}6066{_}Miss Pearson kept a toy-shop at No.
10130-8{_}6067{_}7 Fleet Street.
10130-8{_}6068{_}The Lambs knew her through Charles's old schoolmistress, Mrs. Reynolds.
10130-8{_}6069{_}Page 368.
10130-8{_}6070{_}VII.--_Maria Howe_.
10130-8{_}6071{_}"The Witch Aunt."
10130-8{_}6072{_}By Charles Lamb.
10130-8{_}6073{_}This story is peculiarly interesting to students of Lamb's life, for it describes, probably with absolute fidelity, his Aunt Hetty, and elaborates the passage concerning Stackhouse's _New History of the Bible_, which is to be found in the _Elia_ essay "Witches and other Night Fears."
10130-8{_}6074{_}Aunt Hetty is described elsewhere by Lamb in his _Elia_ essays, "Christ's Hospital" and "My Relations;" and in the poem "Written on the Day of my Aunt's Funeral."
10130-8{_}6075{_}In Mary Lamb's letter to Sarah Stoddart on September 21, 1803, is a short passage corroborative of Lamb's account of the relations subsisting between his aunt and his parents:--      My father had a sister lived with us--of course, lived with my     Mother, her sister-in-law; they were, in their different ways, the     best creatures in the world--but they set out wrong at first.
10130-8{_}6076{_}They     made each other miserable for full twenty years of their lives--my     Mother was a perfect gentlewoman, my Aunty as unlike a gentlewoman     as you can possibly imagine a good old woman to be; so that my     dear Mother (who, though you do not know it, is always in my poor     head and heart) used to distress and weary her with incessant and     unceasing attention and politeness, to gain her affection.
10130-8{_}6077{_}The old     woman could not return this in kind, and did not know what to make     of it--thought it all deceit, and used to hate my Mother with a     bitter hatred; which, of course, was soon returned with interest.
10130-8{_}6078{_}Lamb told Coleridge, in a letter upon his aunt's death, "she was to me the 'cherisher of infancy.'"
10130-8{_}6079{_}In the _Elia_ essay on "Witches" no mention is made of Glanvil; but there is a passage in the unpublished version of _John Woodvil_ which mentions both it and Stackhouse:--    I can remember when a child the maids   Would place me on their lap, as they undrest me,   As silly women use, and tell me stories   Of Witches--Make me read "Glanvil on Witchcraft,"   And in conclusion show me in the Bible,   The old Family-Bible, with the pictures in it,   The 'graving of the Witch raising up Samuel,   Which so possest my fancy, being a child,   That nightly in my dreams an old Hag came   And sat upon my pillow.
10130-8{_}6080{_}That was written some eight or nine years earlier than "Maria Howe;" the essay on "Witches" some fifteen years later.
10130-8{_}6081{_}Joseph Glanvill (1636-1680) issued his _Philosophical Considerations touching Witches and Witchcraft_, in 1666.
10130-8{_}6082{_}Page 375.
10130-8{_}6083{_}VIII.--_Charlotte Wilmot_.
10130-8{_}6084{_}"The Merchant's Daughter."
10130-8{_}6085{_}By Mary Lamb.
10130-8{_}6086{_}Page 378.
10130-8{_}6087{_}IX.--_Susan Yates_.
10130-8{_}6088{_}"First Going to Church."
10130-8{_}6089{_}By Charles Lamb.
10130-8{_}6090{_}John Lamb, the father, came from Lincolnshire, but Charles did not know that county at all.
10130-8{_}6091{_}The remark, "to see how goodness thrived," may well have been John Lamb's, or possibly his father's; and Lamb's own first impressions of church, probably acquired at the Temple (which he mentions here by comparison), were, it is easy to believe, identical with the imaginary narrator's.
10130-8{_}6092{_}Church bells seem always to have had an attraction for him: he has a pretty reference to them in _John Woodvil_, and a little poem in _Blank Verse_, 1798, entitled "The Sabbath Bells."
10130-8{_}6093{_}Page 384.
10130-8{_}6094{_}X.--_Arabella Hardy_.
10130-8{_}6095{_}"The Sea Voyage."
10130-8{_}6096{_}By Charles Lamb.
10130-8{_}6097{_}Nothing else that Lamb wrote is quite so far from the ordinary run of his thoughts; and nothing has, I think, more charm.
10130-8{_}6098{_}*       *       *       *       *  Page 389.
10130-8{_}6099{_}The King and Queen of Hearts This is probably the first of Charles Lamb's books for children.
10130-8{_}6100{_}Of its history nothing is known: the proof that Charles Lamb wrote it is to be found in a letter from Lamb to Wordsworth, now in America, dated February 1, 1806, the concluding portion of which, and the only portion that has been printed--beginning "_Apropos_ of Spenser"--will be found in most editions of the correspondence tacked on to the letter dated June, 1806.
10130-8{_}6101{_}In the earlier part of this missive Lamb enumerates the books which he has just despatched to Wordsworth by carrier from London.
10130-8{_}6102{_}Among these is an edition of Spenser, leading to the "_apropos_."
10130-8{_}6103{_}Also: "there comes W. Hazlitt's book about Human Action for Coleridge; a little song book for Sarah Coleridge; a Box for Hartley ...; a Paraphrase on _The King and Queen of Hearts_, of which I, being the author, beg Mr. Johnny Wordsworth's acceptance and opinion.
10130-8{_}6104{_}_Liberal Criticism_, as G. Dyer declares, I am always ready to attend to."
10130-8{_}6105{_}As Charles Lamb is not known to have written children's books for any one but the Godwins, who in 1806 were still publishing under cover of Thomas Hodgkins' name, in Hanway Street, it is reasonable to assume that if a paraphrase of _The King and Queen of Hearts_ nursery rhyme could be found, bearing Hodgkins' or Godwin's name, and dated 1805 or 1806, Lamb would be its author.
10130-8{_}6106{_}That such a work did exist was proved by the advertisements at the end of other of Godwin's juvenile books.
10130-8{_}6107{_}In the first edition of _Mrs.
10130-8{_}6108{_}Leicester's School_, 1809, is this announcement:--      "Likewise, the following elegant and approved Publications,     containing each of them the Incidents of an agreeable Tale,     exhibited in a Series of Engravings, Price 1s.
10130-8{_}6109{_}plain, or 1s.
10130-8{_}6110{_}6d.
10130-8{_}6111{_}coloured.
10130-8{_}6112{_}"1.
10130-8{_}6113{_}_The King and Queen of Hearts: showing how notably the Queen     made her Tarts, and how Scurvily the Knave stole them away._ &c."  This series was called the Copperplate Series.
10130-8{_}6114{_}In due course a copy of No.
10130-8{_}6115{_}1, _The King and Queen of Hearts_, was found in the library of Miss Edith Pollock, bought by her at the sale of the late Mr. Andrew W. Tuer, an authority upon old children's literature and the publisher to whose enterprise we owe the facsimile editions of _Prince Dorus_ and _Poetry for Children_.
10130-8{_}6116{_}Mr. Tuer, however, had not suspected Lamb's authorship.
10130-8{_}6117{_}The cover of Miss Pollock's copy bears the date 1809, which means that the little book was re-bound as required with the date of the current year upon it.
10130-8{_}6118{_}Copies of the first edition have since been discovered and sold for enormous sums.
10130-8{_}6119{_}The date is 1806.
10130-8{_}6120{_}In a copy of _The Looking Glass_, another of Godwin's books, _The King and Queen of Hearts_ is thus advertised, with a new quatrain, probably also from Lamb's pen:--      "Price 1s.
10130-8{_}6121{_}Plain; or 15.
10130-8{_}6122{_}6ed.
10130-8{_}6123{_}Coloured,       The King and Queen of Hearts,           With the   Rogueries of the Knave who stole away the Queen's Pies.
10130-8{_}6124{_}Illustrated in Fifteen elegant Engravings:   Agreeably to the famous Historical Ballad on the Subject.
10130-8{_}6125{_}"I write of Tarts; how sweet a tale!
10130-8{_}6126{_}You'll lick your lips to hear it told:   I show you mighty Kings and Queens,     Robes of scarlet, Crowns of gold."
10130-8{_}6127{_}This little book, _The Looking Glass_, which relates the early life of William Mulready (1786-1863), was issued in facsimile by Mr. F.G. Stephens in 1885, with an interesting account of its history.
10130-8{_}6128{_}Therein Mr. Stephens wrote: "Mr. Linnell told me that the cuts to the once well-known _Nongtong Paw_ [Vol.
10130-8{_}6129{_}6 of "The Copperplate Series;" see above], _The Sullen Woman and the Pedlar_ [Vol.
10130-8{_}6130{_}2 of the same series], _Think before you speak_, and _The King and Queen of Hearts_, were designed by Mulready."
10130-8{_}6131{_}We thus discover who was the illustrator.
10130-8{_}6132{_}My own feeling is that the plates came first and Lamb's verses later.
10130-8{_}6133{_}_The King and Queen of Hearts_ cannot be said to add anything characteristic to the body of Lamb's writings.
10130-8{_}6134{_}But its discovery is historically valuable in establishing--by the date 1805 on the engraved title-page--the fact that before the _Tales from Shakespear_, which are usually thought to be the brother and sister's first experiment in writing for children, Charles at any rate had tried his hand at that pastime.
10130-8{_}6135{_}_The King and Queen of Hearts_ thus becomes his first juvenile work.
10130-8{_}6136{_}*       *       *       *       *  Page 404.
10130-8{_}6137{_}POETRY FOR CHILDREN.
10130-8{_}6138{_}This little book, attributed on the title-page merely to the author of _Mrs.
10130-8{_}6139{_}Leicester's School_, was published in two minute volumes at three shillings by Mrs. Godwin in 1809.
10130-8{_}6140{_}Robert Lloyd, writing from London to his wife in April, 1809, says of Charles and Mary Lamb: "If we may use the expression, their Union of affection is what we conceive of marriage in Heaven.
10130-8{_}6141{_}They are the World _one_ to the _other_.
10130-8{_}6142{_}They are writing a Book of Poetry for children together."
10130-8{_}6143{_}Later: "It is _task_ work to them, they are writing for money, and a Book of Poetry for Children being likely to sell has induced them to compose one."
10130-8{_}6144{_}Writing to Coleridge of the _Poetry for Children_, in June, 1809, Lamb says: "Our little poems are but humble, but they have no name.
10130-8{_}6145{_}You must read them, remembering they were task-work; and perhaps you will admire the number of subjects, all of children, picked out by an old Bachelor and an old Maid.
10130-8{_}6146{_}Many parents would not have found so many."
10130-8{_}6147{_}Charles Lamb, by the way, was then thirty-four, and Mary Lamb forty-four.
10130-8{_}6148{_}In sending the book to Manning, Lamb said that his own share of the poems was only one-third.
10130-8{_}6149{_}The little book seems to have been quickly allowed by its publisher to pass into the void.
10130-8{_}6150{_}Possibly the two-volume form was found to be impracticable: at any rate _Poetry for Children_ disappeared, many of its pieces at various times reappearing with the signature Mrs. Leicester in _The Junior Class-Book_ (two pieces), in _The First Book of Poetry_ (twenty-two pieces) and _The Poetical Class Book_ (three pieces), all compiled by William Frederic Mylius, a Christ's Hospital master, and published by Mrs. Godwin.
10130-8{_}6151{_}Hence the extreme rarity of _Poetry for Children_, which seemed to be completely lost until, in 1877, a copy was found in Australia.
10130-8{_}6152{_}Two or three other copies of the English edition have since come to light.
10130-8{_}6153{_}Mylius used also the frontispieces to the two volumes.
10130-8{_}6154{_}As I have not seen all the editions of these compilations, it is possible that my figures may not be complete.
10130-8{_}6155{_}An American edition of _Poetry for Children_ was published in 1812 at Boston.
10130-8{_}6156{_}The poems "Clock Striking," "Why not do it, Sir, To-day?"
10130-8{_}6157{_}and "Home Delights," were omitted.
